Femi on Facilities Budgeting for Facilities Management (1) The quality and pricing of facilities management is a differentiating factor in today’s luxury real estate market. The investor or landlord who ignores how his tenants and real estate assets are treated does so at his own peril. The icing on the cake in this very competitive market is FM; hence Landlords must ensure that their facilities management standard is commensurate (or even surpass) the tenants’ expectations. Engr Femi Akintunde explains in this article, that the investor/landlord’s quest to exceed tenant’s expectation must start with the budgeting process ... The aspect of budgeting for facilities management or maintenance as it applies to the investor is not what a lot of people consider to be an important exercise.  A lot of property investors don’t do it – people take it as ‘I will spend when I need to spend’. So, when you are considering your annual budget for all your expenses, including children’s education, household expenses for food, medical insurance and so on; you must understand that your physical environment – home, office, etc also needs to be budgeted for. This will help you determine how well these budgeted costs fit into the resources plan expectation and expenditure. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  For real estate, if you spend on your buildings without planning for it, you cannot control your costs. You will end up spending more than is required. The budgeting process enables you to anticipate events. It enables you to prevent crisis, to be better prepared you for any emergencies, and to put contingency plans in place in case of shortages or inadequacies. Another advantage of budget planning for your real estate asset is that you are able to get better prices than if you have to do negotiations at short notices. For example, if a heavy-duty generator that is to be serviced every 250 hours is planned for, you will have an idea of how much every servicing costs. You will have an idea of how long it takes to get to 250 hours; so you will be ready to meet the costs and schedule the servicing at a time convenient to all. Otherwise, you increase the tendency is to run the generator beyond the recommendation hours and get a breakdown. Then the pressure comes to fix the generator before residents arrive or start to complain. You will have to buy parts under emergency and many times you end up spending more. The risk of buying inferior quality is also very high in unplanned situations. There will also be the attendant effect of the impact of this breakdown on your tenants’ lifestyle (or business in the case of commercial spaces); and this will come into play when they are considering renewing their leases. How does the budgeting process take place?  There are two aspects: the capital and operation budget. Operations Budget is for the expenses that you incur to maintain the asset in a form that will continue to deliver the expected services without necessarily increasing, renewing or modifying the existing capacity. Key considerations in an operation budget are Personnel costs, admin costs & consumables, and third-party services. Working on the Operations Budget raises the question of providing services in-house or outsourcing to an FM company. This is a question that is best addressed on its own merits; but my general advice is that the choice of one over the other will depend on the size, scope or variety of services the asset requires. If the in-house option best suits the circumstances, then during the budgeting process, you will have to look at the salary and emoluments of the staff members engaged in the facility management duties and compute the costs for the budget year or period. The second line under the Operations Budget is the tools and equipment that they will use. There are two categories of tools and equipment. There are Management Tools like laptops, telephone etc and operational tools and equipment like toolbox. Consumables refer to items that run down in the course of usage – brooms for cleaners, washing liquid, toilet roll. Generator servicing parts like filter are also involved.  These sounds mundane but there are clear examples of even Grade ‘A’ office complexes without toilet roll or hand wash soap in their washrooms. Third Party Services are items that you have to call specialist companies for.  Generator maintenance, Refuse collection, Swimming pool maintenance, Lift maintenance and so forth. It is advisable to sign a service contract and on that basis, you factor in the costs into the budget. If you outsource the facility management function, the process is relatively easier as the FM Company will come up with the budget.  Typically, the FM Company’s budget highlights the various services and their costs but power is separated from these into its own category. Many of these services are the planned services – like security, cleaning, swimming pool maintenance etc and as the name implies, planned services should be quite certain – you can see and plan ahead. Note however that provision should also be made for unplanned breakdowns. For instance, it is impossible to predict when a door handle will malfunction or a pump will break down. So, we advise that about 20% of the planned budget be set aside as provisional sum for unplanned activities. It is very important that the FM Company and the owner agree on this because when the unplanned events occur, each party will be looking to the other to finance the repairs.  Another point to note is that the Landlord/Investor should also add into the budget, the cost of his own staff who will be the liaison with the FM Company. In the next segment of the article, we will be looking at the capital budget and the best practice in the industry when budgeting for power for real estate assets. You can send comments, questions etc to Engr Femi Akintunde on highbrow@castles.com.ng. Read past articles on www.castles.com.ng   [/read]

A tenant cannot really do much about the kind of flooring in his rented apartment. At the extreme, he can install the flooring he likes (subject to the Landlord’s approval) but generally he would have to leave this when the tenancy comes to an end. Or he could just put temporary covering like carpeting or rugs.

A more beautiful and satisfying way out, especially if you like wood flooring (who doesn’t!) is to install laminate wood flooring.  According to Jabisod Agencies, this type of flooring can be laid on any other floors easily. And it can be removed easily at the end of the lease because removing the tongue and groove in the laminate flooring locks and clips is not difficult. There will be no damage to the Landlord’s floor. The best deal of is that the same floor can be re-laid in another apartment the tenant moves to.

His contractor absconded to Ireland, his quantity surveyor overcharged him for building materials, the road to the site was waterlogged and almost impassable. He had a busy company to run and had virtually no building experience. Yet he was able to project manage the completion of a beautiful 4 bedroom house in Lekki. Olayinka Olalere spoke with a plucky Lagosian, Mr Niran Ladepo, whom to save cost decided to build his own house. What informed your decision to build by yourself? I was living on the mainland with my family and we wanted to move to the island.  The challenge was that we could not afford to buy a house. This was 15 years ago when there were not many developments or people developing houses for sale, so to move to the island meant I had to develop the house that I wanted. So it is a combination of two things. There were not so many developers then so there wasn't a market to buy a finished house and then secondly, even if there was, we could not afford it at that time so I decided to build. Did you have previous experience building or overseeing a construction project? As a very young man in 1990, I was 21 years old. My father was building his house in Gbagada and to a limited extent, I was involved.  I was there when they were drawing up the plans and engaging the builder, and I spent some time on the site a few days in a month. Subsequently, I worked in the admin department of a building construction company. I would not say I had any technical knowledge as such, but if you ask me for my background in building, I would give these two instances. How were you able to control the construction workers? I have a cousin who is an architect so I went to her to help with the design. I was able to contribute a bit and I was also very careful to tell her that we didn't want any excessive or convoluted design that will be difficult to build. When we were finished with the design, she introduced me to a contractor. It was supposed to be a contractor type thing where I pay in stages. By the time we got to the foundation, the contractor was having financial problems and eventually, he had to leave to go to Ireland. We were then faced with the challenge of building. We had a quantity surveyor who recommended another builder but this time, we didn't want a contractor type agreement because I wanted to be more involved in the project. The builder hired the labour. He controlled the labourers, artisans and subcontractors. Did you also buy the building materials yourself and how did you deal with the pricing? This is where I think if you are someone who is passionate about a project, you are more likely to research and ask a lot of questions. We stopped by other ongoing projects to ask questions. It was a combination of asking others and actually going to the market to price that saw us through. We did rely on the building contractor who was a very experienced fellow. We investigated extensively and we talked to our friends that are in the industry, and by and large, we were able to get away with it and I think got the building in on time and within budget.  What problems did you encounter and how did you solve them? There was the challenge of accessing the site, the property is in Lekki phase 1 and then all the roads were not well done. So for a very long time, access to the site was a problem. Vehicles would get stuck in the mud. The roads were non-existent, the drains were non-existent. During the rainy season, there was flooding that would come up to the windows of the car, it was a challenge to get materials to the site.    The other problem was time. I work for myself and my wife works for a bank but what I can just tell others is that once you’re having a building project your mind goes to it all the time. You wake up in the morning, that’s what you think about. There were days my wife went to the site well before she went to work. On some days, I could not resist going back during the day even with traffic to see what was going on.   We also were worried about the structural stability of the building. What we did was we got a structural engineering firm that would come when there was any structural work being done. So we knew that at the end of the day we did not get a building that was structurally defective in any way because there is a check on the building contractors.   Also, the usual problem of finance. You had to find the money. But when you are building, there is a kind of push that comes to you such that you don’t do any frivolous thing, all your money goes towards your project because it tops your priorities.  Did you have professional friends to call on? We had professional friends but in fact, we employed them. The electrical and mechanical contractor was my personal friend. We employed him according to the right specifications and directives. I was in the building community of my church and so I got the Quantity Surveyor for the church to be our Quantity Surveyor. Was your authority ever undermined as a novice? The consultant we got to do the work was now supposed to come up with the plan of where things would go. So when I looked at the plans I was particularly upset that he put an air conditioner in almost every considerable spot even in the boys quarters and in almost every part of the house. I cancelled about two or three in the living room which is very cool till today without those additional air conditioners. I asked why that would be and he said we may want to use it for one thing or the other. I think that is something he should have spoken to me about.  I also had a falling out with the Quantity Surveyor because when it came to decking we used the hollow clay pot type of decking and I asked him to give us how many hollow clay pots we needed to buy. He did a length and breadth calculation and gave me a number. With the hollow clay pot decking, there are places called ribs where the reinforcements should be and there is also a space in the decking for the stairwell. If you use length and breadth and you do not calculate all these extra spaces, you overbuy because those spaces were not going to be covered by the hollow clay pots. He just did length and breadth and in the end, I was stuck with 25% extra. I think once a lot of professionals accept that you are not a novice, that you are not totally bereft of sense, you can work well with them. Did building by yourself save cost? It would have because looking back now at what we spent if we had a developer who built for us and we bought from him, I would assume that we would have spent easily anything from 30% to 50% more and that would have meant at one single go. I know that we saved money but it would be difficult to compare because we did not have a developed building to compare with.  Would you do it again if you had to? Yeah, I would definitely. Although now I would actually look at the options. If it is a personal house, I would not hesitate to build again. It is a fascinating process. It is stressful but you know that this is possibly your largest investment in one particular place, so it is definitely worth the stress. Thank you for your time. That would be all.

post_content: Development begins with a vision; an idea coupled with the skills, desires, and resources necessary to bring the vision to fruition. Formulating the development strategy is a long process and includes site selection and feasibility analysis, the creation of the project pro forma, and an in-depth analysis of the project appraisal and several processes of obtaining of obtaining a construction loan. 1. Important Definitions about Development Strategy These definitions set the framework for the respective roles of various players in the development process: a ) Developer An individual, firm, or entity that locates and secures control of a parcel of land, conceives and appropriate project to be built on that land and obtains the needed regulatory approval for that project. The developer typically provides the seed capital necessary to get a project to the point where all the development rights are vested. This amount is often several percentage points of forecasted value of a project; that is a hundred million project can easily require several hundred thousands of naira to be fully permitted and quite possibly substantial additional funds. These funds are usually reimbursed at the start of the construction or at the close of the construction loan by the investor providing the equity for the project. The developer also usually receives a “promote” or return for the time he has invested and risk he has taken in putting together or promoting the project. b ) Builder The general contractor who does the actual construction of a project, generally by bidding the job out to a variety of subcontractors. The builder must “ bond ” a project , that is , provide assurances from a third party insurer, guarantor, or surety that the builder will provide the funds to finish the project for the contracted price if the builder does not perform as agreed. The contract may be cost plus a fee or fixed price [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    c ) Investor ( owner) An individual, firm or other entity that provides the equity capital necessary to build a project. Frequently investors do not commit themselves until the project is fully vested with development rights. The investor must often assume personal or corporate liability for the construction loan. d ) Lender An individual, firm or other entity that provides the debt capital necessary to build the project. The lender will not commit until the project is fully vested with development rights. e ) Property Manager Typically, an individual, firm or other entity who handles property/facility management once the project is completed and who also may handle the marketing and management of the lease-up and stabilization phase of the project. 2. The Concept: Product Identification and Establishment of Criteria Most developers tend to specialize within a particular sector of development e.g office complex, strip malls, industrial warehouse, residential communities, high rise. Even within a particular sector, there is a tendency to further sub specialization. The selection of a development concept, product identification, and establishment of development criteria are often a matter of strategic pre-selection based on the developers prior tract record and the company ’ s chosen focus. Although some expansion is normal and even expected – that is, into an adjacent state or subsector— a developer choosing to stray too far from his field of expertise will find it more difficult to attract debt and equity capital. 3. Seed Capital and Assembling the Team Most developers have existing sources of seed capital, internal or external, that can be tapped for projects. Almost as a matter of definition, a developer without access to some sort of capital is not a developer. Most experienced developers also have a well-vetted team, both internally and externally, with whom they have worked over the years. In that case, assembling the team may be as simple as gathering the veterans of prior developments together and reviewing the development criteria, alerting them to block out time on their work schedule as appropriate, and receiving feedback as to changing market or regulatory conditions. If a developer is venturing into a new market or sector he may choose to assemble a new team with experience in that area. There are many ways to find out who the respected professional are in any given area. Appraisers, real estate brokers, title companies and real estate lawyers are good sources of information.   4.Market Area Identification An interesting question is raised as to which is better: a fantastic site ( great visibility, choice demographics, excellent drive-by traffic ) in a so-so market ( mediocre occupancy, slightly below average rent etc) or a so-so site ( nearby power lines, bad sight lines, questionable surrounding area ) in a fantastic market ( robust rent growth, booming economy, tight and raising occupancy) . Unless there is a reason to believe that the so-so market conditions are permanent rather than just a phase in a normal business or real estate cycle), choosing the best site over the best market is the prevailing choice, in theory, because markets recover but site cannot move. Although the theory is a simplification, in that the factors that make a site great can change (traffic patterns evolve and demographics are not set in stone), site characteristics do tend to be more stable than market conditions. Every developer produces a product or service designed to meet a particular need. To improve one ’ s chances, it is wise to select a market that is not already saturated by competition, a market that needs a product that can be produced at a competitive price with a good quality and workmanship, a market that shows signs of future growth and improvement. A good indication of current market needs can be found by determining the present vacancy rate, current construction activity, and forecast of growth in demand   5.Land Acquisition: Optioning the Land, Securing Control After initial investigations indicate that there is a reasonable probability of success for the proposed project on a given site, several important steps must be taken. The land on which to construct the project must be secured, regulatory approvals must be obtained, and capital commitments for both the equity and debt portions of the financing must be received. It’s advisable for developers to gain control of the land via an option to purchase the land. An option to purchase is the right, for a limited period of time, to purchase the land at an agreed upon price and terms. This option minimizes the loss of capital if for any reason construction does not go forward. More than one project has been stymied because of last-minute regulatory issue, interest rate hike, construction cost jump, or other market change. Options may be structured in as many ways as a creative developer or his lawyer can devise, but frequently there is an up-front monetary payment and additional monthly payments. These may or may not be applied to the purchased land. Often a landowner will give a reputable developer a free, 45-to-90-day “ look see ”; that is, the developer puts soft capital ( refundable) to show good, marketable title with no undisclosed defects or quiet partners who might surface are the last moment with additional complications Conversations should be conducted with the appropriate planning officials to discuss the viability of the proposed projects from a regulatory point of view. The option should include full rights to go onto the property, conduct studies ( environmental audits, etc ), do tests ( soil borings, etc ) and generally do further due diligence relating to permits necessary for developments. In hot markets or for a top grade site, a land owner may adopt a take-it-or leave it approach and insist on immediate purchase. In that case, the initiative and advantage lies with the developer who has access to ready capital and whose local market knowledge makes him plunge prior to full vesting of all development rights. Sometimes a landowner is willing to contribute her land in return for an interest in the development or provide a long term lease. Such a lease would have to convey full development rights, automatically be subordinate to any financing, and typically be for a minimum term of 30 years; 99 –years are not uncommon. 6. Site Approvals and Building Permit Once the proper land use designation and zoning are clarified, the next step is usually to develop a site plan that shows where the buildings and parking will be located on the site. It generally shows how the developer intends to hook into the necessary utilities ( water, sewer, electricity); comply with various regulations such as building height, lot coverage ratios, floor-area ratio and landscaping and demonstrate compliance with local transportation plans and water management. The length of time necessary to obtain a building permit is a critical factor in development. It may take weeks or months between the initial submission of completed plans and the receipt of approval to commence construction. Often a site-clearing permit or even a foundation permit can be obtained in advance of the full permit, allowing substantial progress to be made and helping a fast track project stay on time. 7. Construction Financing and Implementation A developer will find it essential to develop a general familiarity with the financial markets that have the capability to fund such projects. In addition, a developer must develop access to key people within those markets (such as bank officers and mortgage brokers). One or more sources of funding for the project should be located early on, either by sending out preliminary project packages. Potential lenders may respond with a term sheet, non-bidding, highly-qualified letter stating the amount and the terms under which they would lend on the project as presented. An investor provides the equity capital necessary for actual construction to aid the debt capital to be secured. The developer usually provides the seed equity necessary to get the project to construction. Investors can be individuals of high net worth, insurance companies, and investment banks. Developers may have established a working relationship with an investor or group of investors. A track record of successes tends to attract a following, and a successful developer may accumulate the funds to make a significant investment in his own projects. A developer may choose the desired builder early in the process and have that builder work closely with the architect in designing the project, providing ongoing feedback on best construction methods and material. After the design is completed, the financing committed, the land secured, the permits obtained, and decisions reached on any consequential details, the contract is awarded for construction of the project   Babafemi Awofala is the Founder and Managing Director of Brickstone Partners Limited, An integrated professional service firm providing project finance advisory and transaction structuring for the energy, infrastructure and real estate industry in West Africa. www.brickstone-partners.comMobile 08051262691 Email: hello@brickstone-partners.com     [/read]

post_content: Laying blocks without cracking requires some basic steps to watch out for. If you are careless the probability of having cracked walls will be high. These amongst others are the causes and how to avoid them- (1)Wrong block moulding mixture-Cement and sand mixture for sand needs to be properly checked which is usually between 1:6 to 1:8 depends on types of constituents. Very good mixture for a 9” block will produce 30 pieces worst it should not exceed 50 on any account. Stone dust are also added in a proportion to give a stronger block, trying to save cost by using inadequate cement, sand ratio will weaken your walls and can lead to cracks. (2)Wrong cement mortar mixture-Mortar is what you use as the bond between one block and the other, the blocks are expected to be adequately bonded by the mortar, if this is weak it can also affect the block and can lead to cracking. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    (3)Wrong laying pattern-Blocks should be set on each other in herringbone manner see diagram——   Laying the edge of one block on another causes cracking along the mortar line when is not broken by locking it up with other blocks, The vertical mortar line is the weakest point and should be broken by walls, straight line from top to bottom will cause cracking. (4)Weak Foundation- Weak foundation causes unusual settlements and movements on foundation that will ultimately affects the blockwalls on top, this surely will cause cracks from foundation through the walls . Cracks could be horizontal or vertical, the horizontal requires serious structural remedy because that may be due to uneven settlements. (5) P’lumbness’ or straightness when laying your blocks can also adversely affect the blockwork especially when is terribly done. (6)Boring holes indiscriminately-Electricians and plumbers are major culprits on site when it involves creating holes on block walls. Caution needs to be taken when creating these holes for  scaffolding otherwise you will have crack walls or you can go for total free standing scaffolds. (7)Long, successive horizontal and vertical blockworks without concrete breaks- laying blocks on each other with any height beyond 3.6m without a corresponding concrete break will create pressure on blockwalls which can also cause cracking especially when the blocks are not strong and loadbearing. (8)Wet blocks-Blocks are supposed to be left to dry and strong before usage, usually it takes minimum of 48 hours to cure, using blocks under 24 hours is not advisable and it leads to cracking. (9) Mishandling of blocks-Proper care should be taken when blocks are in use. (10 )Impurities in mixture-When there are impurities in constituents  that make up the block, expect a weak output which will surely leads to cracking. (11) Improper or wrong materials will not help save money but will create problems: for instance using sand gathered from drainage gutter. (12) Loosely compacted blocks during moulding will also affect the block, which will lead to cracking. (13) Inadequate concrete support incase of load. (14) Shrinkage-When you build on a clay soil that contracts and expands. Clay causes movement in foundation and when the foundation is shallow it will affect the blockwall. (15) Using fresh blocks (16) Using unclean sand with clay just as stated in ‘14’ above,clay contracts when is dried and expands when it is wet: these movements causes cracking. (17) Flooding-Areas susceptible to long-term flooding will also experience walls cracking. Water can go underneath foundation, weaken the foundation and cause movements, which will affect the blockwalls and leads to cracking. (18) Differential settlements in foundation-Please check to make sure where you are building, the problem of differential settlements does not arise. (19) Unevenly compacted fill. When you fill the foundation with laterite but you didn’t ‘rammer’ or compact very well the areas with loose soil will affect the blockwall on top of it and cause cracks. (20) When one side settles on rock which can’t have any further settlement with a corresponding soil area that is required to settle, expect cracking of walls especially when the block spans across. (21) Poorly designed structure without adequate planning of walls joining each other. (22) When you have extremely rich mortar mix, this will also affect block and make it to crack, especially when you want to remove and place elsewhere. It causes wall stiffness; there should be room for the wall to breathe. (23) Rapid loading of blockworks-When you have a deadline and you put too many blocks on each other you are most likely to have cracks. (24) Removing props or construction supports too early will create tension on the blockwall which can lead to cracks. (25) When you have deciduous trees with roots growing underneath the foundation. (26) Free standing walls-This is caused by bad designs when you have too many walls not locking with other walls. The isolated walls are likely to crack. (27) Rising damp around building. (28) Poor drainage will make water gather around building which will ultimately affect the walls. (29) Mining activities around building will cause vibration and affects the wall which can cause cracking especially when it involves blasting of rocks etc with explosives. (30) Very short lintel (concrete) on top of windows, doors and other openings will affect the surrounding blocks and cause cracks. (32)  No oversite concrete or german floor.     [/read]

post_content: Higher value for money – Affordable housing is achieved through a collective effort of 5 parties: the government, private sector, professionals, the community and individuals. This week, we look at one of the roles the private sector can play to make housing affordable. The term affordable housing is defined and described in various ways depending on who’s doing the narration and where. But UN-Habitat broadly defines affordable housing as “that which is reasonably adequate in standard and location for a lower- and middle-income occupant(s) and does not cost so much that it prohibits the occupant(s) meeting other basic living costs or threaten their enjoyment of basic human rights.” This definition is widely accepted and quoted; partly because the definition resonates with the average listener as a fair depiction of the concept. Looking carefully at this description, a few inferences can be drawn. Firstly, affordable housing doesn’t infer strictly sub-standard houses in remote locations. That a house is affordable does not mean it has to be the worst house available on the market. Secondly, affordable housing is very cost-centric, seeking out homes for less than average market value. It is this that actually defines a house as being affordable – price. The price has to be right enough to ensure the occupant can meet other basic living costs and enjoy basic human rights life has to offer. In any business or economic transaction what the receiving party essentially seeks is value for money. You enter a grocery store and exchange a Dollar bill for a Snickers bar; you expect to receive a packaged snack with milk chocolate, crunchy nuts and caramel all flowing in one, anything short of this is a reap off. Value for money can either be by attaining a higher quality level at the same price or receiving the same quality level for less money. Either way, subscribers want an efficient and effective product. A widget that meets objectives using fewer resources, and one that meets objectives sooner. The value for money concept partly describes affordable housing. There is no set price limit that makes a house affordable or not, what is important is that it provides higher value for money. This can either be by attaining a higher quality level at lower price or offering the same quality level for much less money than ordinarily available on the market. Simply put – affordable houses give much more value for money than commercially available houses. Say an average 3-bed apartment of about 120sqm floor plate in your choice location ordinarily sells for circa $100,000. How would you describe a well-built 3-bed apartment in your choice location that is being offered for $60,000? I guess you would describe it as affordable. Or perhaps a steal! This is because the property offers higher value for money. This goes to show the relativity of affordable housing as a concept. It’s a moving target that varies from location to location and transaction to transaction. Affordable housing developers need to tweak their financing, construction techniques, spatial utilization, labour size amongst others to ensure they can offer a property “which is reasonably adequate in standard and location” for lower price. This is achieved by applying technology, ingenuity and where available government and community support to offer higher value for money.   Tayo Odunsi is a chartered surveyor and real estate economist. He holds a MSc. in real estate finance and investment from the University of Reading and an MBA from the Imperial College London. He is the CEO of Northcourt Real Estate a real estate research, brokerage and management company with offices in Lagos and Abuja.

Tenant:  When I bought my first car, should I say my first jalopy, I made no noise about it, as there was seemingly nothing to celebrate. Who would be happy for me? Some of my friends who used to struggle for ‘molue’ or public transport with me even declined a free ride. But I knew they did not want to be caught dead in my ‘tokunbo 1998 model Toyota celica.’ I enjoyed my rides alone. On rare occasions however, most especially during the rush hours, on my way from work, I will slow down by a bus-stop and offer to lift some passengers for some company. Turning up their noses in scepticism, some will hop in; others will say something like, ‘you wan enter one chance.’ I would laugh and say to me, ‘you just missed out of your only chance to get home earlier and zoom off. I never stop to pick up a chic, even if she appears stranded. First impression matters a lot, my first car gives a bad one. I am a youthful and virile man, and that is no exaggeration.I have abs, as in six packs, strong facial features, above average height at 6’1, na condition make crayfish bend inside jalopy. Beyond that my small modelling job that I do at the side is beginning to pay off. And that is how I came about my first car. With my 9-5 job, I could not even afford a bike. My friends are ‘beefing’ my new ride, since they could not afford one.’ It is true our salaries are in the same range, but I am a handsome young man. Don’t hate me, hate my maker! I mean, the first day I drove my car home, my landlord was happy for me, he even prayed for me. It did not end there; I ate at dinner with his family that night. He told me keep up at what I was doing. That night, he gave me a parking space behind his bungalow which is just between his place and the BQ I am renting. It was going to be the only car in the compound at that time and I could easily park somewhere else, but I guess he wanted it to be hidden from plain sight. I understood and concurred and we continued living happily ever after. My landlord is a pensioner, at times when I come early enough I would sit with him and his family and we would chat away into the night. He always went on and on about what pensioners go through in this country. How his father who worked in the UK many years ago continued to receive pension until he died even though he retired and returned to Nigeria. Luckily for his family, his wife had built her business well and that is their sustenance now. He was like a father to me, and I respected him a lot, the only thing he frowned against was bringing too many male friends home. He has only daughters and they are all young, mostly teenagers, and I reasoned with him and complied and that made him love me more, or so I thought until the incredible happened. I got this fantastic billboard job for a multinational company and the pay was huge, I would not disclose it here for fear of being marked but it was in 7-digits and I decided to shut down the town. Of course I was not bringing my friends home, I rented a hall, a small one though and threw a party. I asked my landlord if his daughters could come. He said of course, but they never showed. What was even more painful, I was locked out. The gate was locked from within. I tried calling him or another member of his family and got no response. I had hinted him that I bought a tear rubber(new) car which I would launch at the party. I was eager to come show it to him and get a pat on the back. Sadly, I ended up parking the car outside the compound. I strolled down to a friend’s place, somewhere on the next street and spent the night. The next morning, I got the shocker of my life; my landlord told me I could not park my second car in the compound! I went ballistic, was it not bad enough, that he locked me out, the night before? Here I was, the fool, thinking I had a father figure in him; a proud son coming home to show a father his new trophy, and I get a below-the-belt blow. First, he told me he did not approve of my lifestyle: night crawling, womanizing, drunkenness, that he would not risk his daughters getting unwanted pregnancies. I was shocked to my teeth. It was in the same house, we would sit together and chat over a bottle of stout; at times I brought him drinks; at other times, he served me from his treasure trove –his daughter playing waitress. Dumbfounded, I went into my room and sulked for a while but later went to hang out with friends. Ever since, there has been so much friction between us. I now park my new car outside.I moved my jalopy out as well to avoid any form of confrontations. No more chitchats, we just manage to say hi. His wife never said a word to me about the parking issue; she remained aloof on the matter. And his kids avoid me like a leper. He has brainwashed and turned his whole family against me. I am their only tenant. If there is a notice, bills mostly, they slip it under my door whenever I am not around for me to discover once I return. I got this notice that my rent would expire in three months and that I needed to pay in advance. I used to do that out consideration for him just so he could take care of his family. Not anymore. 90 days to go and I can finally move on to better things. If I get a new modelling job, I could rent a nice place where I would be by myself, better still, I am looking for where I can buy land in my income range. I hooked on Castle’s Magazine for the next couple of months. [caption id="attachment_3611" align="aligncenter" width="400"] Landlord[/caption] Landlord: Boys of nowadays, what do they know about life or delaying gratification. He made small money and he started flaunting. It is the duties of us elders in the market to ensure that a child’s head is well screwed together. Though he is not my son, he is the son I never had. If he is not cautioned he will blow his life away. Let him park his car outside, the rain will fall and wet it, the sun would shine and dry it. When the colours begin to fade he would realize his asset is depreciating and he would look for where to invest. He would be forced to think. If he is lucky enough, it would occur to him to start building his own place; a place to call his own. If he chooses to be a prodigal son and squanders his money, ‘na him know. Come to think of it, when I was building my house, I made sacrifices. I opted for cheap land. Friends said to me, “Why would you leave the hustle and bustle of living in the city and move to a village like Igando? That was 15 years ago. Thanks to the Lagos State Government, I am living in the city and my house is on a major road. Today, I drink stout in my own house, but I had to quit many years ago to make allowances for other things. Should he decide to pack his things and leave, it is even better for me. I will let out the apartment to another tenant and collect house rent, commission and agreement, I am the landlord and caretaker of my property, and I will ‘chop’ alone. ‘Papa landlord never use car, na omo tenant go come pack two cars inside the compound, no be so.’’ I am a proud father; but tough enough let go of my new found son.   Does the Landlord have the right to treat his tenant in this manner? post_content: Published 22nd April, 2017 According to the Merriam-Webster dictionary, a Conduit is defined as a natural or artificial channel through which something is conveyed. In relation to Real Estate, it is usually described as a pipe, tube or trough for protection of electric wires or cables. Conduits protect the occupiers from direct contact with wiring and cabling whilst also protecting the wires and cables from being tampered with by unqualified persons. In the last few months, we have discovered shocking uses for conduits as channels for the flow of illicit monies. Our security agencies have discovered stock piles of currencies lodged in buildings scattered across the country. False walls, Conduits, Sewage treatments tanks, basements, farms, forests, and cemeteries are competing with bank vaults for secret storage of, in this scenario, illicit and illegitimate monies. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    Money Laundering and Resultant Effect on Real Estate Market Values. Market valuation of real estate in Nigeria is a true paradox when comparing to values of real estate globally. It conflicts with the accepted drivers of real estate growth which are among others, Infrastructure& Amenities, Contribution to GDP, Inclusive Housing Finance, Mortgage Re-financing, REITS, REICOs,Sound Zoning and Planning Laws, Effective Land Registration System, Effective Administration of Justice and Access to Affordable Housing which drives up demand. Real Estate growth in developed economies which have developed effective systems for observing and measuring real estate growth through transactional market and data intelligence boasts of 6-8% ROI especially as inflationary rates are below 3%. I attended a Foreign Property Investment Forum in London and the “sheer excitement” amongst prospective property investors of 6% growth rates left be deflated and bewilderedie “6% pere??. The Lagos Real Estate Market boasts of yearly average growth rates of 16-20% pa with no true basis or drivers for such growth. Real Estate contributes nominally if at all to the country’s GDP, there is a huge deficit of housing stock and where such housing stock exist, demand is highly ineffective. 80% of legitimate income earners are fenced off the buying market buttressing the report from Nigerian Deposit Insurance Company which revealed that 90% of total deposits in Nigerian Banks are owned by 2% of Nigerians. So who is buying up real estate in Nigeria particularly in Lagos & Abuja?? Your guess is as good as mine. Illicit monies circling around the financial system is laundered into Real Estate. Please picture an image of a high speed Samsung Washing Machine laundering your clothes, that’s how the monies spin through the swanky edifices and buildings seen around our high-brow locations. So a disclaimer before I continue, there are pockets of developments financed by legitimate monies at very uncompetitive lending terms, foreign direct investment in retail and office developments or perhaps capital or profits from legitimate business invested in real estate developments. Majority of developments of this nature are somewhat competitively priced and are easily snapped up corporates, the upper-middle class whose income can accommodate our double digit mortgage rates and/or whose employers can finance such purchases at low lending rates. Back to Illicit Monies-This is generated illegitimately from capital projects and transactions in the public and private sectors. In the public sector it is diversion of public funds by those in position of authority or beneficiaries of such funds given the responsibility and obligation to execute social projects and thereafter breach such obligations with little or no consequence usually in connivance with public sector officials. The said funds find conduits, channels, fluidity in real estate where they are “invested” with little or no requirement for immediate financial returns. It is a safe haven, A Panama or Mauritius until the need for such returns are required particularly when tenure of office expires or should I say when the gravy train comes to a final stop. So the cancerous effect of corruption-funded real estate growth is such that it drives up the value of real estate in unconventional ways namely Vendor A who sells real estate to Purchaser A at such an astronomical value has wet the appetite of Vendor B of similar real estate holdings who would anticipate such inflows. Vendor B would rather wait it out till he locates his beautiful bride, Purchaser B. The actions of Vendor A/B and thought process of Purchaser B ring fences legitimate income earners from accessing the market. Reluctantly there is a large supply of “luxury” without the corresponding demand. The 2016 Vacancy Factor Index released by Financial Derivatives Ltd and RAC’s Housing Price Index for Ikoyi and Victoria Island are at a 72% high with no major variation or deviation till date.   Paradoxically Lagos as a commercial and trade West African hub should ordinarily attract high investor interests from other jurisdictions similarly to London, New York, Johannesburg etc. However the real drivers for real estate growth as I earlier mentioned simply do not exist and savvy investors realise this growth is corruption driven and highly unsustainable. This also accounts for the lack of foreign direct investment into residential real estate market unlike sectors such Telecommunications, Oil and Gas, Financial Services despite the 17million housing deficit figures. A possible solution to stem the flow of illicit monies into real estate is a Property Transaction Register. This is not the same as the Lands Register found in State Land Registries. The requirement for registration is not mandatory and many owners of real estate bye-pass registration with changes in ownership conducted in the absence of registration. Identities of purchasers of real estate should be disclosed in the same way income must be commensurate to purchasing power. Since the proverbial manna no longer falls from heaven, one can only fund real estate purchases from earnings, inheritance or institutional financing.This property registration should be structured as a seamless technology driven process without the usual bureaucratic red tape. It should be mandatory but with incentives for registering such transactions to drive participation and inclusiveness. More so promoters of institutional purchasers such as companies, NGOs and other corporate bodies should also be revealed. Primarily it can provide state governments with transactional data on real estate trading with reliance on such data to develop policies to boost the markets. For purposes of stemming money laundering in real estate it can assist investigations when trying to identify suspicious flow of illicit monies and those in control of companies owing real estate assets. It would be welcoming if real estate stakeholders can generate more solutions and ideas to curb the flow of illicit funds into real estate in order to create a sustainable, data-driven and investor-friendly real estate market. Real estate must be exchanged for real value. Our Conduits should contain wiring and cables not currency. OmorinsolaIpaye (morinsola.ipaye@kparkwoodproperties.com) Real Estate Professional, Legal Advisor and Good Governance Advocate     [/read]

Published June, 2018 Real estate investment has been the gold rush of the past few decades, more so in the last two decades. Most people with spare income make it their first port of call for investment, however, we realized that most people don’t really know when their property investment is a good investment, as they are fixated on the difference between the price they bought and sold, whilst ignoring all the frictional costs in between. We thought this topic was worth looking into. Typically, an investment is anything that gives you more money out than you put in, and the holistic way to look at this when it comes to properties is to look at the total return the property generates. Total return consists of two things, Capital Appreciation and Yield gained during ownership. However, every investor has a different motive for investing, and what they would call a win. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    Some people look for cash cows that can hold value, others are looking for a lump sum at some point in the future, whilst others are looking for an income generating opportunity. So these would all have different conceptions of value. For the latter individual, their perception of a good yield would be what comes in at the end of every month. The path, however, isn’t necessarily that straightforward. The first thing people forget to tack on to their considerations is outlay. Properties require servicing costs for many reasons. For instance, some apartments have service charges equivalent to 1 - 3 months of Income, which is an effective deduction of 25% of your yield. Some properties can even be as bad as 6 - 8 months, especially when major works are going on in the block. As these works can be ongoing for 5 - 10 years. Costs of some major works can be the equivalent of 4 years of rental income. If we are to speak in numbers to help visualization, some buildings have service charges of about £20,000, with the excess sinking fund being set apart in anticipation of major works. So this is clearly something to factor in when considering what property to buy. What is useful in an end user home, such as a swimming pool, gym, and concierge, may never reflect in the rental yield that would be achieved on the property investment. As all those things drive up cost markedly. To quickly address an alternate perspective, some pay for major works and sell before they are able to see the upswing in value to be gained from such works on their property. This is likewise an undesirable position. People who want to benefit now must be conscious of building plans, as these maintenance works aren’t done spontaneously, there have to be long-term plans in place. High service charges aren’t universal, small blocks and ex-council flats, for instance, have typically low service charges. However, if there are major works in ex-council flats, you bear a disproportionate cost to other residents who aren’t private owners, as their costs are absorbed by the council while the freeholder passes a proportion of costs to private owners. We’ve expended a lot of energy on discussing service charges, but there are many more things to consider, such as Capital Gains tax, repair costs, Title renewal etc. So with all this to consider, when is a property investment really a good return? Is it when you sell? Is it what you believe it’s value is? To quote a client Who bought a home in 1974 for £75,000 and had it valued at over £4m, “ I feel good about the capital appreciation but I still need a roof over my head”. An increase in valuation may be great from an emotional perspective, but one still needs to live in that home. We’ve seen MiFID II requirements in European banking, an attempt to ensure fairer, safer and more efficient markets and facilitate greater transparency for all participants. This has forced asset and wealth managers to be more transparent with fees charged during investment, giving investors a clearer picture of how much they make from their investments and how much is lost to frictional costs and fees. We feel first and foremost, that a property investment is best when you are making an income. This is because the costs are high and indeterminate, but as with all things, awareness shifts the balance in your favor, first by influencing what you buy and how you structure your investment, and secondly by factoring in this costs into the price paid, the appreciation expected and the yield sought.   [/read]

Published May, 2017 In 2011, then Lagos State Governor, Babatunde Fashola, in an attempt to deal with the housing issues in the state, signed into The Lagos Tenancy Law 2011. The new law sought to give tenants further protection from landlords than what existing at the time. Mr Fashola, was particularly incensed that landlords demanded two years rent in advance from workers who were paid monthly. And so the clause, which attracted the most attention, was one that restricted the landlord from demanding rents for long periods, in advance. Indeed, Section 4 (3), (4) and (5) stipulates that it is a crime that landlords should demand or tenants pay more than one year’s rent. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    (3) It shall be unlawful for a landlord or his agent to demand or receive from a new or would be tenant rent in excess of one (1) year in respect of any premises. (4) It shall be unlawful for a new or would be tenant to offer or pay rent in excess of one (1) year in respect of any premises. (5) Any person who receives or pays rent in excess of what is prescribed in this Section shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine of One Hundred Thousand Naira (N100,000.00) or to three (3) months imprisonment Aside from the contentious issue of advance rents, the Law protected the tenant form overbearing landlords who seek to curtail the tenant’s use of rented premises. The tenant is entitled to quiet and peaceable enjoyment of the premises, including the right to privacy; freedom from unreasonable disturbance; exclusive possession of the premises, subject to the landlord's restricted right of inspection; and the use of common areas for reasonable and lawful purpose. Where a tenant with the previous consent in writing of the landlord, effects improvements on the premises and the landlord determines the tenancy, such a tenant shall be entitled to claim compensation for the effected improvements on quitting the premises. It is the responsibility of the landlord to effect repairs and maintain the external and common parts of the premises. And when such is done by the tenant upon the landlord's refusal, such tenant has a right to claim compensation as to be determined by the law. Has the Law changed anything in the Landlord/Tenant relationship in Lagos State over the last 6 years? The Law Reform Committee of the Lagos State Government is asking stakeholders and members of the public for their views on the efficacy of the Law. CASTLES Lifestyle took the opportunity to ask several real estate practitioners if, indeed, tenants are better protected. The unanimous view of the practitioners was that, the rental market reacts to the forces of demand and supply. In locations like Apapa GRA, Ikoyi and Victoria Island, which are exempted from the 1 year advance payment law, tenants pay only one year in advance. This is because there is more supply than demand in these areas. On the other hand, in areas like Ilupeju and Surulere, where there is more demand than supply, tenants routinely pay two years rent in advance at the commencement of their tenancies. They revert to paying a year’s rent after the initial period. This is done causally and routinely with neither party paying heed to the ‘crime’ they are committing. Apart from advance payment of rent, the Law is observed mainly in the breach. Especially as many of the stakeholders themselves, not to talk of the general public, are unaware of many provisions of the Law. For instance, the Law stipulates that the Tenant is not to pay the legal fees of the landlord in the rental transaction. All the real estate practitioners (ten in number) we spoke with were unaware of that section of the law. Legal fees are routinely stated to be paid by the tenant in tenancy offer letters. So it appears that business in the rental market, has carried on as before with the Law’s impact lost because of commercial considerations.

post_content: Published May, 2017 We live in the best two bedroom apartment in Lagos. There may be luxury flats in Ikoyi, Victoria Island and Lekki but our flat in Ikeja beats them all by far. It is not really a flat, more like an extension to the main house which is inhabited by our genial easy going Landlord and his equally delightful wife. The apartment is on two floors - the ground floor has the kitchen, living room and store and upstairs are two lovely ensuite rooms. It was meant to be an apartment for the land lord's son but the boy refused to move back home after his degree overseas. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Everything about the apartment is superb. The rent is well below market price as the landlord is ‎more interested in the quality of the tenant than market rent. There is ample car parking space, the land lord's generator is linked to our flat and we enjoy sumptuous meals ever so often from our landlady. Okey and I share the flat. Even though the rent is quite low, there was a time I was out of work for three years and could not pay it. I asked Okey to join me. He would pay ‎the full rent and I was to pay half of the rent when I got a job. Luckily three months ago I found a job and was looking forward to the time I would have saved enough to pay Okey back. Then Okey landed what appeared to be good news. He had asked his long standing girlfriend to marry him when he heard that she was pregnant. She said yes. I was very happy for them.‎ I had put marriage on hold due to my precarious financial position but with my new job came renewed hope. I asked Okey about his plans, fully expecting to be part of them. When did they plan to marry? Where, what kind ‎ of church service would it be? After a while, I noticed that Okey was not looking very happy. What was bothering him? After two days he explained that it was the fact that as he was getting married, I would have to leave the flat. Leave the flat? I was stupefied. What was he talking about? The fact that I had not paid the rent for three years did not mean that it was his flat. He had paid the rent on my behalf. It was a loan. He saw the look on my face and he started explaining how his fiancée liked the flat and since I could not afford it, he thought he would take it over while I looked for somewhere 'smaller'. I walked out on him. What an ingrate! I invited him to join me in the flat specifically to help me until I got on my feet. He enjoyed what was the best rental deal in Lagos because of me. This is how he repays me. What should I do now? Feedback: Please send your advice and comments to enquiries@castlesweekly.com    [/read]

post_content: Published August, 2017 Our story started last week (go to www.castles.com.ng for the first part) where a housemaid called Esther, wielded more power than her position demands. Guess who she got married to?  While everyone was recounting his or her experiences with Esther, Madam was getting visibly bored. I summoned up courage to ask her if she was going to do anything about what she heard but she just shrugged and said that everyone was lying against the poor girl. I must admit that if I had not had an experience with Esther, I would have believed Madam, so innocent was the look on Esther's face. We all soon forgot about Esther and her sly ways and went about our own businesses. About two years down the line my rent was due but there was a problem. My company was going through financial difficulties and only half salaries were being paid. I was in trouble. What was uppermost on my mind was my rent- if I could keep a roof over my head and petrol in my tank, I was confident that I could get over this temporary situation. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    By this time, all of us in the block of flats apart from Madam and Esther had become firm friends. Feeling a bit embarrassed to tell Peter and Mary, I went to see Fikayo, the banker. After playing with his son for a few minutes, we went on the terrace and by the time I told him my story, he started telling me his. Apparently, he had given out a few bad loans, some related to shares as well and to cut a long story short, he was not going to be paid until the loans were sorted out. This had been happening for some months. The good news was that when his rent was due, he had appealed to the Landlord who had said that because of a new wife he (the landlord) was going to marry; he was in a good mood and would defer receipt of the loan for up to a year. Great news I thought. The Okeke's came in just as I was leaving and Fikayo called me back. They were coming for a weekly fellowship on financial breakthrough and he believed that in my circumstances I needed it as well. What had happened to the Okekes? Well their pension cheques had been delayed for some reasons (not Esther!), their children abroad could not send money due to the credit crunch, they could not sell their shares and gullible Mr. Okeke had fallen for a 419 artist who had wiped off their savings. I felt blessed just to hear such misery. The fellowship opened with over thirty minutes of praying for the Landlord who had also allowed the Okeke's to stay in the flat also rent free until they could get on their feet. After the fellowship, we discussed further and it was agreed that I should table my case at the wedding which the landlord had invited all the tenants to. Mrs. Sanusi came to see me that night  since her husband had a stroke and could not drive, she asked if I could drive her to the Landlord's wedding. I tried to remonstrate with her saying that she did not need to go as the Landlord knew of her husband's condition and that she would have to take care of him. She explained that she was not going to fulfill social commitments only but that she needed to ask the Landlord to defer her rent until she could get back on her feet after her husband's unfortunate accident. I agreed that her mission was very important. We all set off for the wedding in a convoy and I remembered thanking God for this wife that was bringing much joy not only to the Landlord but to his tenants as well. You can imagine our shock when we found out that the bride was no other person than Esther, Madam's housemaid. I could not shut my mouth. My eyes met with hers and she gave me a look that I could not comprehend but I knew that my chances of getting a reprieve from our Landlord were almost non existent. My eyes moved to Mrs. Sanusi, the Okeke's and Fikayo. We all had the same expression on our faces  doom. This Esther was certainly not going to save her former co-tenants.   [/read]

Sweet irony of life: my detractor is now my tenant! Published Nov, 2017 ‘This means you are going to ‘do bridges’” My wife’s close friend, Shade, was aghast that my wife was going to move to the Lagos Mainland when we got married. ‘Gbagada is hardly the end of the world” my wife tried to defend the movement. “A few minutes from Lanre’s house and you will be on the Third Mainland Bridge” Shade looked sceptical. She, my wife and their close circle of friends had all grown up in Ikoyi and Victoria Island. They were daughters of senior Government officials and top corporate executives. They were expected to marry young men from their ‘class’ whose parents had the necessary Island flats to give them upon marriage. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    “Can’t Lanre manage to pay for a Lekki mini-flat?” Shade persisted. She did not want her confidant to be far away from her. “I can’t just jump in the car and come and see you in Gbagada. The traffic and security issues, you know. You are really brave to make this move” The conversation went back and forth. Shade trying to convince my wife to convince me to get a place on the Island while my wife conscious of my preference was trying to get her off the topic. Eventually, the debate got heated and both of them stormed off. I was bemused to get a text that Shade would no longer be one of my wife’s bridesmaids. I tried to get the reasons for this out of my wife but she said that she did not want to talk about it. It was about ten years later, when we had moved to our own house at Lekki Phase 1 that my wife told me the reason why. Over the years, she had made up with Shade but the relationship was never the same.  I was more amused than annoyed. Sure, I had enough money to rent an ‘Island’ flat but it would have meant eating into my property acquisition fund and I wanted to get rental properties on the Island before even building my own home. That first night as we savoured the blessing of living in our own home as well as two flats in Dolphin Estate, Ikoyi we pondered on the vanity of Nigerian values. I was to remember the conversation in three years time. By then, I had sold the Dolphin flats at a nice premium and disposed of some land in the Lekki region which gave a handsome profit. With some financial engineering, I was now the proud owner of two blocks of flats in Parkview Estate, Ikoyi. Eight flats in Ikoyi! No mean feat for the Gbagada boy! That fateful day, my Estate Manager had come to see me with a request from a prospective tenant that she wanted to pay the annual rent in instalments. I was irritated. “You know that I don’t accede to such requests. Why are you bothering me?” The Estate Manager said that the woman was insistent that I would want to see her. I was curious. Who could this be?  It turned out to be Shade. She entered the office in a breezy manner as if we were best of friends, telling the Estate Manager in a regal manner to ‘excuse us’. The poor chap out of deference, complied. The long and short of our conversation was that Shade and her ‘Ikoyi-born’ husband needed to rent a flat. She gave a ‘cock and bull’ story about investments tied up in London, getting planning approval for their Banana island plot, the need to be close to their children’s school etc. I saw through all the bravado. I had heard that the ‘Ikoyi-born’ husband was waiting for his father to die so he could get his share of the estate but in the meantime was not ready to do any work. What he did not know, was that heard that his old man had put all the money in trust for the grandchildren and the money will not be touched for some decades to come. The whole of Lagos knew about it but him. It was Shade’s job that helped them to keep appearances. They had to move out of the father’s flat because the old man had sold the property. Wow! This was the worst sort of tenant to have. Keeping up appearances with the Lagos social set meant that the Landlord’s rent was the last to get paid and I could see that Shade was someone who would use her relationship with my wife to be cavalier about rent payment. I told her point blank that I don’t deal with my tenants directly. It was left to the Estate Manager. She tried to lecture me on how that was a bad way of doing business. I agreed with her but said that that was my way of doing it and it had worked for me. When she saw I couldn’t be moved, she sauntered out of the office to speak with the Manager. I knew she would not pass the tough screening tests we put prospective tenants through. A few years later, we at the grand funeral reception party for her Father-in-law. “How’s that your pokey flat in Parkview?” The tone she gave Parkview Estate was as if the place was in Mowe. I grinned and sipped the excellent champagne on offer. The Will would be read soon and expectations would be cut short. She might even saunter back to convince me that she wants to ‘manage’ to rent my flat. I will fob her off to the Estate Manager like I did the last time. Gbagada boys don’t play with their rent money.  Come to think of it, should I still be calling myself a “Gbagada boy’ now that I am living in my own mansion in Banana Island?   [/read]

Published Affordable housing is achieved through a collective effort of 5 parties: the government, private sector, professionals, the community and individuals. This week, we look at one of the roles the government can play to make housing affordable. Land is very expensive. It amounts to about 25 to 65% of the total cost of developing a single house unit depending on what part of the earth you’re standing. Ironically, land is defined as a free gift of nature. Free, yet so expensive, even when property prices stagnate or reduce, land values seem to always soar. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    Governments in different countries hold varied roles with regards to land management; some own all land, some own a portion while some governments have so liberalised land ownership that they struggle to access the resource. But one thing almost all governments retain is the powers to issue or refuse planning permission for the development of land. Government can use these planning powers to make land less expensive to buyers without reducing the unit price of the land in three distinctly related ways. Firstly, Government can make land less expensive by reducing setback and building line requirements. Setbacks refer to the distance that a building is located from its boundaries to the street and to neighbouring properties. Take for illustration a parcel of land measuring 600sqm (30m by 20m) and which costs $1,000 per sqm. This amounts to $600,000. In a country like Nigeria, only about 50% of the land can be developed upon due to the setback laws (averagely). As such utility is only derived from 50% of the land in exchange for a value of $600,000. Should the setbacks be reduced by an additional 25%, 75% of the land gives a higher utility but for the same price. This is the case in the UK and several other European countries where a lot of houses are built without any setbacks between them and 1 or 2 metre front setbacks. This amounts to development on up to 80% of land. Again, governments can reduce the price of land quite similarly by increasing the density of development permissible on plots of land. Where landowners are allowed to develop more than 2 to 3 floors on the average, the cost portion of land to the total development cost diminishes as the development goes higher. Finally, most parcels of land have a designated land use class. This may be agricultural, residential, commercial, place of worship etc. While such designations are good for giving order to development in towns and cities, planning laws should not be stagnant but dynamically seek to create a sustainable and serene environment. This may require changing land uses as neighbourhoods become gentrified or renewed. By so doing, Government can make land cheaper by re-zoning the use of land to a more viable use. Often times, different uses would pay different prices for land in a particular location. Dynamic zoning laws often permit the use of land for its highest and best use. Cheaper in the three scenarios described means to increase the value of the land without a corresponding rise in the price the owner pays for it. Should any or all these ideas be implemented in a developing country, prices may rise initially due to pent up demand, but this will soon fizzle out as the new becomes the norm and property values return to being determined primarily by market forces rather than a dynamic move by the government to stimulate development. By Tayo Odunsi Tayo Odunsi is a chartered surveyor and real estate economist. He holds a MSc. in real estate finance and investment from the University of Reading and an MBA from the Imperial College London. He is the CEO of Northcourt Real Estate a real estate research, brokerage and management company with offices in Lagos and Abuja. Contact: tayo.odunsi@northcourtrealestate.com   [/read]
