post_content: Published February 2018  Baba Fela is a typical old time Lagos Landlord. He has property in choice areas like Ikoyi and Victoria Island but lives in a modest house in Surulere. “I can’t afford to live in such expensive areas. Rather, the rent I collect acts like my pension and so I am not a burden on my children” Rental returns in Baba Fela’s time were a very good and safe source of return. Rents used to go up regularly. In the cases where the rent was stated in US dollars, it was a hedge against the depreciation of the Naira. Is that the same situation today? What advice should we give anyone looking at investing for rental returns in 2018? This is the question we will try to answer in simple terms in this article…… [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  RETURNS: Which property will give the best rental returns for the amount you want to spend? If two properties will cost the same amount to acquire and one will give higher rents than the other, then the investor should go for the one with the higher rent. It is important that you don’t allow emotions to cloud your judgment if you are looking at investing for rents. You don’t need to like the house; you need to like the returns! As an investor, you also have  to compare this profitability against alternative investment options such as the stock market, treasury bills, fixed deposit etc. Rental income is usually between 5% and 10% but investment in Treasury Bills was as high as 18% at a time. However, investing in property for rental income is usually for the long term and over time the value of the house may increase. This is called capital gains. But you cannot get the capital gains until you sell the house. So the investor must weigh all these in considering purchasing a house for rental income.   RISKS: Another factor you have to consider are the associated risks that might prevent you from getting your return. Fire, vandalism etc are potential risks to the property, although they are rare. Other issues may not affect your property directly but can impact the rents you get. An example is the Badoo cult in Ikorodu may make people leave your house in that area even though they have not been attacked. More common problems are:  non-paying tenants and void periods (when you are unable to get tenants into your property). Most Landlords can relate to the experience of having an unreasonable tenant. A stubborn tenant might decide to stay put in your house without paying rent. The landlord loses the income from the rent and he has to spend money to get the tenant out. A landlord in this situation would wish he had invested in fixed deposit or Treasury Bills   COSTS OF HOLDING THE INVESTMENT:  There are costs involved in holding property as an investment. Generally, there are some obligations landlords have to meet. Painting the exterior of the house, keeping the house wind and watertight are some examples. But there are some costs that are not obvious. For instance, you buy an apartment in 1004 Estate in Victoria Island, you will have to pay service charge if tenants are not in the property. Otherwise, you risk accumulating the service charge. In fact, it is double trouble when you have an uncooperative tenant who has refused to pay the service charge or leave your house. When such tenant eventually leaves, the onus is on you to clear the accumulated service charge before a new tenant comes in. Landlords in the high end locations like Ikoyi have found out that when tenants leave, they have to commit substantial funds to ‘updating’ the property. If not, they will not attract tenants. These are all cost against the house and borne by the Landlord. In essence, while we say the return is the rent as a percentage of the cost of the house at the time you bought it, in reality, you should include these other costs. Effectively, it could mean that your return can be far lower than the initial calculation obtained when other costs are factored in.   For many people, rent is considered almost foolproof, some people see as their pension, constant source of income etc. But the market itself is changing and landlords have to keep up with the times in terms of how they can ensure they get the best rent.   [/read]

When modernist design is constrained by planning rules

post_content: Two weeks ago, we waxed lyrical about a design “House in Llavaneres’ which followed the contours and incline of the site. This week, we marvel about a design, which is on a regular plot but because of planning regulations, has a quirky façade. Atelier Boronski who designed the T-House in Kyoto, Japan describe it thus: On a hill overlooking Kyoto this house had to negotiate some strict city planning regulations. But on the inside we could think freely. This house is a static volume with various private spaces inserted. The public spaces form　a single connected volume, with the main stairway sweeping through it all. In this way we could achieve an expansive and dramatic triple height living volume. `It is a stunning example of what can be created when enterprising architects are confronted with restraints and are challenged to design something extraordinary and unique.

Published July, 2017 The car wars started when three tenants, who happened to be bankers, moved into a townhouse complex with more cars than the parking lots. They then proceeded to takeover the slots meant for the other tenants and the Landlord. Then something strange happened to one of them… (read the first two parts of the story on www.castles.com.ng)   Olufunmilayo Olusola, my dear wife, was looking at Toye with a look of satisfaction. She mumbled a few words of comfort but her heart was not in it. Toye left a broken man: his marriage and career in tatters. With Toye out of the compound, the number of cars reduced from thirteen to nine. This meant that we could all park our cars comfortably in the compound. The two expatriates had a Toyota truck each, Ejike and Emeka, the two bankers had three cars each and we had our slightly battered Honda Civc. Becaue there were only two slots per resident, Ejike and Emeka were parking their ‘extra’ cars in the free parking slots of the expatriates. It was not the ideal situation but at least the expatriates were not complaining. It was only Olufunmilayo Olusola, that was complaining.  She just could not accept the fact that the two bankers were enjoying free parking. I managed to calm her down and things went fairly smoothly. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Then one day, we got home to find a bus parked in the slot for vacant unit. It had the name of one of the popular Pentecostal churches on its side. Olufunmilayo Olusola went ballistic. She got out of the car and went directly to Ejike’s apartment. His wife opened the door. “What is that bus doing in this compound?” Olufunmilayo Olusola, queried the woman. “Oh” the woman squealed in delight. “Emeka is now a full pastor, so we are in charge of the church bus. Since there is free space here, we decided to bring it home.” “So you will be parking four vehicles in this compound?” Olufunmilayo Olusola’s tone was icy. She started sprouting something about Obed Edom and the ark and how the bus will bring blessings to the compound. Olufunmilayo Olusola turned on her heel and motioned that I was to come with her and say no more. As soon as we were alone, I asked her why she went to Emeka’s house instead of Ejike’s. “Ejike could have been the one who parked the bus.” “No. You see Ejike responded with empathy and concern over Toye’s, emm, plight. But Emeka was very hard on Toye and that marked him in my mind as one of those unforgiving spiritual people, high in a church’s hierarchy” There was really nothing I could say to that. The next morning, we woke up to an altercation between Emeka and Sam, one of the expatriates. The length of the bus meant that Sam could not reverse from his spot until Emeka moved the bus. Emeka had taken his time to get out and this had led to a flaming row. The long and short of it was that Sam banned Emeka from his (Sam’s) extra parking slot and Emeka simply moved into the extra space originally meant for Toye. Olufunmilayo Olusola’s entreaties to Emeka to understand that he could not appropriate four slots instead of two, were ignored by him. I should have expected it. I got home two nights later to utter chaos in the compound. Some fellows wearing the uniform of the Drug Enforcement Agency were milling around the church bus. They had found cocaine in it! And the drug bust had been carried out during a House Fellowship in Emeka’s house.  The church members were violently praying down ‘confusion into the camp of the enemy’……….. Continued next week   [/read]

Published July, 2017 The car wars started when three tenants, who happened to be bankers, moved into a townhouse complex, bringing with them more cars than the available parking slots. They then proceeded to takeover the slots meant for other tenants and the Landlord. Then something strange happened to one of them. He had to leave the compound. Now cocaine has been found in the bus of another! (read the first three parts of this story on www.castles.com.ng) [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Pandemonium. Cocaine in the church bus? The church members kept raising their voices and praying but I noticed that some were giving Emeka strange looks. The man was stupefied and shell shocked. While all this was going on, I saw my wife, Olufunmilayo Olusola, looking calm. She had her eyes fixed on the Drug Enforcement officers. The way a supervisor looks when overseeing an operation of her subordinates. Was that an imperceptible nod from the Head of the team as they drove out with Emeka, the bus and all his cars. They were to be impounded as evidence. It took Emeka, several months to clear his name. By which time, he had be dropped as a pastor by his church and demoted by his employer. He returned to the compound a sober man but now with just two cars. He had to sell his Land Rover to meet his legal fees. He was now ‘behaving’,  Olufunmilayo Olusola, grimly commented.   I was flabbergasted. What was happening in this compound? Could my wife have been orchestrating all these calamities on our tenants? Her father had all the connections in Nigeria. He could do and undo. I had seen some of his steel in Olufunmilayo Olusola, when she negotiated some contracts on his behalf. One day, I saw her gaze fixated on Ejike, the only tenant left with three cars, instead of the two permitted by the lease. “What are you planning against Ejike?” I used the element of surprise to shock a response out of her. There it was. I saw it. There was a flash of surprise in her eyes and I could see she was calculating on the best way to answer me. “Whatever do you mean darling?” she moved close to me brushing off some imaginary lint on my suit. I was clear that she was going to use her feminine powers of persuasion to get out of this. I moved out of her reach. Her devastating beauty and personality, which made me propose to her a few hours after meeting her. “Nothing suspicious should happen to Ejike. I know you are upset about the parking habits of our tenants but this is not a Godfather movie. Strange things cannot keep happening to our tenants” “Darling, sweetheart, sugar blossom. Whatever are you thinking? That I am behind all what happened to Toye and Emeka? Me? This small girl” As she was saying this, she was moving to wards me and I was backing down, until she had me pinned to a corner. “If anything happens to Ejike, I will know that you are behind it” I kept my wits about me. She put her hands up in mock surrender. “I don’t know what you are talking about but I will guard Ejike with my life” she said dramatically. A few days later, I got home to see several cars in the compound. Some had the logo of the bank where Ejike works on them. This was the last straw. I charged into Ejike’s apartment demanding why he should have parked in all the slots. He was surprised and denied the charge. I insisted that he come out and see. “These are the protocol cars of my Chairman and CEO. What are they doing here?” The driver pointed to my apartment. At that point two distinguished gentlemen, escorted by my wife, came out of the apartment. “Good evening Sir, Good evening Sir”. Ejike almost bent double to greet them. The CEO, recognising Ejike greeted him and introduced him to the Chairman. “I hope he is not causing you any trouble at all” the Chairman said jocularly. Ejike and I turned to Olufunmilayo Olusola, a silent plea in our eyes. “Not at all.” She said after a few seconds. “He is a model tenant”. Her eyes went meaningfully to Ejike’s third car. By the next day, the third car was gone. Never to be seen again in the compound. Concluded.   [/read]

Published July, 2017 I only really sleep at night after 3:47 am. That was the exact time, when I woke up to find three armed men at my bedside. Before that frightening wake up call, I was a deep sleeper: so deep that I slept through the cutting of the burglar bars and the fiddling of the lock on the bedroom door. How do you describe the feeling of opening your eyes to find yourself looking into the business end of a double barrelled gun? Then lifting your eyes and looking into the pupils of eyes straight from the pits of hell. I knew that behind those eyes was a brain calculating whether to pull the trigger or not. I wish I could say that I was heroic about it. The truth was that I did not know when I messed myself as I lost control of my bowels. I don’t know if that was the time, my family lost respect for me or when the bandits took forceful carnal knowledge of my wife and daughter. Either way, the family was never the same again after that night. My family now live in England, while due to the need to earn a living and maintain them over there I have to stay in Nigeria. It’s funny when I go abroad I sleep soundly through the night. It could be in New York with sirens blaring through the night or any equally noisy European town or even nearby Ghana. As soon as my head hits the pillow, it will be till the next morning before my eyelids open. But once I am in Nigeria, its nightmares until 3:47am. I have moved houses several times just because I heard a mere whisper that the area may not be safe or I notice a possible security risk. So I was very happy to rent a flat from a former top Police officer. There were mobile policemen at the gate of the house and the police security van always made a stop at the house anytime they were passing by. I gratefully paid over and above the rental rates for that area and moved in. it did not matter that the water was not running all the time or the services were atrocious, the sight of four mopol guarding the house was all the facilities management I needed. Then disaster struck. There was a probe into my landlord’s activities in the Force and before I knew it, the mopol were removed and the police patrols stopped. It was then I realised how exposed the house was. The burglar bars were very flimsy, the doors were mere wooden doors and not security doors and worse, there was an opening in the ceiling, through which the plumber was to get to the water tanks. A point of access to the tanks from inside the flat could also be the way an enterprising assailant could get into the flat. I immediately started looking for another apartment. Is this how other armed robbery or kidnap victims also look for apartments in Lagos?  Always looking for the one with the best security? I wonder how many psychologically damaged people are out there…..like me, seeing  only the security threat in any house? Can’t someone lose his mind this way?
post_title: I cannot help it if I am afraid.

post_content: Published August, 2017 "There is never a right time for a man to get married" the words of my deceased father floated clearly into my ears as Chinwe delivered her ultimatum. We had been dating for six years and although I had proposed to her and had told both our families unofficially that we were a couple, we had not actually set a date.   I must admit that the delay in getting to the altar was entirely my fault as Chinwe was ready to become my Mrs at any time of my choosing. I, on the other hand was of the opinion that a man must be financially buoyant before taking a wife. Immediately I proposed I started making saving up and making investments that would make our marriage start on solid ground. I invested heavily in the stockmarket, which was booming at the time and was on my way to meeting my financial goals when my Dad died. This setback meant that I, the only male  child had to meet most of the funeral expenses. I had to spend millions, some of which were borrowed funds.This meant that all my marriage plans had come to nought. I had to start again. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Chinwe was very sympathetic and supportive but pointed out that my delay had meant that my Dad had not witnessed our marriage. My procrastination had resulted in pushing the marriage date, time and time again that the death had occurred before the marriage. I felt bad but was all the more resolved that my marriage would take off on a sound financial footing.   I decided to move jobs from the banking sector to a telecommunications company. With the way the sector was booming, it seemed that the sky was the limit for a sharp professional like me. All was going well at first- I got some incredible bonuses and a large loan from my old bank. I am ashamed to say here that I fell for the MMM scheme.  I lost millions and with the burial money and loan still outstanding, I also had the harassment of debt collectors coming after me. On top of it all, as my employer's fortunes crashed, I had not been paid for about 6 months.   It was in this situation that Chinwe was now pressing for a marriage date in the next three months. I tried to show her the financial situation but she always had an answer for everything. I told her that I could not afford a while wedding and she settled for a simple registry ceremony.  On matters of things like aso ebi, wedding reception and other things important for a bride she made serious concessions. There was however one important matter I had to settle before the wedding. Our marital home. With my present financial situation I could not afford to pay the rent on our dream flat in Yaba. Chinwe's Mother overheard us and agreed to pay rent for the first two years. Chinwe jumped for joy but I was not so sure. Shouldn't a man be able to pay his own rent as a married man? Could this be held against me in future? Maybe I should postpone the wedding for one last time so I can raise the money for the rent? Will Chinwe act true to her threat and call the whole marriage off?   Advice can be sent to enquiries@castlesweekly.com   [/read]

post_content: Published March, 2017 They have begun again. God must send them a miracle tonight, just like He was demanded to send miracles last week. The prayerful people were shouting in tongues and singing for joy, while I was battling to sleep. Sometimes, I felt slightly sinful for becoming so angry at people’s prayers, but the noise seemed like they were having the vigil in my house. My landlord’s Miracle Vigil was held every Friday from 10pm to 4am. I was a participant; my willingness had never been an issue. I had moved from my former apartment mainly because of the church down the street. They had prayer sessions twice a week and Praise Night once a week. I also participated from my bedroom. I was once pushed to the edge, I went to meet the pastor and pleaded with him to remove or reduce the volume of the microphone stationed outside his church. He looked at me like I was the devil, squinted his eyes and said in his best preachy voice, “the purpose of the microphone is to bring people closer to God. When they hear the word, they are convinced. Do you want to stop God’s work?” I had to look like a saint and reply, “No sir. But God also wants us to rest”. I said that part under my breath, afraid that he will rebuke me if I said anything again. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  I put my head under my pillow and forced myself to sleep. “O lord, enlarge my territory”, was the last prayer point I heard before I drifted to sleep for a short while, waking up 30 minutes later with a headache.  The sitting room used for the vigil was directly on top of my room. I stood up and went to the kitchen looking for what to eat. I had given up on sleep. The next day, I saw my landlord talking to the gateman downstairs. I hurriedly went to meet him. We exchanged greetings and I wanted to tell him how I couldn’t sleep during the vigil but I felt a little ashamed to speak my mind. I later told him, “Ah! That vigil was so powerful, I couldn’t sleep.” He just smiled and said he hoped I prayed along with them. I nodded. The gateman must have sensed my sarcasm, which the landlord chose to ignore and smirked with his head bowed. My head still ached and I had a meeting at the office in an hour. I went to prepare my slides for the meeting. I had planned to prepare them early in the morning, after a good night’s sleep, but it seemed that the Miracle Vigil was now every Friday. For the next one month, I hardly slept on Fridays. The problem was I had meetings almost every Saturday; therefore, I was always drowsy and had a splitting headache. I tried changing the room I slept in, but there was no significant difference. It seemed these people now moved to every part of the house to pray. Their impact could be felt everywhere. I tried to plead with the landlord, telling him that maybe all the, ‘Blood of Jesus’ shouts could be reduced. I wondered why other tenants didn’t complain and later found out that although the sound was not as loud as mine from their side of the compound, they had devised means to deal with the landlord’s excesses. One tenant said he moved in with his friend on Fridays to have a peaceful night. Another said I should be happy it wasn’t into voodoo that was practised every night. She went further to tell me tales of her former landlord. Am I to move because of my landlord? I think there should be tenant laws against this kind of disturbance? How can we develop without respecting the privacy of others?  The Lagos State Government has promulgated laws against noise pollution from religious bodies but what about private night vigils? Comments to enquiries@castlesweekly.com   [/read]

Published December, 2017 I work in a construction company on the Island as an Executive Assistant and was one of the favourite staff members of Mr. Ken Schlong, the expatriate CEO. I used to live in a miniflat around Owode area with my wife and two kids before problems started with the landlord. I had some arrears on the rent which I promised to pay up soon but the man got impatient and threw us out of the apartment six months ago. Fortunately, at about the same time, Mr. Schlong was transferred to Ghana as the new Regional Head for West Africa. Just before he left, I told him about my predicament and he asked me to move into his four bedroom duplex in Ikoyi since he still has a year and half on his rent. The landlord had refused to refund the balance rent as he was worried that he may not be able to let out the property. I was grateful for his generosity and we moved in the day after he left. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  The house was beautiful and my children, Tayo, 13, and Sola, 15, had their own rooms for the first time in their lives. The big 27KVA ‘silent’ generator that powered the house was still available and that was where trouble started for me. After a week of running the generator, we were out of diesel. Calculating diesel costs meant we needed to find an alternative and we switched to the ‘I-better-pass-my-neighbour’ we brought from our former apartment. With this, we suddenly became a nuisance to the quiet neighbourhood because you hardly notice when there is no power as all the generators come on silently and automatically. As for the swimming pool and DSTV, we did not bother to use them when we found out the cost of maintaining these facilities. We could only use two of the twelve air-conditioners in the house. Do you know the cost of servicing one air conditioner?! We could not use the gas cooker – it was just too expensive. So we resumed using the kerosene stove. The soap for the washing machine was way out of our budget. Also apparently, the cost of electricity is more in these highbrow areas – so I was shocked at the electricity bills of this size of house! I only had to pay for the lighting of two rooms before but here there were four rooms, five bathrooms, two living rooms, a large kitchen and a study, whose lights were draining me. I got my family to switch all of them off at night only to find out that the security lights were a major cost on the electricity bill.  My wife and I were just learning how expensive it is to live in a big house Six months into the use of the place and my kids are already getting used to the standards of the area and now despise me for not being able to afford the upkeep of the house. Anytime I have to put on our little generator, they just grunt and head off to bed. As if that was not enough, I have been harassed by the neighbourhood security men who often take me for a loiterer anytime I take a stroll. The look on the faces on some residents of the area when they drive past me in their flashy cars also reveals a lot of disdain as if I were an unwanted intruder. I’m already tired of the whole situation and I still don’t have enough saved up for another apartment. I won’t be due for a loan at work until next two years after I pay up the present one I’m servicing. The only other option I have is to move in with my mother-in-law at her house in Ikorodu. She is a nice woman and wouldn’t complain but I’m very reluctant to take that option. This place is turning into a nightmare for me and my family but I don’t know what to do. Should we stay and continue enduring all these expenses or just move to Ikorodu to stay with my mother-in-law? I honestly don’t know!   [/read]

post_content: Published November, 2017 A real estate agent is offering a 2 bedroom flat in Dolphin Estate Ikoyi for N1.2million per annum. Read very closely and you will find that the Estate Agency is actually referring to a Servants Quarters (Boys Quarters) which has been ‘done up’ to look like a flat. Now how is this information of any use to you if you require a duplex in the said Dolphin Estate? Well, the Estate Agent is offering 4 bedroom Dolphin Duplexes (with 3 rooms BQ) at N3.5m and N4m per annum. If you do the maths, you will come to the calculation that, if you have no need of the servants quarters and you sub-let it, your actual rent will be significantly reduced to N2.3m/N2.8m. That is a third off the rental rates! We have found that there is strong demand by singles for such accommodation in the upmarket areas of Ikoyi, Lekki, Victoria Island and central parts of the Mainland. These, invariably young and employed singles trade off space for proximity to their places of work and the lure of an impressive address. So a number of renters who are feeling the pinch of the times have resorted to subletting their servants quarter. That way, they reduce their rental costs significantly. For the Tenant who wants to sub-let there are some hurdles to cross. First, there is the legal hurdle of the clause in your Tenancy Agreement prohibiting you from sub-letting without the consent of your Landlord. If you want to part with the BQ of the property you want to let ensure that this clause is not inserted in the document. What Landlords insist on usually is that the tenant cannot sublet without the consent of the Landlord but that the consent must not be unreasonably refused. The second hurdle is getting the right type of Sub-tenant. You are going to be living in close proximity to this person and will be sharing your compound with him/her. There must be detailed rules agreed to from the start and you must ensure that the person has the character to abide by the rules. It’s not that easy to get 34% off your rent!

post_content: Published March, 2017   There is nothing so disenchanting as uneven steps (called risers in construction parlance) in a building. It is even more annoying to discover the uneven steps can be easily avoided if basic care and attention to detail was given during the construction period. Concrete stairs are built by pouring concrete into a wooden (usually) formwork which reinforcement (steel rods) have been placed. When the concrete hardens, the formwork is removed. It is not rocket science to understand that if the concrete stairs will take the shape of the formwork. So it therefore stands to reason to ensure that the formwork, which is to be built by a carpenter, is built to the exact specifications of the drawings. The risers steps must be of the same height, width and depth. Even an untrained eye would be able to see that if the boxes that make up the stairs are not even. Do not accept that any mistakes will be corrected during casting (the pouring of the concrete) as this is a case of ‘what you see is what you get’. It is not enough that the risers are all even. ‘Accidents’ can happen during casting so the carpenter must ensure that good strong wood planks are used and they are braced properly. This is to ensure that the formwork is rigid during casting: otherwise the concrete will take whatever shape the formwork moves to. The workmen pouring the concrete must take great care to ensure that the concrete is poured evenly and any movement of the formwork must be reported with the carpenter in place to repair the breach. Ensure that the concrete is properly set before the form work is removed and you should have perfectly even stairs. The threads (the top of the stairs should be leveled into evenly. Some builders argue that uneven stairs can be corrected by chiseling and during the tile laying process. It is true that some remedial work can be undertaken at this stage but it can never beat the results that would be obtained if things were done properly the first time. Even steps takeaways • Ensure that the carpenter is experienced. • Use good strong wood/planks to build the formwork • Make sure the formwork is rigid • Care must be taken during casting and any movement of the formwork reported and repaired • Threads must be leveled. • Allow concrete to set properly before removing formwork.

post_content: Published March, 2017   It is wrong to throw caution to the wind when carrying out a construction project. Because structures have to interact with their environments, several factors naturally affect them. If it is not wind, it’s their self-weight or imposed load. There is a common saying that ‘you have to be able to carry yourself before you can carry someone or something else. This assertion is also valid for structures. They have to possess enough strength to support themselves and even more to resist any other external or internal forces that might want to impede on their integrity or destabilize them whichever way and they must be able to do so throughout their estimated life span for them to be considered safe structurally. There are no excuses for building collapse especially occasioned by negligence or human error hence the need to get it right at all times. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  The provision for reinforcement in the column shown in the picture (case study) was inadequate hence the column began to buckle under load from inside out. The process of buckling would normally begin with the reinforcement inside the structural member which can be likened to the ‘skeleton of a human body’, that explains why you can see the reinforcing bars bending inside the concrete. As they struggle under the burden of excess load, they begin to bend in a certain direction usually of least resistance. With increased stresses along the member, the bending moment increases and the concrete also begin to bend in that direction also. With time you notice a slight tilt from say a perfectly vertical position (for columns) and from a perfectly horizontal position (for beams). As the burden of the load on it increases, the tilt begins to go wayward; this becomes very obvious to observers. If not checked and corrected, the member might fail totally, leading to a collapse. Columns aren’t just built, each of them are designed to carry a certain amount of load which if in excess can cause them to fail. For instance a column designed to support a maximum load of 70kN should not be subjected to load greater than 70; in the same way it is dangerous to put a 50kg bag of cement on the head of a baby boy weighing 28kg. He is most likely to crumble under the load and sustain fracture. If a column is not constructed properly with respect to its concrete mix, moisture content, compaction, reinforcement provisions, etc. it might not meet its design strength and so becomes defective. Whatever the case, where there are defective columns or beams on a structure, it can be strengthened by a process known as Shoring and Replacement. By shoring a column you provide a temporary system to support the load on it while you remove the existing column and recast a new one in place of the old one then you disengage the temporary support once it has achieve adequate strength or alternatively you add a new column which is not surplus to requirement to the existing one and build it into the beam above it and the starter bar of the existing column as seen in the next picture. This operation is critical and you should engage a professional structural engineer to perform it successfully. Engr. post_content: Published March, 2017   Bill of Quantities (BOQ) is literally the quantities of different materials required for a construction project. For the cost conscious layman it should actually be the starting point of his project. A causal discussion with a Quantity Surveyor (the professional trained to draw up a BOQ) should be able to give a rough idea of how much the cost would be. He will possibly hedge his comments stating that it relies on a number of factors and the layman should take note of these factors. One of such factors will be the quality of the soil in the area he/she wants to build. Generally the less compact the soil, the more money would go into putting in a solid foundation to carry the weight of the building. If you want to know the cost implications of a building a bungalow on the land vis-à-vis a one storey building, you can make an informed estimate rather than assumptions which bear no resemblance to reality. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"] Having the various factors which can impact on a building cost in mind then you can give a brief more in line with your pocket to the architect who is to draw a building design. Generally three things impact on the cost of construction: the size of the structure, the finishes to be used and how intricate the design is. Even a layman will accept that a three storey building is likely to cost more than a two storey building, likewise if you use expensive materials the building cost will be higher than if cheaper materials are used. What may not be readily apparent is that the more intricate and complex a building design is, it could significantly add to the cost. Arches, decorative columns etc do not come cheap. Once the architectural drawings are available, the BOQ can be prepared if copy of the drawings are given to a quantity surveyor. He prepares the Bill of Quantities based the on the drawings which gives the client a clue of the cost implication. If after the BOQ is prepared and the cost is beyond the budget of the client or the cost is too high then a quantity surveyor can sit with the client to reduce the cost because BOQ gives the full information that can allow for amendment; for instance at a sitting a quantity surveyor can advise on how client can down size the project. This advice might be on the quality of finishes to be used which may not require any change in the architectural drawings bit if the advice hinges on size or intricacy of building design, if the layman does not want to end up with a project he cannot complete, another visit to the architect may be required which will require changes which again should be cost against using another BOQ. Aside from alerting you on the total cost of the project, the sectional cost of different stages of the project -foundation cost, ground floor cost, decking or slab, roofing cost etc also become apparent, helping the layman to plan his cash flow. Obviously some stages, for example casting the floor slab cannot be broken further and the would- be landlord has to find the entire cash (or get trade financing from the contractor) for that section. The BOQ also guides in negotiating with contractors. If a contractor’s quote substantially less for a section or the entire project then it is either your Quantity surveyor does not know what he is talking about or it is the contractor in the dark or the contractor simply does not intend to complete the job. There was the case of a layman who was supervising his own project. Any quote the contractor gave him, he would slash by 25%. Once the contractor deduced this he would quote a very high figure, the client would slash it by 25% but even at that the contractor was getting well over the normal charges for what he was doing! While the owner thought he was smart, because he did not have the right figures which a BOQ would have given him, he was just cheating himself. Working without a BOQ on your project because you want to save costs is definitely a false economy.  [/read]
post_title: Bill of quantities: Counting your construction costs

post_content: Published April, 2017   Sometimes the use of direct labour in conjunction with supervisory and quality control inputs from one or two professionals is seen as a more budget-friendly approach to the delivery of a project, especially small-scale projects. Other times, the project owner may choose to be engaged directly in purchasing and organizing the supply of construction materials to their site, also in a bid to save cost. Whatever the case may be, whether it’s your personal project or as a group, it is important to know what and what you should expect at completion. You don’t plant grapes and expect to reap blueberries. A project for example, a building development is essentially a product of the use of materials and workmanship. You don’t order for tiles and expect to see epoxy flooring; neither would you see a classic brick wall when you actually paid for blocks. The usefulness of a material schedule is undoubted. You may never know it until you lose money buying the wrong or a substandard material at the same price as the original or even more. It is that piece of document that shows you the types, sizes, quantities, quality specifications and sometimes current price of all the materials you would need for a project from start to finish. It is not the same as a Bill of Quantities (B.O.Q) or Priced Bill of Quantities which gives brief details of all the items of work in a construction project and cost included respectively, it doesn’t give you the work item or work processes, it only deals with the materials aspect. The Material Schedule is presented in such a way that the user can easily identify with what materials will be used in the construction of his/her project and it often reveals approximate quantity estimates of all the materials needed with minimal allowance for wastage. Usually the material schedule is a construction document prepared after all the relevant designs/drawings has been completed so that at no point is any material is omitted due to incomplete architectural and engineering details and a thorough market survey has been done to check availability and current prices of the required materials. It is often done in conjunction with the owner’s specifications. When engaging a contractor, it is important to ask for a material schedule so that you can follow up on the quality of materials used for your work. If the materials used are not those you have agreed on as duly reflected on the material schedule in the absence of a pro-work variation, you can call for a replacement. But if there are no documents to show material specifications, then you can expect anything. Sometimes regret may follow; this is particularly the case when a supplier is engaged without a material schedule to back up your claims on the specs of the materials ordered for. Take for instance, you need a simple timber (wood) to construct your roof carcass, if you don’t specify the product type, size and condition (e.g. Mahogany Hardwood, 50 x 75mm full lengths, new and smooth) but just say supply me ‘wood for roofing’ who is to blame when a truckload of used fragile softwood is brought to your site and workers begin installing them? Although the material schedule comes at a cost, it is worth it. Engr. post_content: Published May 2017   For most people what they consider as building plan is actually not. The most important part of a home is the interior because the ease and comfort you enjoy depends on adequate planning. For a simple bungalow, you represent a plan on paper when you place yourself, looking at a floor plan as if you’re directly up looking down the edges of walls of the building you tends to create. After deciding on the type of building you want, the first thing to come to mind is the adequate land space you need to accommodate the plan in reality. You have to consider the setbacks from fence, going by town planning regulations is mostly 6m or 20ft from the property line in front to the start of building and 3m or 10ft each by both sides. Also 3m or 10ft is required at the rear as setback before the building line behind. Knowing the minimum setbacks you can now check the area and compare with you really need and if you still find more space that will be left unfilled, then is good for you to have a nice landscaping plan to complement the building this will make your building actually look nicer. How to determine room sizes Room sizes actually depends on people that will occupy the rooms and the nature of traffic expected, the furniture is very important and knowing the nature of man and how he behaves will help in giving him the space adequate for him. The average sizes of man contributes to the sizes of furniture and in turn the room spaces. 600mm or 0.6m or 2 feet width is usually seen as a space an average man can fit in that’s why most modules in building are in 600mm or 2 feet, check the sizes of ceiling modules and the division of 600mm is of course 300mm which also serve as minimum circulation allowance after the normal 600mm. Therefore the standard door is put at 900mm to accommodate man and his furniture width. So for a common bedroom what you consider first are the furniture you planned to have inside based on the number of people to use them, then the doors and windows. Consider the bed, the size of wardrobe and other shelves this will help in determining sizes of the room. You must have heard 6feet bed as very common statement, the wardrobe width space is around 600mm or 2 feet to 900mm as it may applies. For a minimum size of a room add door space 900mm or 3ft plus bed space 1.8m or 6ft plus circulation space 300mm or 1ft which equals 10ft or 3m now to add the human space of 600mm or 2ft which makes it 3.6m or 12 ft which is the standard/acceptable minimum room size. Living room will require more furniture and expect convergence of more people compare to bedroom so function it should be the biggest space in the house (television, settees e.t.c) There is no set minimum but from experience I will say minimum should be from 4.2m or 14ft by 3.9m or 13ft. Dining requires less space because it requires less furniture and traffic , for this I will put the minimum as 2.4m derived from two seats in opposites of 0.6m each which adds up to 1.2m and table width of 0.9m plus 0.3m as circulation which makes 2.4m . For the longer side of the dining with five seats arrangements which is 5 by 0.6=3m. Staircase width minimum acceptable is 0.9m or 3ft which is the size of a door, and kitchen designs has changed a lot lately , modern designs now require bigger space with breakfast table, worktops etc Considering the arrangements in building plan you are expected to step into the waiting room from entrance porch which can sit two people before moving to the living room or for some cases a corridor that leads to other parts of the house, this type is good if you expect exceptional visitors in your living room any other persons familiar with the house can simply take the corridor and walls straight to the other rooms as shown in pictures below. From the living room you can connect the dining directly, and from the dining next should be kitchen that has a door leading to the dining and one door leading outside of the building, this door will serve as an inlet for foodstuffs that are to be brought inside and going side by side the store and the laundry. These facilities should have access through the kitchen door to a bay outside where foodstuffs etc can be brought in without passing through the living room. For a residential project, is important you have three compartments called Public, Semi Private and Private areas. Someone should be able to move from the private areas which consist mainly of bedrooms to the kitchen without you first showing up at the dining or living room to the full glare of your guests at the living room so the coordination should be this way: LIVING ROOM,WAITING ROOM-Public GUEST ROOM,DINING-Semi Private BEDROOMS,STUDY-Private KITCHEN-(In between private and semi-private) Windows also follows various sizes from 600mm for windows to 900mm,1200mm,1800mm windows as the case may apply for a tropical region like ours with erratic power supply is advisable to have two windows at different walls in a room to aid proper aeration, this will also affects arrangement of furniture and size of your rooms.

post_content: Published May, 2017   Zoning is generally defined as a separation of areas with respect to particular functions. In the context of designing your home or other buildings, it is carried out for better function and more convenient utility of a building. The concept of zoning can be subjected to use in a number of different contexts. A design can be zoned according to the degree of access different individuals may be allowed to have to particular areas of a building. Thus one could demarcate a “public zone” in the house from the “private” or “restricted zone”. Your typical “public zone” would probably consist of the front porch, entry lobby, patio, guest toilet, living room, dining area (optionally), courtyard, verandah, den, etc; while in the same light, your typical “private zone” would probably consist of bedrooms, kitchen, family room, back entrance, bathrooms, closets, etc. “semi private” or “semi public” spaces could also be grafted out of a number of above-named spaces. Another kind of zoning is one that is carried out according to the degree of noise permissible in a particular part of the building at any given time. Thus your home could be demarcated into a “quiet zone” and a “noisy zone” in relative terms. Bedrooms and studies obviously would fall into the former category while the living room and kitchen could relatively be associated with the latter. As above though the terms “semi-noisy” and (or) “semi-quiet” can be applied to a number of spaces (and thus designed accordingly). A site located near a busy road for example, would necessitate “quiet” areas to be located as far as possible from the road. Yet another form of zoning could be carried out in terms of “wet” and “dry zones”. Thus your bathrooms, toilets, kitchen, laundry,and other spaces which make use of water would be termed “wet” while bedrooms, living, etc. would be termed “dry”. “Semi-wet” and (or) “semi-dry” would also apply as required. This sort of zoning could also present a number of cost advantages. Grouping wet areas together could reduce costs of drainage, and water supply, as well as reduce the number of inspection chambers and septic tanks required for proper waste disposal. In tiling as well, such zoning could save time and money as “wet” areas which would probably require “non-slip, vitrified” ceramic floor tiles could be laid simultaneously with similar tiles thus reducing wastage, while likewise a similar floor finish could apply for “dry” areas. Creative positioning of windows could preclude the undesirable consequences of grouping “incompatible” spaces, such as the kitchen and, say, a toilet. Still other types of zoning could exist in a building. Thus “fire-risk” zones such as the kitchen, electrical panel room, etc (are zoned away from bedrooms and escape points); “toddler zones” (with “child-proof” electric points, physical barriers to staircases and swimming pools, etc); “security zones” (relatively impenetrable during a robbery siege); and several others can be conveniently identified as requirements incorporated into the design

PREAMBLE/INTRODUCTION Over the years, design and construction methods of buildings have evolved. These evolu­tion has led to many options of design and construction methods of various structural components or elements of a building; such as floors, wall, and so on. The desire to construct a cost effective and safe building has also created many options for building components. For instant, there are different types of slabs like: solid slabs, hollow/ribbed slab, waffle slab, and flat slab. So how does one choose the best type of slab for a building? what are the criteria one should look out for? Here, we will discuss the two most common floor types in Nigeria : Solid floor slab and Hollow pot slab. We will compare and contrast both slabs and attempt to advice the best to be used out of the two. WHAT IS A SLAB A slab is the part of a building  known as floor which divides the building into stories, usually horizontal, in building floors, roofs, bridges, and other types of structures. The slab may be supported by walls or by reinforced concrete beams. A slab can be placed on the ground can be supported by beam and soil strength capacity while a suspended slab is supported by beam, wall and column. SOLID SLAB Solid slab is constructed with mainly reinforcement and concrete. It can be constructed as precast or cast-insitu (monolithic solid slab construction). The solid slab construction method involves the following: Formwork construction: Platform to support the slab and other activities during construction. It can be removed only when the concrete slab attain its maximium strength after 28days according to British standard. Placement of reinforcement: This is done according to the structural drawing provided Pouring of  concrete: Pouring of workable Concrete and compaction by the use of vibrator. Curing: Curing of the slab for 28days to attain its design strength. Advantages of Solid Slab
  • It is economical for small span
  • It is suitable for heavy loads or dynamic load
  • It is easy to repair or strengthen
  • It is good to hide services such electrical and mechanical pipes.
Disadvantages of Solid Slab
  • It can be very heavy.
  • It is not economical for long span.
  • Its construction involves much time
  • It involves large number of labour work
HOLLOW SLAB This is a type of slab that is constructed  with  hollow clay pots or blocks. Hollow clay pot slabs are usually constructed with fewer concrete and reinforcement  compare with solid slab. Hollow blocks are used to fill portions of the slab thickness; this results in deeper the amount of concrete and hence the weight of the slab. Hollow floors, which floor system in Office buildings, auditori­ums, hotels, commercial buildings, residential dwellings, houses of wor­ship, nursing homes and educational facilities, are all ideal applications. This is because of the advantage it gives in large span and of course its aesthetics cannot be compared to that of the solid slabs. In either way, floor slabs could be fabricated off- site (as pre-fabricated or pre-cast) The eventual on-site assemblage of these slabs will require newer technology and methods The Hollow slab construction method involves the following: Formwork construction: This is done either by laying the formwork to cover the floor area and then lay the pots on them, or laying the formwork just directly under the ribs of the pot Laying and arrangement of hollow blocks: This is done according to the structural drawing Placing of reinforcement: for ribs and concrete topping Pouring of concrete: workable Concrete and compaction by the use of vibrator. Curing: Curing of the slab for 28days to attain its design strength. Removal of formwork: This is done after 28days of curing Advantages of Hollow Slab
  • Reduced slab weight due to reduced amount of concrete below neutral axis.
  • Ease of construction, especially when all beams are hidden beams.
  • Economic for spans > 5m with moderate liveload: hospitals, office and residential buildings.
  • Attractive soffit appearance if exposed
  • Improved insulation for sound and heat
Disadvantages of Hollow Slab
  • Not economic for small spans
  • Not suitable for heavy loads or dynamic loads.
  • Difficult to repair or strengthen
  • Requires special or proprietary formwork
Why Should I use hollow pot slab or solid slabs From the information stated above, hollow slab give a significant advantage over the conventional solid slabs in terms of reduced material usage (reinforce­ment and concrete), reduced cost, enhance structural efficiency, decrease construction time and it is a new tech­nology in the construction industry.
  • Reduced material usage (reinforce­ment and concrete)
The quantities materials require such cement, gravel, sand and reinforcement are minimal. Also, the formwork area is reduced. As a result of this, workmanship force and cost is minimal.
  • Reduced cost of materials
With the reduced quantity of materials required, the cost of materials and workmanship will be less when compared with solid floor slab system.
  • Decrease in construction time
As a result of the simplicity of its construction and reduced quantity of materials and labour  required, the time require for its construction is less but requires technicality
  • Enhance structural efficiency
Due to its less weight property, total load of the building on the foundation is reduced thereby reducing the complexity of the foundation  at design stage. it also good as fire resistance and sound insulator.   Oyeleye Apampa (mnse) Managing Partner, Qota Consulting Ltd, 7, Modupe Johnson Crescent, Surulere, Lagos. 08034355663

Published June, 2017   If you have decided to go the self-build way and have engaged the services of a contractor, it is possible for you to get to site and not quite understand the goings on. At times the site may be very quiet and the next day, for instance when there is casting of concrete, a large number of workers turn up and there is a lot activity and the day after, total silence with only the site guard on duty. And if you have no experience in construction, you may not know if the works are on time behind or ahead of schedule. To keep on top of your project, you should ask the main contractor to give you a construction schedule and to make you understand it, request that it is given in bar chart format as in the diagram. As the owner, you do not need details of every aspect of the construction but this bar chart will help you see the bigger picture in an instant. On the left side of the chart is a list of the major construction activities and on top is the time frame (divided in weeks) for carrying out those activities. The chart not only shows when an activity is to be started and completed but also how the activities are inter-related . For instance, the plumber has to put in the drains and some pipes before the german floor of the foundation is cast and if this is not done, the casting date would be affected. In our bar chart, you can see that the plumber visits the site in Week 4 in between Weeks 3 and 5 which is the scheduled period for the foundation and this is for the express purpose of inserting the drains and relevant pipes. If he does not visit, the foundation time frame will be affected. The bar chart also helps you confirm that the necessary off site work, like purchase of materials has been done so that work can go ahead as scheduled. Again from our chart, we can see that electrical works are carried out in weeks 12 and 13 and this is for laying of the conduit pipes and wiring, while the electrician is back again in week 23, this time it will be for fixing lights, light switches etc. if you are not to delay him, you must have made your selection of lights and switches before week 23 and made sure they are on site by that date. For materials that have leadtimes to be delivered, the schedule should alert you to ensure that they have been ordered within a period that will allow for possible delays. So do not go to site as a complete novice. Have your Construction Schedule bar chart as a guide. Gantt chart showing activities for a detached house [caption id="attachment_6248" align="alignnone" width="796"] Gantt chart showing activities for a detached house[/caption]   WHAT DOES IT COST TO BUILD THAT? WHAT DOES IT COST TO BUILD AN AVERAGE 4 BEDROOM DETACHED HOUSE?

Unfortunately, to answer this question, one must be like a Nigerian by answering the question with a question. Well, ten questions in fact. This is because several factors, some significant, others less so come into play in determining the construction costs of a building. Costs do add up and so you will have to put in mind the following ten factors

  1. What type of soil is it?

The soil type is important because this determines the physical properties like bearing capacity different soil types have different load they can carry  i.e.  Sandy, swampy, clay or solid ground. This affects the cost because each soil type a specific kind of foundation that can be built on it and the foundation types all have different cost implications

  1. Where is the site?

This is also important because of accessibility, the easier you can get to the site the cheaper when it comes to logistics i.e. getting there and transporting materials to the site

  1. What type of house is it?

Is it a bungalow or a storey building or a two storey building?

  1. What is the size ?

The larger the foot print the more it would cost , the higher the head ,the more the cost goes up

  1. The design

The design of the house affects the cost, because the more complicated the design is, the more you will need to build it,  an average 4bedroom has 12 to 14 doors but the less doors you have the cheaper .

  1. Type of contractor affects the cost also; you can get the a top construction company like Julius Berger or Cappa & D’Alberto and other sub-contractors ,or a @Sule and Sons’  or you do self build by calling any bricklayer and other workers .
  2. Quality of materials also affects the cost
  3. Where are you getting your materials from?

The further away your materials are from your site the more you pay for transportation

  1. What type of finishes and the quality of the finishes?
  2. Do you have your financing in place? Mobilizing and demobilizing from site is an expensive business. Are you prone to making changes as you go along? Changes from the plan costs time and money.

Published June, 2017   Wastages broadly caused by inefficient planning can cause you to spend double the amount of money you ought to spend on a project if not more ,yet the building may not still be in perfect shape in comparison to the ones that was properly handled. These are causes with the remedies. (1) Improper planning-Before you open up a site it is important you decide on what to do and at what stages tasks will be done so that you don’t end up prolonging some tasks and not doing some until when it will affect other tasks on site. This will cause wastages to arise on a site for example you decide to paint the building before you realise there are some spots that needs to be patched , obviously wherever the repair is done you will still need to paint again which is a loss/wastage to the project. (2) Unskilled labour- one of the fastest ways to lose money on site is using quacks or unskilled labour to do some important tasks, you may have been charged less but at the end you’ll spend more money repairing the work the unskilled labourers did. (3) Delayed payments-Delay in payments affects planning and will also affect the cost of labour because more days will be spent completing a project that could have been done in a specified time frame. (4) Unscheduled disbursement of funds-Despite that there shouldn’t be delay in payments, releasing money carelessly or without proper account can give your builder/contractor a false impression there is plenty of money to be made which may cause excesses on his part. (5) No schedule of work-There must be a document containing how a project will be carried out, the time allocated to each task and showing how the task will overlap each other and help to achieve a wholesome project. (6) Untested Artisans-There is no harm in using different artisans for your projects but tested and trusted hands help in no small measure to reduce waste and saves time since they are already used to the contractor/builder. (7) Inexperienced workforce-This will affect the general outlook of your building yet you’ll spend more repairing badly done jobs. (8) Not buying materials in bulk-Buying materials only as at when needed from retailers around will cause you to spend double the amount you ought to use for a project, avoid it if necessary. (9) Improper storage-Store should be provided either onsite or buildings nearby, and the store must be secured with locks and keys and if possible a security man to monitor activities. Materials should also be protected from rain and other negative environmental conditions. (10) Theft-When there is no adequate monitoring/security theft is bound to occur. (11) No or improper account-How money is spent, materials coming to site, how is being used and for what purposes need to be put into considerations if not, when is difficult to trace materials abuse by workers is inevitable. (12) Overzealousness or ‘too know’ on your part- Your builder will not educate you on what you don’t know since you now claim to know so much. (13) Ignorance of basic steps/stages in construction-Not knowing anything at all even if it has to be through reading from the internet may put you at a greater risk from a contractor that wants to outsmart you, if left alone taking over the site may be difficult and chaos in management of materials is inevitable. (14) Check and balances every week is important from material bought, materials supplied, to work done. (15) Using substandard materials-Substandard materials will make you loose money rather than gain through repairs that will be caused from those materials. (16) Buying materials without specifications or your workers help accompanying you to the market may not be too good, you may end up buying materials not suitable for your project which will invariably leads to waste. (17) Site must be fenced to avoid encroachment, things falling out of site to gutters infront and unwelcomed intruders to site. (18) Improper siting during Design and construction-You must decide where the gatehouse, septic/soakaway tank, gen house and other ancillary buildings must be before construction , if not this will lead to major redesign/reconstruction which will eventually end up in wastages. For instance it is better to locate your septic/soakaway tank to fall in line with slope of site and placed at the lowest part of site this makes placements of pipes less strenuous to achieve because your plumber won’t be digging much soil. (19) Lack of foresight during demolition-There are sites you have to do some demolitions of old buildings onsite before new construction. For a well-planned site, the rubbles from the demolitions will still be useful. (20) Contractual matters should be clear and stated in black and white between the client and contractor to avoid arguments at the tail ends of the project. (21) Delay due to human factors like deliberate absence by workers or strike action can cause loss of time and money, which will eventually adds up when prolonged. (22) Delay due to environmental factors like rainstorm can affect a construction site which can lead to waste. Imagine if you had mixed cement down for some work only for the rain to affect you during execution of task.(23) Employ security guards if necessary to avoid thefts. (24) When no room for overlapping of task . Artisans should be encouraged to work side by side except for some cases to avoid material and time wastages. (25) Weak or bad designs in buildings-Using quacks to design a building for you will definitely make you to pay more and may even lead to total collapse of building. (26) No site investigation of site before moving to site-This is one of the major and most important steps to take before embarking on any project. If the place is waterlogged or you question the soil integrity, do a soil test, check how safe the place is for your materials to be brought to site? where will your workers stay? where will they sleep? where is food coming from? and how about toilet? If all these are not planned for, you’ll be surprised at man hours to be wasted by your workers because of these. Arc. Omion Emmanuel Tel: 08026228682 Email: omionick@gmail.com

post_content: Installing Solar Roofing sheets/ Roof tiles on your building: What you should know Smart homes just got smarter with the invention and general acceptance of solar electric roof coverings. Prior to this innovation, buildings used to have solar panel systems mounted on their roofs or elsewhere and these came with a lot of inconsistencies; including several cases of theft and vandalism but now the solar panels have being built into the roof tiles and sheets so that you simply install over the whole area at once or just a portion depending on your power need (i.e. the power requirements of the building). This way solar energy sufficient enough to power all appliances in a regular home can be harvested on a much larger area overhead.   Solar roofing tiles is designed and installed to compliment the home’s architecture while converting energy from sunlight into electricity. But the roofing sheets/tiles do not come alone; they normally come with powerwall batteries. These batteries enable excess energy generated during peak periods to be stored during off-peak periods and can be used in conjunction with public power source.   There are various types of solar roofs available in the market however the solar shingles roof is more commonly used here; most of which still retain their parent material and are typically glass-coated. The solar shingles also referred to as photovoltaic shingles have the solar panels integrated into the naturally asphaltic parent material giving it a glass surface finish which actually bears the solar cells. It is believed that this combination of asphalt base and glass surface material is good enough to make the solar shingle roof last as long as the life span of the building which is traditionally put at 70 years. Although much is not known about the aesthetic functionality of this type of roof after a long period, it is believed that the primary functions of roofs which is to protect the interior of a building or structure from rain, excess sunlight and other external (overhead) weather conditions will not be jeopardized by this relatively new innovation.   In Nigeria, particularly faced with erratic power supply in many towns, villages and cities after many years of intervention in various capacities, the adoption and usage of solar roofs is beginning to take center stage in new building and housing estate developments where green (noiseless, neat and eco-friendly) energy is cherished and preferred over the popular substitute. It may not be wrong to say that most people would prefer this system if it comes affordable.   There are lots of good stuffs that don’t come cheap and this roof type, from the poor and middle class perspective at present, is one of them. A square metre of solar roof will cost about twice higher to purchase and install than the regular one of its kind and can generate an average of 0.2kWh. Installing solar roofs on your existing building will require that you remove the old roof to allow for the installation of the new one and that comes at an additional cost but for new constructions, this extra cost does not arise. Considering the abundance of sunlight in the country especially during the typical dry seasons, it has been observed that the amount of solar power needed to completely power a typical average nuclear family living unit can be harvested by the solar roof over the house without the need for additional support until terrible down times. The power generated reaches optimal values depending largely on the roof space, the power rating on each unit of roofing sheet or tile and the angle of inclination. This is a huge plus for users of the technology. The cost effectiveness of the system over a period of time therefore is good.   Solar roofs are installed in the same way as the regular roof types except that due to the electrical configurations, the service of an electrical engineer or solar expert is advised. There are some buildings in Nigeria with solar roofs already installed over them and its turning into the next big thing for luxury living. Before buying a solar roof it is important to check for its power rating so that you get value for your money. Engr. Published July, 2017   There are old roofs everywhere. They litter the skyline. They have become so notable and symbolic in some areas that those places are jokingly referred to as ‘Brown Roof Republic’. Everything and Everybody ages, we only manage to keep them evergreen; that’s where the beauty really lies. Roofs are designed to last at least half the life span of a building but they don’t always maintain the same aesthetic value and relative strength throughout this period as it was when they were first installed coupled with the number of inferior roofing products flooding our markets that don’t even stay up to 10 years before failing. There is nothing abnormal with the natural aging process though. The metal roofs rust, stone-coated roofs fade off, asbestos roofs crack, plastic roofs rupture and glass roofs become stricken. They all grow weaker each passing year from external weather conditions and bow to wind pressures at some point. But when there is a will to restore them, there is always a way! [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Roofs installed on top of a building are normally put in place to protect the interior and some part of the exterior of the building from the direct effect of sunlight, rainfall and other external weather conditions. This no doubt makes the roof a very vital component of the building. Remove the roof from your house; then you no longer have a house but an ‘open arcade’ where the kids can have fun when the weather is just cool. Generally in building construction, roofs, except concrete roof and similar types consist not only of the roof covering but also the carcass. In Nigeria and elsewhere, the carcass and roof covering material usually constitute more than 10% of the entire construction cost for bungalows but lesser as the building rises and this is evident in the fact they often spread beyond the perimeter of the building with clearance of 600mm or more away from the face of the building on nearly all sides, depending on the design. The roof carcass are made of tie beams, trusses, struts, purlins, king post, queen post and so on connected together to form a rigid frame to support the roof covering (roofing sheets or tiles or other materials) usually installed directly over them; although this is not often the case for concrete roofs which are normally reinforced internally with metal rebars, bamboo strands, etc or externally with thick anti-rust metal plates. Beyond this description, roofs have become key aesthetic components of buildings for which architects can play in designs. By manipulating the design of a roof you can actually give a unique perspective to a building. A lot of people are familiar with various roofing styles but not much is known about what to do when the roof loses its value. ‘Replacement’ readily comes to mind. However, you can actually strengthen and restore your roof completely without necessarily removing any piece. For concrete roofs you simply strengthen the concrete and damp-proof membrane. For roofing sheets and tiles, you clean up dust and dirt from the surface using anti-grease or sugar soap and a wire brush or large sand-paper brush for metal roof and a soft brush or sander for stone-coated tiles. After cleaning the entire surfaces of grime, loose paints and dirt, steam-spray the roof or simply flush with warm water over it to rinse off. Give it some time to dry. Then spray a recommended strengthening mix over the surface to improve its strength. The strengthening mix defer with various roof types. Find out the one that is suitable for your roof. Some re-coating paints naturally come with such mix. Leave it for a while to set too. Thereafter you spray the surface with rust-inhibiting primer and then followed immediately after by acrylic latex paint or other suitable equivalents of your new choice of colour in two coats. Use brushes to apply to edges or smaller areas. Roof restoration can keep your roof in good shape for additional 30 years. This is how to make your old roof new at reduced cost (some 62% lower than the cost of replacement) in few hours and you leave everyone thinking their eyes must have been deceiving them! Engr. post_content: Published August, 2017 What is Stamped Concrete? Stamped Concrete floor is concrete that is Patterned or Textured by imprinting-process to resemble Stone, Tiles, Wood, Slate or Bricks using added colours and sealed with acrylic resins to give it a coated finish that prevent the penetration of external elements. A textured finish may also be used to decorate the concrete.   How is it properly done? [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  The installation requires the right tools, materials (in the recommended ratios), expertise and favourable jobsite conditions to ensure a successful outcome. Specialized equipment is needed to stamp the desired pattern onto the concrete before it dries out. The technicalities of pouring out the concrete onto the installation areas are also a challenge. Overall It is a laborious and time-sensitive process although the finished look is well worth the effort. Good planning and fore-preparation are necessary to make sure everything comes out as designed. A well-compacted sub-grade is critical to the structural integrity of the concrete slab as it helps drainage and can prevent soil erosion under the concrete. Installation of proper Control Joints which must be cut to a depth of at least one quarter of the slab thickness are required to prevent and control cracking. It is critical to use a Mixer for smooth and consistent "bubbles-free" concrete mix that can stand up to the anticipated exposure conditions such as wear and tear from foot or vehicle traffic. Special attention must also be paid to the water-cement ratio, to get the right cement paste for durability. Cement grade of 42.5 is recommended for external floors. .For many slabs, reinforcement in the form of steel bars, welded wire mesh or fibre is necessary to augment strength and control cracking. This is especially critical for drive-ways and other surfaces that will support vehicle or heavy traffic.   Common Pitfalls Below are some of the pitfalls to avoid; Wrong Concrete Paste and Hand-Mixing Not any proportion of concrete mixtures can be used. As ready mix is not readily available to small and medium sized constructions in Nigeria, its best to go with the mixer, because hand mixing will always have defects especially when the Labour crewmembers begin to tire out. Concrete must be allowed to cure (i.e. dry) properly (needs 3 clear days without rain) before washing and sealing it. Unrealistic Colours and Poor Finish An illusion of natural Colour can only seem realistic if the Colours are realistic and in harmony with the environment and creates the desired effect. It is best to consult the experts when choosing colours. The quality of Finish is highly dependent on the quality of Colour Hardners and Antiquing Release Powders. These are mainly imported and there are very few suppliers in the market. It is critical to ensure these materials are not diluted with locally mixed pigments and white cement (a common practice amongst installers) as it will ultimately impact on the quality of the finish and the longevity of the installation. For this purpose it’s best to buyer materials directly from the Suppliers as the least Quality control Effort by project owner towards the Output. Non-Sealing and Lack of Maintenance Stamped concrete has to be sealed properly for it to preserve the colours as well as the texture. This also prevents the concrete from getting discolored by molds, stains, algae and other contaminants. Inadequate Tools and Poor Supervision: Like any service and technical work, the quality of the final output is highly dependent on the tools, experience, dedication and quality of supervision, more so in construction work. Paying attention to the finer details is highly necessary to produce quality work. Very few Installers use the correct and recommended tools and understandably this impacts on the quality of work output. Mixing Products of Different Brands: Another common practice of Installers is to combine stamped concrete materials of different brands forgetting that the Chemical components of these products are designed as an integrated system to achieve a desired result. For example some buy Colour Hardners of particular brand and use Antiquing Release Powder of another brand. It is critical to ensure materials of the same brands are combined at all times.   [/read]
