post_content: Published 01-08-2018   Chief had arrived at the tough decision many years ago but it took his wife (known to all as ‘Madam’) a few more years to agree with her husband. Their seven-bedroom mansion with 3 bedroom guest chalet and 4 bedroom service quarters in an estate in Ikoyi, was “unfit for purpose”. Their last child had left for school in England seven years ago and one after the other, his three older siblings had indicated that they intended to continue their studies or work abroad. When she had to relocate abroad temporarily for ‘Grandma duties’on the birth of their first grandchild and her husband was outnumbered by five to one by their domestic servants, Madam finally conceded that the house was too large for two people. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Two questions they had to deal with: what to do with their palatial mansion and where should they move to? The second issue was resolved quickly: a three bedroom flat in a serviced apartment block. The first, what to do with their mansion, was more difficult and time consuming. The massive property was impossible to let as there was virtually no demand for such a large property. Selling the property was not a consideration. Culturally, the house is considered as a family asset to be passed on to the next generation. Besides, the couple was put off by sale offers received that valued only the land and put a nil figure on the buildings. According to their agent, buyers do not look favorably on a fifteen year old mansion, even one which was considered as ‘cutting edge’when it was built. The challenge faced by Chief and his wife is getting increasingly common these days. Estate Agents are reporting a new trend of ‘empty nesters’ and ‘downsizing’ in the real estate sector. These are terms that have become commonplace in the West but will become regular in Nigeria, particularly in the luxury locations of the country. Owners are getting to the realization forced on them by maintenance and other costs, that large buildings are expensive to hold on to. Changing cultural norms, like a couple living alone unlike the past when they were likely to house several members of their extended families, is also having an impact. It is more pronounced in the luxury end of the market as owners are faced with children ‘leaving the nest’ to study abroad. What is to be done with the large houses built to accommodate a lifestyle that is changing? This challenge has opportunities for forward-looking owners and investors. How did the big houses come about? Castles Lifestyle wrote about this in 2016.“You have ‘arrived’. Congratulations. Now it is time to put up that mansion that you have always envisaged. A bedroom for every family member and the family dog is in order. What about a room for the grandchildren that will come in future? Now that the bedrooms(all en-suite of course) have been sorted out, what about the living areas? There are the formal parlours downstairs, the family living room up-stairs and surely there must be an anteroom to receive such callers like the mechanics etc. who cannot be invited into the main sitting room. There’s also the small matter of political ambitions so there must be another parlour where top-level consultations with ‘my people’ can be held in secrecy. Apart from the living areas, there is also the prayer room, the study and the gym where Oga can go a few rounds on the treadmill. In the meeting with his architect, the owner of this castle can probably justify why he has to have a mansion with so many rooms. Many years down the road when the cost of maintaining it is over bearing or the owner has passed on and the children are saddled with the property, the sagacity of putting up the humongous structure is in doubt. Now it is difficult to sell or rent it and none of the children want to live there. Speaking with several agents who advertised such grand family homes, we find that such properties can be on the market for upwards of two years or more but still cannot find buyers. With this hindsight, one would have thought that such overbuilding would have died out but while most modern Nigerians would claim that they do not believe in big houses, let a few millions of Naira hit their bank balances and voila a 13-room castle is built. If you really must have that grand house, do go ahead but instruct your architect to design it in such a way that it can be divided into various apartments with few modifications and no structural work required. That way, the ten bedroom house can be converted into an apartment block of four flats or two semi-detached houses. These could be more easily let as separate apartments, sold as investment properties or divided among the children who will find them easier to live in than the decaying monument to ego their progenitor built! The advice of 2016 is still relevant today. Even if there is a predilection for a large house, the owner should consider how the house can be divided up into smaller units for letting or resale. This has implications for owners in estates like NICON Town, Northern Foreshore and Charlton Gate Estates in Lekki where the building approval rules mandate a house on a plot. Owners of the large houses will have their options severely limited in this regard. On the development side, Developers can also consider developing properties suitable for this demographic of geriatric buyers! The Osborne Towers complex might have achieved notoriety for the stash of foreign currency unveiled by a whistle blower but the news inadvertently revealed the profile of the owner/occupiers. Not expatriates as might be expected but well heeled Nigerians who by their pedigree should be in mansions in high-end locations but preferred flats in the serviced apartment block . Retirement housing may not have a market in Nigeria at the moment, but as our habits continue to reflect those of the western world the more, Highbrow Living may be penning an article on the topic in a few short years.   [/read]

Published 01-08-2018 If the answer to the above question is Yes, your property was probably bought with a Leasehold title as most flats are. Leasehold properties unlike Freehold properties have a lease term usually of up to 999 Years (virtual freehold). When buying a property the lease term is important before committing funds as you might only know the true position when the solicitors get to work, so unlike damp or structural cracks, where the detrimental effects on value are easy to see and quantified, it nonetheless can be detrimental to the value of your property at its most extreme. Statistics indicate that there have been more first time homeowners in the last 15-20 Years than ever before. Most of these new homeowners are often sadly unaware that there is a ticking bomb or value loss inherent in a low lease that can accompany their purchase. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Prior to the year 2000, most flats were purchased with an unexpired lease of between 90 and 99 Years, with the property boom and aggressive new build developments leases are now mostly drawn at 125 years. Most accidental landlords, Buy to Let owners and indeed homeowners that have owned their properties for over 10 Years have focused more on the capital appreciation and better rental returns to be gained due to low interest rates and higher rents, losing sight of the capital cost that might be required to extend their property lease. Why is it important? 1. Banks and mortgage lenders are uncomfortable with short leases and are particularly interested in the number of Years unexpired when a loan is granted i.e. a property with a 63 Year lease being mortgaged over 25 Years would have 43 Years left in Year 20 of the mortgage and might have adverse effect on the value of the property due to low unexpired lease. 2. The cost of extending a lease becomes higher the lower the lease becomes an example is a client we are presently negotiating on behalf of: The flat was bought in the Year 2001 at £140,000 with an unexpired lease of 54 Years, he negotiated with the freeholder to be granted an additional 90 Years at £10,000 which was agreed but not concluded due to disagreement on who would pay the legal cost, 14 Years later he initiated negotiations again with the freeholder, with the property now having 40 Years unexpired lease and now valued at £400,000. The cost of extending the lease was quoted at £78,000, as expected the leaseholder was astonished and opted to instruct his own valuation which pretty much confirmed the same figure. The value of the lease is usually tied to the area where the property is situated, which can again be loosely correlated to the value of the property. We've renewed a lease in central London for as much as £750,000, so you could very well see a case where properties with identical lease cost vary vastly, £750,000 in central London and as low as £10,000 elsewhere. The point at which you need to start looking seriously into negotiating a lease extension is in the 70 to 80 years left period. If you had bought a property in 2008 with one of the characteristic 99 year leases of the time for instance, you are getting into borderline low lease territory. You become free to negotiate the lease extension on your flat once you've owned it for north of 3 years and your freeholder is duty bound to deal with you, if your landlord or Freeholder refuses to do this or you can't seem to settle on an agreeable price, there is always recourse to the court of arbitration. Belying all this is the fact that leases are increasingly looked at as cash cows by developers and freeholders alike. Gone are the days where ground rent was at peppercorn value, with people paying between £1 and £10. Today we see rates of about £500 every half year with provisions embedded in contracts for increases periodically. RPI (retail property index) is now increasingly used as a parameter for ground rent charges. The way some leaseholds are structured in new builds have rendered them simply unattractive to secondary buyers, with the escalating ground rent being a major turn off. There have been growing reports of new home buyers complaining of deals falling through for this very reason. What next? Check the unexpired term of your lease. Approach your freeholder for a quote to extend. Appoint a good Solicitor or experience Property consultant to advice or act on your behalf. Good news is that your mortgage lender would consider equity release to fund the cost of extending the lease as it enhances the value of the asset. Remember that every passing day your lease decreases, the cost of extending probably increases, so start the process today.   [/read]

Area Spotlight: Kings Cross, London London is a unique city with multiple cultural centers and hubs, we’ll be taking an in-depth look into some of these hot spots one by one, to see where the best opportunities lay for you the investor. Today we begin with Kings Cross, located within Zone 1 and a deep history within the city of London. Kings Cross is named after a monument of King George IV that stood between 1830 and 1845 and marked the point where Euston Road, Grays inn road and Pentonville road met. Hence the name of the Kings Crossing. The area today is light years away from the aforementioned description and has experienced a Cinderella-like transformation from its designation in the 90’s as a red light district, to a formidable cultural and tech hub that boasts the most connected transport hub in Europe. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  In a world where travel time is the new conception of distance, six London Underground lines, two mainline stations and an international high-speed rail link all within a few hundred meters, make Kings Cross a commuters dream. One of the largest regeneration schemes in London's recent history has seen the addition of three million sq ft of workspace, 500,000 sq ft of retails, restaurants, bars, cafes and other facilities, as well as over two thousands of new homes. This renaissance has attracted companies such as BNP Paribas, Google, and Facebook, with the latter two sitting their European headquarters there. For the investor this spells out a compelling case, Kings Cross has become both a destination and a transit hub, with space to Live, work and play. This means a large supply of potential tenants that are willing and able to pay the rent expected of such an area. The price appreciation of an asset is as important as the yield obtainable and is a signal of the underlying strength in the area. We’ve attached a few examples of price movements in the area over time gotten from the Land Registry. Northcourt, a ‘real estate investment solutions company’ with offices in Lagos and Abuja recently released it H1 2018 Real Estate Market Review. In the following pages, we reproduce from the Report, the firm’s reading of the residential, office and retail markets. RESIDENTIAL Residential markets showed improved price stability and levels of activity in comparison to H1 2017, though fairly high but reducing vacancies exist in the high to mid income locations. As land prices and other construction costs soar, developers continue to stay competitive by intensifying land use, reducing plot sizes, car parks and built-up areas in a bid to supplement the decline in profitability caused by weakened prices since 2016/17. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  There is a general improvement in design and finishing features provided in recent developments, however, the quality of materials and workmanship can be improved on and remains a major differentiator. However, residential developments in close proximity to high streets and areas with high traffic continue to be gentrified i.e. converted to other use classes that attract higher rents such as retail and office use. To foster housing provision, the Central Bank selected 34 mortgage banks and 4 commercial banks to increase access to housing finance for low-income earners. The banks will benefit from a $15M Housing Micro-finance Fund and a $10M Technical Assistance Fund. Furthermore, the CBN engaged the Mortgage Bankers Association of Nigeria (MBAN), the Nigeria Mortgage Refinancing Company (NMRC), Federal Mortgage Bank of Nigeria and Nigeria Deposit Insurance Corporation (NDIC) to launch the Uniform Mortgage Underwriting Standards for the informal sector. In another public-private partnership effort, the Kaduna state government entered a partnership with Sterling Bank to launch a ₦5Bn fund aimed at providing mortgages at single-digit interest rates. Beneficiaries are required to make security deposits of between 15 to 30% of the value of the houses but would be expected to liquidate mortgages within 10 years. This is in addition to the foundation laying for 600 housing units, a five-star hotel and two shopping malls in the state. The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) also completed 608 housing units in Borno State as its contribution towards rebuilding areas destroyed by Boko-Haram. This is as a 72- unit housing project under the National Housing Programme in Jigawa state attained 80% completion. The MPW&H would also engage 20 local contractors in Sokoto to construct an 80-unit housing estate worth N1.3Bn. The Edo State Government started the construction of 1,800 housing units in partnership with MIXTA Africa - a property development company with projects spread across Africa. Completion is expected by Q4 2019. Property values remained linked to location, infrastructure availability, perceived levels of security and historical antecedents. This was evidently the case in the ‘Garden City’ of Port Harcourt. Still, Federal Government- owned Trans Amadi Gardens was in fair demand. High-end rents for 3-beds went between ₦4 – ₦6M per annum as sale prices averaged ₦45 – ₦60M. Peter Odili, NAF Harmony estate, Trans Amadi Garden, Old GRA, and GRA Phases 1 – 3 ranked highest on the most desired places to live. Vacancy rates in Lagos showed slight improvements with Mainland strongholds - Yaba (3%) Surulere (4%) and Magodo Phase II (5%) recording the lowest vacancies of the nodes considered. The more cosmopolitan areas of Victoria Island (35%), Oniru (37%), Lekki (39%) and Ikoyi (40%) had higher vacancies, as affordability remained a central consideration. Flexibility also featured in many residential areas with some Landlords willing to offer monthly or quarterly rents. Abuja’s city centre saw high demand for low cost 1 and 2-Bed apartments while that of 3 to 4-Bed houses saw a drop in demand due to the weakened purchasing power of the average resident. High tenement rates, waste management and water bills contributed to the reduced interest. To increase the housing supply in the FCT, the Federal Government would partner Zvecan Consulting and a Chinese firm, Wengfu Company Limited to build 5,000 housing units under the Federal Integrated Staff Housing (FISH), programme. Vacancy rates in Abuja ranged from 3% (Maitama) to 28% (Katampe) Put the retail with the diagrams on one page…   RETAIL Retail continued to struggle with the shrinking middle class and the dwindling purchasing power of the customer. However, with the exchange rate stabilization, planning around operational costs and profit projections is much more feasible for retailers. Local investors, emboldened to make further investments, softly opened the Next Mall in Port Harcourt and The Atlantic in Lagos. Vacancy rates largely reduced across the Grade-Amalls. The Palms and Ikeja-City Mall had the lowest vacancies at 0% and 2% respectively. Novare Mall came in at 28%, down from 47% at the end of 2017. Artee’s Port Harcourt Mall, Big Treat and Genesis Centre had 8%, 15% and 25% respectively. Ceddi Plaza and Gateway Mall in Abuja recorded 21% and 38% respectively. Abuja’s largest mall – Jabi Lake (20,000sqm) recorded the highest vacancy rate in city – 40% due to a number of stores that closed down in Q1 and high rentals. While some international investors find business conditions less favorable and are instead pursuing retail interests in Eastern Europe and Eastern Africa, local HNI’s (High Net- worth Individuals) who are not disturbed by currency risks amongst others, are moving into the retail space to make large-scale investments. Outside purpose-built and A-grade malls, high street retail within central locations continue to experience high demand. Larger malls, though more appealing to international retailers due to better infrastructure, are less attractive to local brands due to higher rents and service charge costs. Events, entertainment and leisure features continue to be a traffic pull for large malls with car park payments remaining a key income stream and a counterweight to the pain of declined rents in major malls. put the office with the diagram and contacts on one page OFFICE The office market in Lagos, Abuja and Port Harcourt continued to struggle in the review period. Rents either stayed or declined to remain competitive. The security risks and environmental hazards in Port Harcourt sent office rents to its lowest in over five years. Grade-A office vacancies in particular remained high and it appears the economy would need to strengthen much more to reverse this trend. The wait for the global brands looking to open up shop in Grade-A signature addresses worthy of their presence may be taking too long. Demand for grade B and smaller office spaces remained stable when compared with last year and co-working spaces continue to grow in popularity with a few service providers opening more locations. With increased flexibility in pricing and terms, a renewed focus on volume, partnerships and programs that drive profitability. The development pipeline remains rich and is much more active in comparison to H1 2017. With over 100,000sqm of office currently available for lease on the market, completions scheduled for 2018 already have significant competition for the few multinationals and big brands that can afford grade-A space, not accounting for the brands that are willing to settle for the more flexible and affordable co-work option. Contact  North-court .   [/read]

RE-CALIBRATING WEST AFRICA’S REAL ESTATE MARKET FOR SUSTAINABLE GROWTH

29 August 2018, Lagos, Nigeria. The annual West African Property Investment (WAPI) Summit, the region’s most prominent and largest investment and development conference will take place on 15 & 16 November 2018 at the Eko Hotel and Suites, Lagos. Organized by African Property Investment (API) Events, the summit marks the specialist real estate insights and networking platform provider’s ninth conference in 2018. As the company’s managing director, Kfir Rusin, says, “Nigeria is a bellwether economy in Africa and when it expands; it impacts regional and global sentiment across Africa, which is driving a major swing towards Africa’s premier emerging markets.” This year’s summit theme: RE-Calibrating Supply and Demand for Sustainable Growth is a natural evolution of the previous year’s theme, Changing the West African Narrative, which aided more than 400 delegates representing over 250 companies to reposition the sector in a region sparked to a growth footing by Nigeria’s resurgence. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  A re-calibrated market As Rusin says, “After years of challenging conditions, the question facing the local market - and what our regional and international investors and developers will explore is: How has the market re-calibrated and evolved to cater towards changing end-user demand and regional market realities in an economy flush with $70 oil? We believe the market has matured through these lean years, and we’re seeing a change in the market which includes more purpose built and tailored projects, which will be unpacked in detail by the developers, tenants, operators and new entrants.” This year’s key focus areas include: Funding; Non-traditional Asset Classes; Proptech, Innovation and Big Data; Affordable Housing, Retailer Occupier and End User Product Demand and Infrastructure, Planning and Permits – with such detailed discussion topics, the WAPI Summit is regarded as the year’s definitive annual real estate forum for the region. As Rusin says, “We’ve witnessed continued development across Africa and Nigeria is attracting a lot of attention from industry stakeholders from funders, developers, retailers, hospitality and operators. And by exploring these topics in-depth, we will provide the market with the platform for growth by sharing unique insights case studies and high-level networking opportunities.” Speakers in attendance Some of the first C-Suit level presenters and panel discussion thought leaders to confirm their participation include Olasupo Shasore (SAN), Partner at African Law Practice, Ali Djire, Fraym’s Country Manager, PwC Nigeria’s Chief Economist Andrew S Nevin, Fola Aiyesimoju, Founding Partner, Themis Capital Management, Kehinde Ogundimu, Managing Director, NMRC and Broll Property Group Nigeria’s CEO, Bolaji Edu. As the continent’s largest economy, Nigeria is a key focus point for the investors and developers and this year’s theme and agenda is reflective of the increased regional and global appetite for real estate assets in Nigeria and Ghana says Rusin. “Nigeria’s exit from recession at the end of 2017, changed perceptions and once again catapulted the region back onto the radar of investors, which is evident by the uptick in transactions this year, which we have noted across multiple sectors.” Having hosted multiple events across the continent, 2018 has provided ample opportunity for Rusin to gauge international and regional appetite and performance. “We’ve witnessed a recovery and maturing and improved appetite for diverse assets in the market – with new funds launched and a lot of deal making throughout 2018. However, we have also noted volatility in global markets, which have impacted Africa, but bullish developers continue to forge ahead across the continent’s most appealing markets.” With a large proportion of the 450 delegates representing more than 250 companies travelling from across the region, and further afield, the WAPI Summit provides unique networking and deal-making opportunities. “Over the years, we have seen numerous multi-million-dollar deals struck and introduced development finance institutions, sovereign wealth funds and private equity firms who are increasingly interested in the opportunities in West Africa.” Ends About API Events The West Africa Property Investment (WAPI) is the region’s largest and most premier real estate event. It connects the most influential local and international Africa property stakeholders, driving investment and development into a wide range of real estate and infrastructure projects and developments across the region. API Events delivers Africa’s most renowned events in real estate investment and development. Our events across the continent have become the ultimate meeting places for Africa’s property market to learn, network and most importantly to do deals. The company also hosts the API Awards – these prestigious awards provide a platform for distinguished developers, suppliers and owners in the African real estate industry, to showcase their best projects and services. IT’S THE TENANT MIX, STUPID

On a Saturday morning in the month of January, 2017, I took a stroll within the sprawling Lekki Phase 1 estate in Lagos until I found myself on Admiralty Way which has in recent years, turned into a commercial retail haven. A few of these retail facilities had full occupancy whilst majority of them were obviously struggling to let their spaces. Since then, I have made it a habit to study commercial retail developments whenever I find myself in different localities, cities and states away from Lagos. It is quite obvious that this trend of high vacancy in commercial retail facilities is not restricted to certain areas within the Lagos metropolis; Be it Maitama in Abuja, Kaduna central, Port Harcourt City, the story is the same. Sprawling all over the place are retail facilities which are struggling to achieve 70% occupancy rate. This is as a result of one key problem which most promoters of malls/shopping centers have repeatedly failed to accept as the prime factor in determining the success of such developments. IT’S THE TENANT MIX, STUPID! [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Pardon me on the choice of the phrase which I feel is most appropriate to capture my observation and comments to developers of shopping centers. The title of this piece was inspired by the phrase “The Economy, Stupid” which has turned out to be a popular cliché’ commonly used in American political discourse over the years. For political history buffs, it was coined as a campaign slogan by Mr. James Carville and used during the successful 1992 presidential campaign of a certain Mr. Bill Clinton. In my school days at the University of Lagos, our lecturers consistently told us that as far as real estate is concerned, it is all about the location- Location! Location! Location! In the numerous books written by Donald Trump - a real Estate mogul and now President of the United States in my crowded office library, he has repeatedly emphasized the importance of getting the best location when dealing in real estate. Well, I am of the view that when it comes to real estate especially as it regards commercial retail, It’s not all about the location. Most of the malls/shopping centers in the major cities in Nigeria are in fantastic locations but are struggling to achieve full occupancy. While some people attribute it to the bad economy and exorbitant rents being charged by the promoters of the retail facilities, I am of the strong belief that it all boils down to the tenant mix. Worldwide, it has been an accepted norm for those in the commercial retail space that for any retail facility to thrive, high footfall has to be generated. Once this is achieved, the tendency for all shops to be let out is very high as retailers would ensure that their businesses are situated in such facilities. With high occupancy comes higher income and thus a better investment performance of the property for the promoters of the facility who more often than not borrow money to develop such properties. For a decent footfall to be achieved in a mall/shopping centre, key human traffic generators have to be carefully selected to take up space in the facility even if it means giving these retail brands concessions in rent, fit out cost, and free trading periods. For the Nigerian market, the human traffic drivers can be segmented into 3 categories: Supermarket/Grocery/Departmental stores; Entertainment/Leisure- Cinemas, Game arcades, Bars/Lounges; Food & Beverages -QSR etc. Any retail facility in a good location that has a combination of these 3 drivers stands a chance of attaining a high level of occupancy. In centers that are on multiple floors, it is wise to situate these drivers on different floors. Without strategically placing these drivers all around the centre, there would be a tendency for the upper floors to still remain vacant as most retailers would focus more on the floors that are perceived to have more traffic. A good example where the tenant mix has worked in facilities that have multiple floors is the Maryland Mall on Ikorodu road in Lagos. The mall went against tradition by placing drivers on other floors apart from the ground floor, which is typical in most retail developments in the country. That is the main reason why the mall was able to attain 75% occupancy on the opening day which happened at the heat of economic recession in the month of June, 2016. With the traffic drivers being correctly identified and allocated shops, it usually becomes easier to attract other retailers to the facility. Quite a number of commercial retail facility promoters are ignorant of this fact and believe that once the properties are built, they would be easily leased. “Build and they will come” as the saying goes but people tend to forget that the only reason why the average retail brand intends to take a space at a facility instead of a stand-alone property is because there is an assumption that such facilities generate human traffic which would give them a better opportunity to find patronage for their goods and services. From my experience, there are instances, where irrespective of the traffic pullers, these centers have been fully leased. However, come a year after, most of these tenants vacate the centers as a result of low patronage; it becomes hard to justify the high rental. So isn’t it better to do it right from the onset? Over time, I have had cause to discuss with some of these promoters of such facilities and a few accept my argument. The biggest obstacle is usually the discounts required to entice the supposed traffic generators to their facility. The demand by these retailers are at times as good as giving them spaces of between 1,000 –1,200sqm in a facility of 3,000-5,000sqm GLA almost for free. In the Entertainment and Leisure segment, most of the retailers now request for the retail centre owners to bear part of their fit-out costs as a condition to taking up space at the centre. The ultimate solution to avoid these financial issues especially at a later stage when the centre is fully operational is to ascribe a certain percentage of GLA to anchor tenant and key tenants when preparing the financial model at the conception stage of the project. This would have taken into consideration the discounted rents prescribed and resources allocated to take care of these set of tenants. By so doing, financial pitfalls would have been avoided in future. It is my hope that my article has steered some taught in this area of practice. So next time you want to build a retail facility, don’t forget; It’s all about the Tenant mix.   Olurogba Orimalade FNIVS, FRICS Commercial Retail Specialist     [/read]

HOW A DERELICT BUNGALOW WAS TURNED INTO A WARM COSY HOME

Published 23rd September, 2018 An avid Castles Lifestyle reader has sent us photos of how he turned a derelict bungalow in Abraham Adesanya Estate in Lekki into a lovely home for him and his family. His story…. Many people had rejected the bungalow, which had been abandoned for many years. As we can see from the ‘before’ photos, the exterior and interior of the property was not attractive to say the least. But this reader looked at the property as a blank canvas to achieving a great outcome. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  “I was advised by many, including experts, to avoid the property. But I saw beyond the poor layout, grime and dirt and had a vision of what it could become. Also, because of the state of the property, I was able to get it at a relatively good price. The first thing I did was to gut the entire property. I changed the layout by moving the entrance to the side of the property. I also rearrange the living area turning it into an L shape and incorporating the kitchen as part of the space. I know that this is not common in Nigeria but I have lived in England for a number of years and I was comfortable with the idea. It makes the space look bigger and brighter.   Also Read: How to Construct a Slab Culvert Over a Drainage   To incorporate more light, I made the windows bigger and increased the number. Never underestimate what natural light can do for your design and the disposition of those living in the property. For a modern look I changed the window style from sliding to casement, incorporated red facing bricks design and put in a new contemporary gate.   [caption id="attachment_25258" align="alignnone" width="519"] Red facing bricks and a modern gate changed the look of the bungalow.[/caption]   [caption id="attachment_25259" align="alignnone" width="553"] The unappealing bungalow when it was bought. Never underestimate what natural light can do for your design and the disposition of those living in the property[/caption]     [caption id="attachment_25262" align="alignnone" width="452"] The lounge-Kitchen-diner concept came up because the purchaser had lived in England and this is a trending topic in home design there. LONDON: THE £5K INCOME MODEL OR THE £5000 PER MONTH INCOME MODEL. (WHICH SOUNDS BETTER?)

London Property Eyes In business terminology, the phrase cash is king is often heard. By and large, any business owner would tell you the same, liquidity is incredibly important to the survival of any organization. Likewise, with individual investments, it’s important to have some regularity of cash flows, as people who have been stuck with Lands or assets they can’t sell or tenants who can’t make rent payments can testify. Amongst various investment options, property is one of the most tried, tested and proven strategies to sustain liquidity. We feel London property investment in particular and what we call the 5k income model is able to meet the long-term objectives of the average investor. A significant percentage of expenditure for most international owners of property is in Foreign exchange which is usually paid out in the form of school fees, holiday expenses, and medical fees. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  We chose the £5k number in specifics because for most people £5000 per month covers more than the basic requirements of living. You may not be able to spend 7 nights at the Penthouse suite of the Dorchester hotel, but it guarantees you a decent holiday in almost any location worldwide. The fact that the pound retains its strength is also significant, for most overseas investors, its a great parameter of lifestyle. For example, in the past, you could have bought a new car for 3 million Naira, but now that same car would cost you 15 million Naira. That 3 million Naira then was £10,000, but today £10,000 is just under 5 million Naira. So the pound stands the test of time and is a good proxy to plan future spending. Whether or not all your expenditure is in Naira, you shouldn’t invest solely in Naira. But especially so if you enjoy holidays abroad or want your kids schooling outside Nigeria. After all, there is a reason all countries have foreign reserves. Any investor in property needs to hold a long-term view. Historically rent rises crudely in tangent with inflation. A case study in point is of a client who bought a 1-bed property in Islington, North London for £130,000 in 2000. The property was rented for £680 at the time, with a mortgage of £630. Fast forward to 2018 and the value of the property is now £450,000, whilst the rental income of the property is now £1750 with the mortgage having dropped to £320 per month. So the property has moved from positive equity of £50 per month to £1430 per month. This is in broader terms an annual positive equity of £17,160 and a valuation boost of £320,000.

  However, In this piece, our focus is on rental growth, not the capital appreciation. If this same model is replicated with 3 or 4 properties, we would achieve our model target of £5000 per month income during your less active retirement years. This model has worked for a lot of our clients and helped sustain their lifestyle at the latter end of their careers and old age. The model is also flexible. ROLE OF TRUSTEES IN REAL ESTATE TRANSACTIONS

STL Trustees, plays varying roles in different Real Estate transactions. The aim is to ensure that transactions are concluded seamlessly and conflicting interests of the various parties to the transaction are harmonized. Our role in any given transaction depends on the structure of the transaction ie. whether it is a transaction for the sale and purchase of real estate or a Joint Venture for the development of real property. We shall discuss STL Trustee’s role under a Joint Venture for the development/redevelopment of real property. The property to be developed or redeveloped can either be residential or commercial or both. WHAT IS A JOINT VENTURE? [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  A joint venture (JV) is a business arrangement in which two or more parties agree to pool their resources for the purpose of accomplishing a specific task. This task can be a new project or any other business activity. In a joint venture (JV), each of the participants is responsible for profits, losses and costs associated with it. Use of Joint Ventures in a Real Estate Transaction: A real estate transaction can be structured as a Joint Venture where the owner of a large parcel of land may wish to develop same either as a residential property or for a commercial property including a shopping mall, for sale to eventual buyers but lacks the financial or technical wherewithal to execute same and rather than simply employing the services of a contractor to execute the project may decide to enter into a Joint Venture with a developer for the development of the property. In this case both parties share the costs and liabilities that will be involved in the development. In some cases the size of the project may even require the developer, who is the party usually tasked with providing the finance for the development, to approach Financial institution(s) or lender(s) to access finance and in most cases using the project as security. The financier may decide to be part of the JV in which case, the transaction will be structured to accommodate the various streams of financing involved in the JV. In either structure, the services will require that a Trustee be appointed to manage the transaction to give comfort to all the parties. The Role of STL under this type of transaction will usually include the following: Take custody of the title documents on behalf of the parties to the transaction; Hold on behalf of stakeholders, all rights and benefits that accrue under the transaction; Ensure proper registration of titles under the transaction; Co-coordinating, perusing and generally reviewing the Trust Deed and other transaction documents; Monitoring obligations under the Trust documents as well as managing the Trust relationship generally; Protect Stakeholder’s interest; Where the interests of the Stakeholders will not be jeopardized, authorize waivers and modifications as may be required; Ensure compliance with the terms of the Trusts Deed

PROPERTY EXPERTS PREDICT SUSTAINABLE GROWTH FOR REAL ESTATE SECTOR

Real Estate: The annual West African Property Investment (WAPI) Summit, the region’s most prominent and largest real estate investment and development conference will be once again taking place in Lagos on 15 & 16 November 2018 at the Eko Hotel and Suites. According to the summit’s host, API Events’ Kfir Rusin, this year’s theme: RE-Calibrating Supply and Demand for Sustainable Growth is a natural evolution of the previous year’s theme, Changing the West African Narrative, which aided more than 400 delegates representing over 200 companies to re-position the sector in a region sparked to a growth footing by Nigeria’s exit from recession. As Rusin expands, “The market has undergone a shift, which is most evident in the changing retail and office occupier market. To help our 500 delegates unpack these changes – we’re pleased to announce that we’ve secured more than 60 well-known regional and international thought leaders to speak at #WAPI2018. These include, Broll Nigeria’s CEO, Bolaji Edu, regional legal authority, Olasupo Shasore (SAN), Ali Djire, Fraym’s Country Manager and PwC Nigeria’s Chief Economist Andrew S Nevin.” As the head of one of the region’s largest multi-disciplinary commercial property services providers, Broll Property Group’s Bolaj Edu’s, position provides him with a unique position to gauge how the market has re-calibrated post-recession. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  As Bolaji says, “If we analyse the grade-A office market in Lagos and the overall retail mall market following the economy entering a deep recession in 2016; take up dropped by approximately 40% (offices) and 55% (retail) between 2016 and 2017. However, as the economic recovery strengthens, we have seen numbers flatten out, and we expect to see an increase over the whole of 2018 from the low point of 2017.” And while Bolaji argues that the drop-off proved challenging it did enable the market to strike a balance, especially at the height of investment – with property values reaching sky high levels. This boom, he says can be attributed to the post 2007 global recession economy whereby investors fueled by low interest rates entered emerging markets aggressively searching for high yields. As Bolaji explains, “We don’t expect to see the same level from the institutional international investment community, which lead to emerging market currencies being too strong and artificially inflated the size of the economies and the size of the middle class in USD terms.” A More Sustainable Market: Following this inflation and subsequent re-adjustment, Bolaji believes that the market is now on a more long-term stable footing. Commenting that: “The market has begun to rebase itself down from a level where rent levels and capital values in parts of Lagos were comparable to the wealthiest cities in the world such as New York and the out skirts of London.” For him, this is most evident in the reducing rates in the commercial and retail sectors, which are now at “more sustainable levels,” he says. One of the most striking results of this re-calibration are the new strategies employed by developers to cater to demand and not “copy & paste” and a change in the demographic of international retailers drawn to the market’s demanding and aspirant middle-class. “Developers and investors in the market are examining building size and design that better reflect the target market. It is important to entertain best practices and the latest trends from around the world, but we need to tailor our projects,” says Bolaji. Adding that the region’s market size and growing demand from the middle-class means that retailers and companies still wish to establish a presence in Nigeria. “However, they are looking at this more strategically taking into consideration both the potential risks in addition to the incredible upside opportunities. International investors and retailers are seeking more partnership opportunities.”

Market Trends: As the market continues to evolve, Broll has deduced several key trends emerging within the local retail space says Bolaji. “We see local retailers driving demand for retail space especially in secondary locations, while international retailer demand is predominantly driven by retailers from Europe and the Americas, whereas historically, Asian brands were the most aggressive.” Adding that the biggest demand driver in existing malls is food and beverage. As the market continues to evolve and re-calibrate in line with economic development – Bolaji has noted the demand continues to be driven by the high end and budget segments. “These are the two areas that we see most inquiries from both investors / developers and retailers and corporates.” Rising Oil Prices: While the rising oil price continues to be of benefit to overall regional GDP growth, Bolaji believes that one market seeing un uptick from oil’s surge is the office sector with occupier demand being driven by the oil and gas sector. While this may not reach the highs of previous eras, especially as many of the new firms are local oil servicing firms. The trend he believes is driven by the fact these local companies can enjoy shorter timelines when closing transactions compared to their international counterparts. THE FEAR OF FOWLER'S FIRS

The Chairman of the Federal Inland Revenue Service (FIRS) is pushing for increase in the country’s tax revenue. Owners of high end properties are in his radar…   It’s pretty difficult to hide a Grade A office block of ten floors. An eighteen storey tower of luxury flats is impossible to overlook. And so, for many signature properties in Lagos, Abuja, Port Harcourt etc, their owners are subjects of speculation, not only for the general public but increasingly, the tax authorities. Most owners utilise companies as special purpose vehicles to acquire their assets and the strategy of the taxman is to tax the corporate structure itself. As the Chairman of the FIRS, Babatunde Fowler, said at the recent Annual General Meeting of the Nigerian Employers Consultative Forum (NECA) in Lagos, “We are not taking property tax. We look at corporate properties in the name of corporate organization. Because we found out corporate organizations, limited liability companies were not filling any returns but we noticed that they own properties.So we started a process in Abuja. We found that property worth N4 trillion in those corporate names have not paid any tax. People fund companies, file no return and then use them to develop properties.” [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  The position of the FIRS in such cases, is to apply the the law, that companies that don’t file or keep any record, the FIRS will take its turnover as a basis to compute tax due by such company. The FIRS will take 20 per cent of that turnover as the assumed profit and tax it at 30 per cent. “So if you have a property worth N100 million, with that computation, we charge you N6 million. That is basically what it is. It is not property tax, we are just using turnover to estimate the tax you pay” the Chairman said.  

Also Read: Property experts predict sustainable growth for Real Estate Sector

  “We started at home in the Federal Capital Territory, and we established over 2,000 properties and land that were built or developed in corporate names and limited liability companies. The value of these properties is in excess of N2tn, and they (the owners) have never paid any taxes for them. We have contacted them and sent them our assessments. A number of them are paying. “But for those that have owners that are not paying, we will go to court to get the approval or court order to sell those properties. We are not only doing that in Abuja. We have concluded in Lagos; we are currently going to Osun, Oyo, Kaduna; and eventually, we will cover the whole federation.” Feelers by Highbrow Living have confirmed that indeed, a number of properties have been caught in this process with owners caught out, negotiating their assessments with the FIRS rather than taking the matter to the courts for a judicial pronouncement. In a tough environment for property owners, there is something else to fear: an assessment from the FIRS.   [/read]

ALL HAIL THE ANCHOR TENANT

Why the retail centre promoters and anchor tenants have a symbiotic relationship A summons from my aunt in her 80s is not to be taken lightly even if it is to be sent on an errand for a petty item. But my ‘errand boy’ status may be coming to an end as she now does her shopping at a nearby mall. I was abit surprised at this because she and my mum belong to the older generation of Nigerians that travel to Lagos Island and visit places like Apongbonand Oke-arinto buy consumer goods and foodstuffs for the month in bulk. My aunt in her remarks,wondered why she should ‘stress’ herself under the hot sun and go that far when youcan get everything at a reasonable price within the anchor shops of the mall which is in close proximity to where she lives. Well, thanks to the anchor tenants in most malls, they havegiven most people, young and old a justified reason at least to visit shopping centres/malls. Why anchor tenants are vital [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  www.businessdictionary.com defines anchor tenant as “Usually the first, and the leading, tenant in a shopping center whose prestige and name recognition attracts other tenants and, it is hoped, shoppers”.They serve as the primary traffic generators and are expected to make the centres economically viable. InNigeria, they are mainly departmental store branches that trade consumer goods in different product categories such as clothes, electronics, groceries, furniture, householdappliances, food, drinksetc. Also quite common are the retailers in the Entertainment and leisure category such as Cinemas, game arcade centreswhilst the others common to this class usually deal and trade in white consumer goods such as refrigerators, washing machines and large pieces of electronic household equipment. My article would not please a number of shopping centre promoters, as it might seem to be placing much emphasis on the importance of the anchortenant. The truth is that they are indeedsignificant and are the keysuccess determinants of most retail facilities. Understanding anchor tenants costs It’s a known fact that most traditional anchor tenants demand for an arm and a leg before they agree to secure a space in most facilities. This puts most promoters off from the onset and thereby make them consider brands that might not be ideally suitable for the space being leased. Thereasons for their consistent demand for lower rents and perks is notexaggerated however. It boils down to the cost of fitting out, stocking and carrying out their operation in such shops. In the entertainment and leisure segment forinstance, setting up astandard 4 screen cinema in a 1,000sqm retail space would cost an average of $1million(approx N365m).This is excluding the rent and the service charge.For the supermarkets that comprises of the butchery and the bakery, the average cost is N130,000-N200,000/m2.Unlike the cinemas,this excludes the stock, the trading equipment,rent and service charge. Even though this columnist has not analysed the average cost of fitting out similar spaces in shopping centres outside Nigeria,it isquite obvious that it would be costlier in the country when considering the fact that most of the equipment and items used are imported.The eventualcost of procuring such foreign exchange to import the goods is very high and usually makes the whole venture highly expensive from the start.   The symbiotic relationship The mall promoters should start looking at the anchor tenants as partners and consider supportingthem in their various businesses knowing fully well that once they succeed andare profitable, the likely chance of the mall to be successful is very high.This could be done by both carrying out joint marketing sessions, promotions, regularbrand activation to promote the brands, road shows, etc. Due to their strict adherence to standard and the importance most anchor tenants place on fit-out, most traditional anchor tenants carry out their fit-outthemselves. What is required in most cases from the developer is to provide a shell which would have taken into consideration the required head room and M & E requirements. Mall promoters could assist anchor tenants such as cinema owners in supporting them further by carrying out additional works in their spaces such as soundproofing of the entire space, tiling and provision of ceiling cover. Joint venture initiatives between the mall promoters and the anchor tenants should also be considered. Thanks to modern technology, there are better ways to monitor revenues generated from retail sales.This will help clear the doubt of most mall promoters on the workability of the initiative as the technology deployed would help provide the needed accountability and transparency. Granting the anchor tenants free trading periods is usually a good way of supporting their business too as they would be able to recoup a part of their start-upcost.   Not just any anchor tenant: The choice of the anchor tenant is also quite crucial and can make or mar the overall viability of such facility.There are a lot of mistakes being made in this area by retail shopping centre promoters all over the country. Some years ago, I was opportuned to consult for a mall developer who was building a facility with a GLA of about 3,000m2. The facility is situated on a prominent road and is surrounded by multiple estates with residents having good spendable income.I tried to let him accept a big supermarket chain which had the full compliments of a general store,pastry and bakery to cater for the class of the immediate locality but he rejected them due to the low rent they were offering. He ended up leasing the space to a supermarket eventually.I was at the same facility some weeks ago and even though the anchor tenants are in place, the mall is only about 30% occupied. Before a major space is leased to an anchor tenant, market research has to be carried out on the population statistics, demographics and lifestyle of the trading area. This research would help determine the quality of the anchor tenant that would be required to help drive the traffic in such facility and also attract other retailers to the centre. It is important to realise that most of the traditional anchor tenants like most businessmen all over the world are all concerned about the bottom line which is, making profit. In making decisions as regards the location to set up and the retail facility to be considered, they also would determine the kind of consumer goods to trade in such locations. Therefore,beyond considering the brand of the anchor tenant and the market research outcome, the retail facility promoters must properly look into the consumer goods to be traded to ensure that it would be able to fully attract all categories of consumers coming into the mall. Effort has to be made for all shopping classes to be covered in terms of product offerings. The product offering invariably defines the shopping class coming to the mall. Therefore, don’t just consider an anchor tenant by its brand identity but also consider properly what its offering. The mall might be better off with an unknown brand than one that brings the name but fails to supply the full compliment of options. The summary of the story is that both the retail facility promoters and the anchor tenants should realise from the onset that they are partners and they need each other. The landlord needs a primary driver of traffic whilst the anchor tenant requires a facility with a good tenant mix that would attract consumers to buy its goods and generate profit to its shareholders. Danger from the okadaman? There is currently a rising trend where retailers in the traditional markets are now heavily deploying the use of technology to link up with their customers. They now provide homedelivery service(by men on motorcycles known as okadamen)to their customers for all kinds of consumer goods. The anchor tenants most especially the supermarkets in most cities are yet to provide these services. Nigeria has a youthful population with 65% of our population between the age bracket of 18-35 years. The people in the category are easily influenced by social media and they embrace technology. More than ever before, employers of labour are demanding more from the working class. This reduces their free hours in a typical day. In North America, Amazon has caused a major disruption in the commercial retail industry. The introduction of Amazon Fresh – the arm of the company that delivers everything from fresh meat and chicken to farm fresh vegetables and fruits even more so. It’s hard for you to find any supermarket or departmental store that doesn’t have a section of the business that caters for internet shopping or home deliveries. The demography and the work culture in the country today supports it and should be provided for by most supermarkets and departmental stores. The upsurge in the development of shopping malls/centres for the past decade is a welcome development and has shaped the shopping experience from what it used to be. However, we are entering an era where a sizeable section of the populace would patronise more of retailers that can deliver consumer goods to their homes and offices than visiting such retail facilities. Just Imagine if my Aunty had the number of her retailers in Apongbon and they could provide home delivery service. Would she have gone to the mall to shop? Food for thought.   Olurogba Orimalade FNIVS, FRICS Commercial Retail Consultant Email: rogba@rogbaorimaladeandco.com Tel. No: +2348033089562   [/read]

The quality and pricing of facilities management is a differentiating factor in today’s luxury real estate market. The investor or landlord who ignores how his tenants and real estate assets are treated does so at his own peril. The icing on the cake in this very competitive market is FM; hence Landlords must ensure that their facilities management standard is commensurate (or even surpass) the tenants’ expectations. Engr. Femi Akintunde explains in this article, that the investor/landlord’s quest to exceed tenant’s expectation must start with the budgeting process ...   The aspect of budgeting for facilities management or maintenance as it applies to the investor is not what a lot of people consider to be an important exercise. A lot of property investors don’t do it –people take it as ‘I will spend when I need to spend’. So, when you are considering your annual budget for all your expenses, including children’s education, household expenses for food, medical insurance and so on; you must understand that your physical environment – home, office, etc also needs to be budgeted for. This will help you determine how well these budgeted costs fit into the resources plan expectation and expenditure. For real estate, if you spend on your buildings without planning for it, you cannot control your costs. You will end up spending more than is required. The budgeting process enables you to anticipate events. It enables you to prevent crisis, to be better prepared you for any emergencies, and to put contingency plans in place in case of shortages or inadequacies. Another advantage of budget planning for your real estate asset is that you are able to get better prices than if you have to do negotiations at short notices. For example, if a heavy-duty generator that is to be serviced every 250 hours is planned for, you will have an idea of how much every servicing costs. You will have an idea of how long it takes to get to 250 hours; so you will be ready to meet the costs and schedule the servicing at a time convenient to all. [read more="Click here to Continue Reading" less="Read Less"]  Otherwise, you increase the tendency is to run the generator beyond the recommendation hours and get a breakdown. Then the pressure comes to fix the generator before residents arrive or start to complain. You will have to buy parts under emergency and many times you end up spending more. The risk of buying inferior quality is also very high in unplanned situations. There will also be the attendant effect of the impact of this breakdown on your tenants’ lifestyle (or business in the case of commercial spaces); and this will come into play when they are considering renewing their leases. How does the budgeting process take place? There are two aspects: the capital and operation budget. Operations Budget is for the expenses that you incur to maintain the asset in a form that will continue to deliver the expected services without necessarily increasing, renewing or modifying the existing capacity. Key considerations in an operation budget are Personnel costs, admin costs &consumables, and third-party services. Working on the Operations Budget raises the question of providing services in-house or outsourcing to an FM company. This is a question that is best addressed on its own merits; but my general advice is that the choice of one over the other will depend on the size, scope or variety of services the asset requires. If the in-house option best suits the circumstances, then during the budgeting process, you will have to look at the salary and emoluments of the staff members engaged in the facility management duties and compute the costs for the budget year or period. The second line under the Operations Budget is the tools and equipment that they will use. There are two categories of tools and equipment. There are Management Tools like laptops, telephone etc and operational tools and equipment like toolbox. Consumables refer to items that run down in the course of usage – brooms for cleaners, washing liquid, toilet roll. Generator servicing parts like filter are also involved. These sounds mundane but there are clear examples of even Grade ‘A’ office complexes without toilet roll or hand wash soap in their washrooms.

Also Read: Hail The Anchor Tenant

Third Party Services are items that you have to call specialist companies for. Generator maintenance, Refuse collection, Swimming pool maintenance, Lift maintenance and so forth. It is advisable to sign a service contract and on that basis, you factor in the costs into the budget. If you outsource the facility management function, the process is relatively easier as the FM Company will come up with the budget. Typically, the FM Company’s budget highlights the various services and their costs but power is separated from these into its own category. Many of these services are the planned services – like security, cleaning, swimming pool maintenance etc and as the name implies, planned services should be quite certain – you can see and plan ahead. Note however that provision should also be made for unplanned breakdowns. For instance, it is impossible to predict when a door handle will malfunction or a pump will break down. So, we advise that about 20% of the planned budget be set aside as provisional sum for unplanned activities. It is very important that the FM Company and the owner agree on this because when the unplanned events occur, each party will be looking to the other to finance the repairs. Another point to note is that the Landlord/Investor should also add into the budget, the cost of his own staff who will be the liaison with the FM Company. In the next segment of the article, we will be looking at the capital budget and the best practice in the industry when budgeting for power for real estate assets. You can send comments, questions etc to Engr Femi Akintunde on highbrow@castles.com.ng. Read past articles on www.castles.com.ng    [/read]

post_content: Tottenham is a name that for a significant part of its recent history has either elucidated fear or forlorn looks in the hearts of all those who hear the name. Venturing within its borders were feats thought to be reserved to either the brave hearted or very foolish. Whilst popular for being the home ground of the Premiership football side Tottenham Hotspurs, it became more infamous for the 1985 Broadwater Farm riot, the 2011 Tottenham riot, and gang crime. That narrative, however, is fast becoming the tale of a Tottenham past. The postcode’s chequered past has seemed to be a catalyst for a regeneration akin to that of the Kings Cross and Paddington area, that is bringing about a positive change to the area. Investments to date of over £1 billion from the public and private sector alike has birthed a new stadium, 10,000 new homes, and a £100m new Tottenham Hale station. [read more="Click here to Continue Reading" less="Read Less"]  The new stadium, set to open later this year, will be the largest capacity football club stadium in London, creating a new sports and leisure destination for the capital with a hive of activity 365 days a year, a new museum, an innovative Skywalk, 21st century retail experiences, first-class conference and banqueting and high quality leisure facilities including restaurants and a hotel – and will attract in excess of two million visitors per year. Supporting the stadium development will be a vastly improved local transport infrastructure, including redeveloped stations at White Hart Lane and Northumberland Park and upgrades at Tottenham Hale. The arrival of Crossrail 2 will further enhance an area that is already highly accessible by public transport. The Club scheme has kick-started regeneration plans to the east and west. The Club has to date already delivered 258 new homes, 100 percent affordable, the new Brook House Primary School on the site of an old rubber factory, the 78,000 square foot Sainsbury’s supermarket and the London Academy of Excellence Tottenham school (LAET). Lend-lease also signed a £1 billion development deal with Haringey Council to regenerate the area around the site of Tottenham Hotspur's new stadium in north London, with the promise of 2,500 homes and 3,000 new jobs over the course of the project which begins in 2018. Plans and images describe public spaces with shops and restaurants, a community park, library, community center and a new Tube station that will help with getting fans to and from the new stadium once it has been opened. In a recent questionnaire we held, transport came up top as the chief consideration we take to account in the selection of where to live for first-time buyers. Closely followed by affordability and the intuition makes sense, whilst you are just getting your feet planted in life, you want to be as close to jobs as possible. A criterion sufficiently met by Tottenham which is in Zone 3, a short ride from the city of London's financial center. For a wider perspective, there are journey times of 15 mins to Liverpool Street, 20 mins to London Kings Cross, 14 minutes to Stratford and has the Stansted Express to Stansted Airport. Also Read; Step into a World of Beachside Luxury Perhaps the best reason to consider Tottenham as an area to live or invest is the property price, which is relatively lower than most neighboring areas (DATA). In a time of unaffordable housing, Tottenham represents one of the few truly good deals for first-time buyers and investors, with its Victorian houses becoming increasingly popular with young professionals and families that have been priced out of Hackney for instance. We believe Tottenham to be one of the open secret London property success stories, and one that is long overdue at that.   Price: £250,000 - £280,000 Rental: £1,400 - £1,700 per calendar month      [/read]

International Brands Versus the Locals: The Debate Less than 30 minutes of arriving at the venue of a birthday event,the usual debate started.Who is the greatest football player of all time-Cristiano Ronaldo or Lionel Messi? Once such arguments starts, just know your event has developed another life on its own. From a football enthusiast standpoint, both players each have their fans and nothing under the sun would ever change their mind about their position and justifiable so as both players have various attributes that make them so unique and great. It all depends on the kind of attributes that endear you to the player. The same can be said of International and local retail brands. There has been a rapid influx of International retail brands into the country over the past decade in Nigeria. This can be attributed to the increased foreign direct investment which targeted the promotion and development of commercial retail centres of international standard in the country. This happened to be a blue ocean area in the country at the time and given the fact that most markets in southern Africa, Europe and the Americas were becoming saturated, it was definitely inevitable for such investments to make way into the country. The big international retail brands also were filling the pinch in these countries and they also created an expansionist plan in Africa with Nigeria being at the centre of their plans. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  The successful entry of the Mobile telecom giants and the Pay Cable TV promoters were also good reference points as to how profitable business could be in the most populous black nation in the world. Majority of the malls in the country which we call ‘’GRADE A ‘’ derive most of their financing from international foreign lenders and banks that have foreign affiliation. For a mall promoter to have a chance of being funded by these companies/institutions, there has to be a certain percentage of off take tenants willing to lease the shop spaces before being considered for funding. The International retail brands are usually the first set to be approached especially in the anchor tenant’s category. Irrespective of their credit worthiness, capacity and the market demand for such brands in the local market, there is usually a demand by the financiers to secure these brands in the malls first before considering the local players. Furthermore, there has been a general acceptability of International retail brands by Nigerians. The bullish nationwide roll out of such brands in the business of departmental store/ supermarkets seems to give credence to the success of the brands in the country.
Also Read:
  • Property Eyes: Spotlight on Tottenham
  • Step into a World of Beachside Luxury
  • Budgeting for Facilities Management
If you enter any supermarket in most of the Grade A malls which are mainly international brands, you would observe that 85% of goods displayed and sold are locally produced. I have also observed that majority of the workforce in most of the shops that have international retail brands are Nigerians. There are now local retailers in all retail category segments. It is common place to see local departmental stores on high streets these days. The question then is ‘’What’s stopping the local brands from dominating the commercial retail space’’? It could be argued that it boils down to finance which the international retails have access to easily in single digits compared to the double digits that the local financial institutions provide to retailers in the country to ply their trade. Finance could be part of the problem but is it really the major problem? To compete favourably with the international retail brands, there is need for the locals to run proper outfits governed by strict corporate governance which adheres to certain standards and principles. There has to be continuous update of their knowledge on modern management practice, most especially in the area of supply chain management and technology. Creating a unique brand is non-negotiable in Nigeria. The average Nigerian is a believer and loves the best things in life irrespective of his level in the society. With the right exposure and training on how to properly run a business, the sky is the limit for the average retailer operating in the remotest parts of the country. The funding would eventually come. There are good examples that the locals could relate to. In the healthcare sector, Healthplus started from a small shop in the heart of Ikeja over a decade ago. Now,this company operating in 48 locations was just recently able to get US$18 m investment from Alta Semper Capital LLP, a private equity manager investing flexible and strategic capital across select African growth markets. I fondly recollect that the founder of the outfit delivered a lecture at the Lagos Business School in 2014 where she talked about the company and the processes being used to run the outfit. I was therefore not surprised when I heard about the news some months ago. In a volatile economy like Nigeria, any retail facility needs the best of both worlds. Some years ago, when there were sudden changes in policy and it become difficult to obtain foreign exchange and the attendant cost, the newly developed malls during that period suffered greatly. It was mainly the local brands that were able to lease shop spaces. Some retailers even had to halt their roll out plans due to the disruption brought about by the government policy. Indeed, the gap between the international and local retail brands as regards brand identity especially in the anchor tenant segment is closing and in not too distant future, I see both brands almost at par with each other. Quality and standards would always be at play whether the brand is international or local. On my answer to the best player debate,It’s neither of those two players.I am not even going to suggest Maradona or Pele.My choice, King Kenny Dalglish MBE. The reason is most obvious- YOU WOULD NEVER WALK ALONE!

Data & Tech to Transform Nigerian Retail Market The convergence of AI, tech, and data on Nigeria’s multi-billion dollar plus retail market – will be a strategic focus to local & international developers, investors and retailers at the 4th annual West Africa Property Investment Summit taking place on 15 and 16 November 2018 in Lagos. Considered one of the world’s most significant and accessible investment opportunities, the opportunity in the country has long whet the appetites of the world’s capital movers; however, for many, the opportunity has been missed or misjudged to a lack of relevant, actionable and useful data. A ROBUST RETAIL SECTOR: One of the emerging thought leaders in the field is Ali Djire, the country head of Fraym, who believes that embracing a data-driven approach to retail will prevent further Nakumatt styled retail implosions. In a market under pressure with retailers struggling with under performing new locations due to steep competition and a lack of critical consumer mix, access to data is increasingly transforming the fortunes of companies in the sector. Says Djire, “The need for a data-driven approach is becoming an imperative for retailers to not only inform what products to carry on the shelf, but also to get unprecedented insights into where to locate their stores, how to price based on ability to pay, and how to respond to competition.” RETAIL’S GROWING VALUE TO THE NIGERIAN GDP: According to Djire, retail currently accounts for 16% of the Nigerian GDP and is viewed by many as a new frontier of growth for local and international investors. A view which is shared by Jan Van Zyl, head of property development for leading pan-Africa real estate development fund, Novare Equity Partners. “Nigeria is the largest economy in Africa. Therefore, you cannot brand yourself as a Sub-Saharan Fund and not have a presence in Nigeria.” Adding that the fund is also looking at options in Ghana and Cote D’Ivoire. While the scale of the opportunity in Nigeria has attracted many entrants over the past decade, experienced investors and developers understand that the formal retail market is limited and dynamic that can grow exponentially. $300 MILLION INVESTED: As Van Zyl explains, “We believe that we are at the right place, at the right time, and we have invested in four shopping centres in Nigeria since 2010 with a book value in excess of $300 million.” As one of Africa’s bullish international funds in real estate on the continent, the pan-Africa fund is in the country for the long-term. However, while the recovery over the last 12 months has been slow, Van Zyl argues that this is not a Nigerian, but an emerging market phenomenon. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  RECOVERY AND ELECTIONS: “Combined with elections in February 2019, we find that many potential new entrants are waiting on the sidelines until the uncertainty surrounding an election period has settled. It is important to note that, such a cycle is not Nigeria specific, but is experienced in most emerging markets throughout Africa and other continents.” However, he does note that there has been a trend of decreasing the size of future shopping centre developments in the current market, which is one way in which the market has recalibrated to cope with market relating to the recession. For Kfir Rusin, the Managing Director of the WAPI Summit, the advent of data and new technologies are critical to quickening the somewhat slow pace of recovery in the retail sector post-recession.

THE FUTURE: “As a pioneer in their field, Fraym’s use of Geospatial data, AI and Machine Learning technologies can provide actionable intelligence on communities down to 1 square kilometre across the country. This unique and relevant data has the potential to be transformative catalyst of growth for the retail sector.” With such useful smart data increasingly, many large market layers are actively recalibrating their approach. As Djire reveals, “We are actively working with global investment players, development organisations, as well as local companies, to get actionable market insights. Through our data, we are seeing early signs of companies leveraging Fraym’s geospatial data platform to streamline their operations and retail strategy.
