How to get capital gains on property in these tough times In 1999, when Castles Lifestyle was first published, a plot of land in Lekki Phase 1 was valued at around N2m. Today, in 2018, the same plot is slightly above N200m. So anyone who paid for the plot in 1999, would have made N198m profit on the transaction. The N198m is what is known in investment terms as capital gains. Capital gain is the difference in the value of the property down compared to when you bought it. Rent as we discussed last week is what the property owner gets from someone who uses the property for a while. Major difference between rent and capital gain in cash-flow terms is that you can continue to enjoy revenue (rent) by giving up possession of the property for a period. You don’t give up ownership of the property. But for you to enjoy the cash from the increase in the value of the property, you have to sell. The point that you have to sell to enjoy the capital gains* is very important when we are considering real estate investment. This is because as a general rule, property tends to appreciate. So even if you buy property as your home or for rental income, the value will go up. As you don’t intend to sell these properties, that is outside of our consideration here. We are looking at a scenario where you buy property with the express intention of reselling it for a higher price at a later date. What factors do you have to consider when you are buying real estate to sell at a higher price subsequently? [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Holding Period: First is how long do you want to hold the asset before selling? Accepted wisdom is that the longer you hold, the higher the price. So if you want to hold for a short period, say between a year to two years, then there must be a factor or factors that will make the price move in such a short (for real estate investment) time. One is shortage of supply. If there is only one plot of land left in a desirable estate and you have the money, you can reasonably expect that within two years someone will come to buy the property at a premium. Another factor that can make property desirable is if some deficiency is going to be cured. So plots of land around the route of the new rail line in Lagos which suffered from poor transport links to the city centre, will become more desirable when the line is complete. Or land covered by a ‘mere’ Letter of Allocation, which is considered as an inferior title will be cheap but as soon as the Certificate of Occupancy on the property is processed, the price goes up. So for quick transactions, there is some skill. For long term, say about 5 years, buying in areas that are not well developed and so reasonably cheap, is a good way to invest. As soon as development reaches the area, the price would have gone up and you can sell. Locations like Ibeju Lekki and the Mowe Ofada axis are good for this kind of strategy. Having said that, four years ago, land in Lekki 1 was trading at around N150m per 1,000sqm plot and today, such plot is going for N200m to N220m. Read Also:
  • Data & Tech to Transform Nigerian Retail
  • International Brands Versus the Locals
  • Property Eyes: Spotlight on Tottenham
Land or developed property: Second factor you should consider is whether you should buy land or developed property. Developed property means you can enjoy a hybrid return of rents during the holding period and also enjoy capital gains when the property is sold. This means that you have to invest more money as developed properties generally cost more than bare land. You also have to get into the management of the property during the holding period. It also appears that it is generally, easier to sell land and the returns better than developed property. Transaction Costs: A third factor to consider is cost of the transaction. Buying and selling land is not cheap. Agency fees can be anything from 5% to 10% of the price of the property. Perfection (Governor’s Consent and Land Registry registration) could add another 10% as fees. When selling the investor is also subject to Capital Gains Tax on the profit he had made on the transaction. Rate of return: In the good old days up to 2010, property values could double in a year. In 1999, a 675sqm plot of land in Victoria Garden City sold for N1.7m. Three years later, it was N12m. But those days have gone and property price rises are more conservative now. So it is up to the investor to check if the capital gains he is expected are commensurate to other investments like shares, Treasury Bills etc    [/read]

Nothing adds as much drama and style to a modern building like a cantilevered room, projecting from the upper floor. Our main subject is a a Quebec house featuring  a living room contained within a glass box that projects over the garden designed by Montreal studio ACDF Architecture. But you don’t have to go for such a dramatic and some may say, impractical extension. So, we have for the more conservative readers, more practical examples …..but we dare say, no less alluring. Location: catch the future With the rate of our population growth in Nigeria, it is only logical that in 10 years from now there would have to be newer developments and areas to cater for the increase mass of people. This growth is going to be centered in urban areas like Lagos. Ten to fifteen years ago, Lekki was not a prominent thought in the mind of a lot of people investing in property, but today through the efforts of Lagos state, population increase, the expansion of the Lekki-epe expressway and the soon to be opened Lekki-ikoyi link bridge, Lekki peninsular scheme 1 can be labeled a success. It is one of the leading suburbs in the city where people can work, live and play all in the same neighbourhood. This was not always the case though; Ten years ago, one could find a thousand square meter lot in Lekki phase 1 for One Million Naira, today that same lot would command no less than a hundred times that amount. The question now is, in 2028 where would we look at and wish we had invested in in 2018? Would that be Lekki Scheme 2, Epe, the free trade zone or even Otta? It is not a matter of if, but when, population scientist are predicting that our population in cities like Lagos and Port Harcourt will double within the next fifteen years, how will you cash in? [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Think Long term: It is important to note that the modern family goes through several cycles; there is the beginning stage when a couple are newlyweds and need decent size space, typically 3 bedrooms to start. The family grows, and has three, four or maybe five children and requires more space both inside the house and outside. At this point people we start to see the seven to ten bedroom homes, then there comes the stage when the children start moving out and getting married and before you know it the house is empty, just the man his wife and a lot of vacant rooms. It is at this point we see the older parents leaving these ‘empty nesting” homes and opting for small spaces as they did in the beginning stages of their family, the difference now is they typically have more financial ability at this stage of their lives and want nicer neighbourhoods. So what happens to these empty nester houses? It is harder to rent and maintain a 10 bedroom house than it is let a three or four bedroom apartment. Keeping that in mind can inform the design of a house so in future it may be easier to partition and break down into smaller units or be converted into alternate uses. Read also:
  • The Cantilevered Room
  • Africa RE to build Corporate HQ in Abuja
Running cost: Quite simply the upkeep of a house is directly proportional to the size of the house. It might seem like a good idea at the time to build the biggest thing one can afford, but as time goes on repairs and maintenance would have to be done on the house and this can get very pricey the bigger the property. For one, there is increased electricity and water consumption which add up over time. It is a great idea to try to balance long term housing needs with long term cost of maintenance. Yes, you read that right. Not Eko Atlantic City, Banana Island, Asokoro or Maitama. All those locations have a lot to commend them and put them in the running for top spot but as the massive projects sited in Ibeju Lekki take off, the promise of the area is more obvious. The Lekki Free Trade Zone, Dangote Refinery, Dangote Fertilizer Plant, Lekki Deep Sea Port, Lagos Fourth Mainland Bridge and Lekki International Airport are all planned for this location.  While the fate of such large projects are always suspect in Nigeria, two factors give investors cause of guarded optimism that most of them will be completed: private sector interest and the continuity in the Lagos State Government. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Some may argue that Ibeju Lekki, like other outlying areas of Lekki always had latent potential. As was the case for Ikate Elegushi, then Agungi, the Chevron etc, demand and high prices of mature Lekki locations will compel interest in outlying areas like Ibeju Lekki. True, but because of the employment generating capacity of the projects in Ibeju Lekki, people are not only going to live here- they will work here as well. Not only will the projects employ people directly, they will also attract businesses to the location as well. It is not far-fetched to predict that the Lekki Deep Sea Port will create another ‘Apapa’ type location in the location. Unlike Sangotedo or Ikota, Ibeju Lekki will be a complete town with self-sustaining commercial life compared to other areas where people live but go to work or school in Lekki 1, Victoria Island, Ikoyi etc. This has implication for all stakeholders: Government, businesses, real estate developers/investors and potential residents of the area. For Government, the planning imperative is clear. If they are to avoid the mistakes of Lagos – trailers parking on the road, traffic gridlock etc, a proactive approach to how the area develops has to be taken right away and maintained over the formative years of the location. Real estate developers have to think beyond the residential estate as the only type of business that can flourish here. Business parks and other commercial real estate and even tourist based real estate will work here. For Ibeju-Lekki, it is a matter of ‘when’ not ‘if’. Read also:

  • Three things you don't think of when buying property
Ibeju Lekki Projects & likelihood of success Assessment by MCORE (MCORE.co) a Nigerian real estate investment firm.  
Lekki Free Trade Zone (LFTZ)
 
100% Chance of success The LFTZ was established as an industrial and commercial hub for West Africa. The Tolaram Group, a multinational with products in 75 countries is the sponsor. Other parties are the Nigerian Ports Authority (NPA) and LSG. The zone has commenced operations and the refinery, fertilizer and petrochemicals plants in addition to gas for power generation will create a critical mass that draws manufacturers to the zone. We give the LFTZ a 100% likelihood of success
 
Dangote Refinery
100% Chance of success The refinery, producing 650,000 barrels of refined crude per day is set to become the largest single train petroleum refinery in the world. The project is fully funded and the sponsor is known to deliver large scale projects to completion. The project is strategically important to the nation hence political backing is very strong and with the project having very strong commercial viability, we give this project a 100% likelihood that it will be completed within 5 years
Dangote Fertilizer Plant
 
100% Chance of success   The Plant will produce 3m tonnes of fertilizer per annum and will be one of the largest single capacity fertilizer complexes in the world. Dangote is a strong sponsor with a track record of completion of large projects of this magnitude. The first producing unit of the fertilizer plant is complete and is awaiting the completion of the feeder gas pipeline to commence operations by 2019. Based on the above, we give the project a 100% score for expected completion within 5 years
Lekki Deep Sea Port
100% Chance of success The US$1.2Bn project will be the deepest sea port in Africa. The Tolaram Group is the sponsor in conjunction with the NPA, LSG and China Harbour Engineering Company. Political will to complete the project is strong driven by the critical need to support the refinery and the FTZ along with the growing pressure on existing Lagos ports. The project is due for completion in 2020 and is fully funded hence we give this project a 100% probability of completion within 5 years
       
Lagos Fourth Mainland Bridge
 
50% Chance of success The LFMB will link Lekki with Ikorodu and ease pressure on the Third Mainland Bridge and adjoining feeder roads. LSG are seeking a private sector partner to deliver the project under a PPP Concession. The LSG has been unable to identify a suitable partner and may need to sweeten the deal to bring credible parties to the table. We give this project a 50% probability that the LSG will be able to sort out outstanding issues and deliver the project within a 5 year timeframe
     
Lekki International Airport    
   
30% Chance of success The LIA is proposed as a PPP with the LSG contributing 3,500 Ha of land as its equity and a private sector consortium designing, building, financing, operating and managing the project. Neither sponsor nor funding has been found as the airport is currently not commercially viable. This is likely to change as corporate take-up within the LFTZ reaches critical mass over the coming 10-15 years. The airport has been given a 30% probability of completion within the coming 5 years.

Last month, Engr Femi Akintunde explained that for an investor/Landlord to exceed the expectations of his tenant (a requirement in this competitive market), a facilities management budget is the best place to start. He detailed in our November edition, a practical guide on how to go about the operations side of a facilities management budget.  This month he concludes with directions on budgeting for capital expenditure and power.  

Capital Expenditure budget

Capital Assets like generators, transformers, pumps etc have a life span. The investor/landlord has to maintain a Capital Assets Register and plan for the replacement of these assets at the appropriate time. This is done by keeping a proportion of the rents every year aside as Capital Replacement Reserve. Where it is an owner-occupier or estate owned by residents, the norm is to levy themselves (the Owners) to keep a percentage of the service charge as ‘Sinking Fund’ also for this purpose. Apart from replacing capital items, the fund will also be used for large projects like external painting – which we recommend should be done every two years. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Planning for the replacement of capital assets means that the estate will keep to the standards when it was first built. Take for instance, the replacement of gym equipment. Equipment like treadmills wear out within two years. If this provision to replace is not made, there’s the high likelihood that only first set of gym equipment will be used and upon breakdown, the equipment will be set aside and the gym turned into aerobic dancing hall or hall for children birthday party or meeting! Make sure that the Capital Assets Register is all encompassing.  ‘Small’ items like pumps for recycling water for swimming pool, taking water from the underground tank to the overhead tank, must be replaced when they get to the end of their useful life, must be included.

Power Budget

We always advise that this is separated from the operational budget. There are many things that impact your power budget that makes it very difficult to plan ahead. Power has two components – diesel generator power and public supply. For public supply, it is a function of how many hours this is utilised and the tariff structure that applies to the property. Typically, a large property has its own transformer for which a meter- known as the Maximum Demand (MD) meter is attached. Tariff here is typically higher. For budget purposes on a figure for public supply, you usually start at the historical usage and arrive at a projected amount. For example, records show that a particular building enjoyed 30% public supply in the current year – that could be a basis for calculating public supply at 8 hours a day. The tariff is known and the cost can be calculated. Second part is the diesel and generator supply. For the generator, there are two components - maintenance and capital cost. The capital cost is usually rejected by tenants; they argue that it is factored into their rent and when the generator packs up, the landlord is to replace it, not them. For maintenance, you calculate how many hours we need to run on generator and calculate the diesel consumption. Every generator has the diesel consumption rate per hour. The hours used and the consumption rate will give you the diesel required for the year. You can then take an intelligent projection of the diesel price. The prices in the last two years have been fairly stable in the N210 – N230/ litre range unlike previous years when it has been quite volatile. Here the macro economy comes in: looking at the rising crude oil prices, events in the country etc, you can project that diesel prices will go up to say N250/litre (Engr Akintunde was quite prescient as a newspaper reported shortly before going to press that diesel rates are in the N250/litre range).  With these projections, one can arrive at a budgeted rate for public supply costs, diesel costs and maintenance costs.  This will give you the operational budget costs for power.   Conclusion The Facilities Management budget is about projected figures. So one must continue to compare actual costs against budgeted figures to get the variance. This can be done on a monthly or quarterly basis. At the end of the year, you may have a deficit to be financed or a surplus to be rolled over. One must sound a note of warning. Owners tend to over negotiate budgets down instead of accepting realistic figures.  A pared down budget may look attractive to the landlord/Investor/tenants but it means that you are making it more difficult for the Facility Manager to respond adequately to needs that arise during the period. A number of factors will determine if there is a surplus or deficit at the end of the year but what is certain is that you would have averted many crises because of the proactive nature of the budgeting process.   [/read]

In Africa and the world over, nationalistic laws and doctrines has never been much greater than these days. In the United states, Mr. Donald J Trump cannot stop emphasizing his America first doctrine. Same message seems to be blowing all over Europe. In Nigeria, President Muhammadu Buhari has directed through Executive Orders that local professionals should be given first priority when companies are engaging service providers in key aspects of the built environment. This columnist cannot claim ignorance to the reasons behind this nationalistic call spreading all over the globe. One of the most important reasons is the rise of unemployment. Unemployment has been proven to be a time bomb which if not quickly handled, could create instability and breakdown of law and order in any nation. The memories of the Arab spring comes to mind. Nigeria in particular, has a huge unemployment rate. Most of the ethnic killings and crime can easily be attributed to the unengaged youths who have nothing to do. The most political correct and sensible thing to do to curb the surge of unemployment by any sane Government is to create policies that restrict foreigners from snapping such opportunities the indigenous professionals can handle.  However, there has to be a delicate balance when such laws are put in place especially in the real estate sector. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  In the 70s, key personalities like Alhaji Femi Okunnu SAN ensured that most professionals in the built environment had their professional organisations established and recognised by law which gave them the legal right to practise locally and for the citizenry to patronise their services. In fact, it was made mandatory for such jobs to be done only by a local professional. The Engineering, Architecture and surveying professionals were the biggest beneficiaries of this act. As good as that initial thought was, complacency over the years has caved in which has led to questions being put on the standard and quality of professional services within the whole value chain in the real estate industry, most especially commercial real estate.    Using the retail commercial segment as an example. In 2005, Mr. Tayo Amusan promoted arguably the first Grade A Mall  in the country. Being the first of its kind in Nigeria, most professionals in the value chain that participated in the development were either expatriates or companies that had some affiliation to a foreign company. In the developed nations and even countries in southern Africa, developments of this nature were common place so it was expected that such expertise would come from such places. The financiers would not even participate in such projects if the right expertise were not used. Come 2018 and we have about 20 of such Grade A malls with a total GLA of 318,208sqm. It is my expectation that over the years, there would have been a concerted effort by professional organisations in the built environment to put in place skills transfer initiatives where the local professionals are able to gain experience and knowledge in the delivery and service provision of such real estate asset classes. In the value chain of any commercial development, you have a series of professionals that are usually involved from inception to completion of such developments-Architects, Engineers.builders, valuers, project managers, facility managers, accountants, lawyers, Quantity surveyors etc. Majority of the professionals working in these organisations are indigenous and have been able to gain useful experience and knowledge in their various disciplines. Why can’t the professional organisations identify these individuals and companies and form a synergy towards skills training and capacity development of the entire membership of the institutions/organisations. Instead, what I observe is a keen focus on regulation and enforcement of the local laws. Protectionism is what I call it. Read also:

  • Budgeting for Facilities Management (2)  

  • Kitchen Makeover: The Island
Let me be clear. This columnist is not proposing that the laws should be thrown out of the dustbin and foreign companies allowed to operate uninterrupted. The Government has done its part over the years to put laws to protect the indigenous professionals. The indigenous professional however has a duty to ensure that he is constantly equipped and updated to the modern trends and standards expected in the industry. In a recent visit of the society of Engineers to the Honourable Minister of Works,Power and Housing, Mr.  Babatunde Raji Fashola SAN, the minister was quoted as criticizing the professional leadership in the areas of quality and lacking capacity .In other forums, the minister has castigated almost all professionals in the built environment about the same issues - this includes my profession. As harsh as he might sound, how have the players in the built environment reacted to such comments from the supervising minister of the industry?
Why should the commercial real estate segment be accorded more attention by the professional organisations? Among all the asset classes in the real estate industry, commercial office and retail projects bring in the most amount of Foreign direct Investments into the country. This columnist is aware of investment funds running into millions of dollars targeting the commercial retail space. The major drivers are the Private Equity firms who still see Nigeria as a market that has the ability to generate the much-expected yields compared to all other countries. In 2016,a pension fund management company was able to raise $350million for investment in a portfolio of Investments in Nigeria, Zambia and Mozambique. This company has so far built some Grade A mall in the country, one of which gulped a whopping N31.5 Billion along the Lekki-Epe Corridor. In a recent chat with one of the biggest mall promoters in the country, I was informed that they would be ready to engage indigenous professionals in most aspects of their development once they are able to provide the quality and expertise expected. In their words, it’s cheaper to solicit the services of the indigenous professional than bringing in one from overseas. So, a lot of jobs are out there for the indigenous professionals in the built environment. What is therefore needed in my view is to push human capital development to the front burner so that professionals can exploit the great opportunities that lie in the sector. In the world today, there is a scramble for investors. In Nigeria, the need for such investment has never been much higher with the sudden downward spike in oil prices and the countries alarming infrastructure deficit. It is therefore not wise to underrate the influence such foreign companies can have in changing Government policies to suit their needs in whichever county they decide to invest. This article is meant to serve as a wakeup call to the leaders in the built environment. Real estate does not exist in a bubble. As capital allocation is not constrained, real estate as an investment asset class, must compare favourably with other classes of investment. For real estate to compare favourably, it must have a return on investment similar and comparable to other asset classes such as government bonds and company shares; and it must be priced appropriately with consideration given to relevant macro-economic indices in the given jurisdiction. In Nigeria, with inflation at c. 11% (and rising) as at August 2018, Monetary Policy Rate / Base Rate at 14%; Treasury Bills yield between 10% to 12.6%; FGN bonds yield between 12.8% and 14.69%; and Nigerian Government Eurobonds yielding 7% to 8%, it is exceedingly difficult (if not impossible) for real estate assets yielding between ‘say’ c. 5% and c. 10% to attract investment from retail or institutional investors especially given the alternative investment classes – primarily government securities. [The justification for investment in real estate (yielding between ‘say’ c. 5% and c. 10%) is capital growth, primarily through rent reviews / rent uplifts during the period of investment as opposed to yield compression. Capital growth would aid to give a total return (over the investment period) which could compare favourably with other investment asset classes.] Given the above yield differential, it seems to be the case that there exists a structural fault in real estate returns and pricing relative to macro-economic indices in Nigeria. To attempt to understand the issue of real estate pricing and, perhaps, the relative lack of institutional investment (other than regulatory limitations such as Regulation on Investment of Pension Fund Assets – April 2017) in Nigerian real estate as an asset class, one must consider the concepts of price, value and worth and view this triumvirate from a real estate perspective. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"] 

Price, Value and Worth

Price is the amount of money or the consideration that has to be paid to acquire a given product. As long as the amount of money paid for a product represents its value, price is also a measure of value. As said by Warren Buffet, “Price is what you pay; value is what you get.” It follows therefore that price should not be too dissimilar from value – certainly, one should be within a reasonable margin of the other. After all, a purchaser does not want to pay a price that far exceeds value nor would a seller want to receive a price far lower than value. Theoretically, market price is the amount at which one transacts on an asset while market value is the true underlying value of an asset. The difference between price and value is usually as a result of inefficient markets i.e. lack of information, or situations where prevailing market prices are not reflective of true underlying market value. For market price to equal market value, the market must be efficient from an information perspective and rational expectations must prevail. One could conclude that price would hardly equal value as markets are not efficient and rational. Read also:
  • The Best of 2018
  • FCMB Premium Banking
From a real estate perspective, open market value (OMV) or value, according to International Valuation Standards is “the estimated amount for which a property should exchange on the date of valuation between a willing buyer and a willing seller in an arm’s-length transaction after proper marketing wherein the parties had each acted knowledgeably, prudently, and without compulsion”. Open Market Value determination or property valuation based on yield implies that the value of an asset is the net annual income from the asset multiplied by the inverse of the yield (where yield is the annualised return from the asset expressed as a percentage). Therefore, an asset with a yield of ‘say’ 5% would have its net annual rental income multiplied by 20 while an asset with a yield of ‘say’ 9% would have its annual income multiplied by 11.11 to determine its open market value. As well as yield, property valuation is also based on comparable evidence from the market. In finance, the value of an asset could be considered to be the lump sum payment made (today) for the benefit of the future cash flow accruing from the asset. This is essentially the DCF method of valuation. Given that price is the amount that one transacts on an asset, and it can be established as a matter of fact from market evidence, it follows that price would be equal to value as described above once a transaction completes. This gives objectivity and acceptance to both price and value. Worth, whilst used, unfortunately, interchangeably with price and / or value, should not be mistaken for price or value. Worth is a subjective view of price or value; and it is the price or value to a particular entity or individual as opposed to the market. For example, an asset (‘say’ office premises) next to a manufacturing plant could be worth more to the owners of the manufacturing plant due to its proximity to the plant. The same asset would not be worth so much to any other tenant or potential owner. In this example, the worth to the owners of the manufacturing plant exceeds the value of the asset in the market. Similarly, due to the legal, planning and construction challenges faced by a residential developer, residential units developed on a (perhaps inherited) parcel of land could be considered to be worth a lot more than a willing buyer would pay. The worth ascribed to the asset should not be determined to be the value of the asset. With price, value and worth broadly understood, consideration should be given to capital and cost of capital used to acquire real estate.

Cost of Capital

All capital, debt or equity, has a cost, with debt generally considered cheaper than equity. In any (investment) market, debt (and cost of debt) is a vital element, which serves to, inter alia, improve return on (equity) investment. In broad terms, the start point for the cost of debt is to determine the risk-free rate, which is the rate at which sovereign entities i.e. governments borrow, then add a risk premium for borrower risk and investment risk. In Nigeria, the Nigerian Naira risk-free rate would be the yield on Treasury Bills (10% to 12.6%), or for long term borrowing, the yield on 5-year or 10-year bonds (12.8% to 14.69%) whilst the United States Dollar risk-free rate would be Nigerian Government Eurobonds (7% to 8%). Borrower risk and investment risk could be upwards of 2% depending on a host of considerations. Assuming a total (borrower and investment) risk premium of c. 2% or 3%, then the cost of long term debt should be no less than c. 15% or 16% in Nigerian Naira and c. 9% or 10% in United States Dollar. Considering central government securities (treasury bills, bonds) are considered risk-free and other investment asset classes are priced (with a risk premium) relative to the risk-free rate, then no asset class should be priced or yield a (total) return lower than the risk-free rate……..unless the investment is seen and accepted to be more secure or less risky than sovereign / government securities. Real estate investment is certainly not considered to be more secure / less risky than government securities even with a very good quality tenant in occupation on a long lease. In addition, to the extent that debt (priced as explained above) is utilised in the acquisition of real estate investment, then the real estate investment must have total return in excess of the cost of debt i.e. a yield in excess of c. 15% or 16% in Nigerian Naira and in excess of c. 9% or 10% in United States Dollars to service the debt; and capital growth to compensate for the risk of investment. Otherwise, the investment total return would not suffice to service the interest on the debt never mind amortise the debt and compensate investor. Note: It is possible, and there could be significant value in buying an asset at an initial yield lower than the cost of debt if the purchaser believes that a reversionary yield in excess of the initial yield can be achieved. The reason for this is likely to be that a rent review is imminent or the asset has high vacancy. The value in a transaction of this nature would be the purchaser’s ability to maximise annual rent at rent review, or minimise vacancy within the asset in the shortest possible time or both. In any event, the purchaser’s key initial objective would be to achieve reversionary yield (in excess of cost of debt) as soon as practically possible.

Back to Value

Only when real estate yields (initial and reversionary) are in the range suggested above would real estate as an investment asset class be attractive to retail and institutional investors when compared against other investment asset classes. When considered from this perspective, the logical conclusion is that real estate assets, with initial yields of c. 5% to c. 9% (i.e. multiples of c. 11 to 20) on Nigerian Naira net annual income, are significantly over-valued especially in the absence of real capital growth and reversionary yield to support an attractive total return (which is not based on yield compression). With real estate yields as explained and determined above, multiples on Nigerian Naira net annual income from real estate should be in the range of 6.90 (c. 14.5% yield) to 6.25 (16% yield) in the absence of real capital growth to derive a total return in excess of cost of debt. The yield could reduce slightly in a market with a deep tenant pool (therefore low vacancy rates) and stable currency. For completeness, real capital growth is based, largely, on increases in rental income over and above prevailing inflation during the hold period of the investment. An asset bought and sold at the same yield but with the benefit of rental income growth over and above prevailing inflation would have the benefit of capital growth and would be likely to derive a positive total return. The above suggests that real estate asset with a net income of ‘say’ NGN 5 million per annum currently valued and priced at c. NGN 83.33 million based on a yield of 6% is significantly over-valued and should, perhaps, be more appropriately valued and priced at c. NGN 35.5 million based on a yield of 14.5% especially if a rent review is not imminent and real capital growth is not certain. Over-valuation is one of the reasons real estate financiers are often asked by agnostic investors: ‘why invest in real estate for a yield of x% (without certainty of real capital growth) when an investment in government securities can be made for a yield of 1.5x% or 2x%? Whilst it could be argued that any difference between price and value of an asset is down to demand and supply and market inefficiency, price, we know, would equal value at transaction completion. The issue of worth, and trying to equate worth to value or price, should not occur nor should it be permitted in any market. For prudent and competent real estate pricing, consideration should be given to whether an investor / a purchaser would be willing to acquire an asset that yields a total return that is far less than the cost of capital and if, indeed, the cost of capital has been considered, determined and understood. Should an investor or purchaser be willing to accept a total return less than cost of capital, then, it seems value creation is not the objective of investment and, perhaps, the source of the capital ought to be questioned. In order to create value within the real estate industry in Nigeria, it is incumbent on all participants in the sector to consider international best practices in real estate asset valuation and pricing and ensure that overvaluation / unjustifiable pricing (based on worth) is avoided. Landlords need to keep their properties in shape, not only in order to satisfy their tenants but also in order to avoid potentially expensive disasters. But it can be difficult to know where to start. So this article aims to help point out a few of the things a London Landlord needs to know. It’s important to note that in the U.K, the responsibility of a tenant having an enjoyable stay in a property rests on the landlord. So, as a result of this, there are certain statutory requirements of a landlord. These statutory requirements include but aren’t limited to appliances and structural wear and tear. One of the greatest and most critical appliance cost come in the boiler. A white box, usually little bigger than a mini fridge, but all so important. Boilers are crucial both for heating and hot water and as such is top of the most critical requirements of tenants. Repairs to boilers must happen within a reasonable time frame and can’t be simply at the whim of the landlord. The expected time envelope of response for boiler related issues typically 24 - 48 hours. This is especially daunting during the winter season where the resultant cold - with sub-zero temperatures - leads to the cost of replacing a boiler becoming astronomical. Depending on the rent the property attracts, this can take out the equivalent of a year's rental margin - profit made on the rent - or the entire rent even. Annual gas safety checks are also required on the boilers. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Read also: 

  • Budgeting for Facilities Management (2)  

  • Is Ibeju Lekki Nigeria’s most promising real estate location?

Landlords also have to keep well abreast of changes in regulation, health, and safety. With regards to Fires and flammable items, the landlord needs to ensure that the furniture in the property is generally fire resistant and that Fire alarms are installed in the property and working. The criticality of such things horrendously observed in the Grenfell disaster, where a fire from a faulty unit caused untold damage to lives and property building-wide. This is thus particularly important for those who own multiple units in a house or even a flat in a block. From 1st of October 2015, it became compulsory to have smoke alarms on every storey of a property. For flats or houses in single family occupation, all properties must now have a long-life or mains-powered smoke alarm system throughout, along with a carbon monoxide alarm in all high-risk rooms. The requirements are more demanding for HMOs (House of Multiple Occupancy). These alarms must be checked at the start of each tenancy and the fine for going afoul of this can go up to £5,000 Apart from the danger, the fire poses to the occupant of the building. The property itself could suffer significant damage and not having it may impact the insurance claim. There is also a similar requirement for Carbon Dioxide alarms, however, this wouldn’t apply to most new build properties. You should also conduct a fire risk assessment for each of your properties. Best practice dictates that you should keep a written copy of this assessment for future reference. With most of the above mentioned, most of your responsibilities are restricted to the apartment, but if its a freehold house, the responsibility might include communal areas and public areas as well. As well as proper checks at the beginning and end of a tenancy, you should arrange to make inspections of the property at regular intervals. By keeping an eye on problems as they arise, you can make sure you head them off quickly. Before a new tenant arrives, make sure that you provide them with an information pack that sets out the basic things they should do in order to prevent damage to the property. For example, make sure that they know to air the property regularly and ensure that it is kept properly heated in colder months in order to minimize mold. Many tenants, especially those who have recently begun renting, are not aware of the simple things they need to do in order to keep the property running, but you can avoid problems by making sure that you educate them from the outset. Don’t ignore problems – they will only get worse. If a tenant reports a fault, or if you notice one during an inspection, make sure that you fix it immediately. A simple problem, if left unattended to, can quickly grow into a potentially expensive disaster. Make sure that you pay particular attention to the property during the winter months, as this is the time during which many of the most damaging problems can arise. Its the landlord's responsibility to ensure that they are applying the relevant legislation correctly. Ignorance of legislation doesn’t offer sufficient protection. We feel that these are some of the advantages of using a managing agent, it’s their duty and responsibilities to always keep an eye on relevant legislation and to ensure all your properties are compliant. You might be able to save some money by going the DIY route, but if you hire an agent to do it for you, you could save your own valuable time, especially as an international landlord. PROPERTY INVESTMENT Follow the money: A real estate investment guide for Landlords in 2019 Describing the Ikoyi property as a house would be pushing the definition of ‘house’. The roof had caved in, the wooden stairs rotted away, kitchen was non-existent, the garden was a jungle and there were no functional windows. “But it is structurally sound” was the Landlord’s cheerful response as he placed an offer of $175,000 per annum rent, payable five years in advance to the potential tenants. The representatives of the tenant - a bank, made a counter offer. They wanted a lease for 15 years at the same rent. Eventually, it was agreed that a five-year advance of the rent ($175,000 per annum) would be paid with rent revision clauses for the next ten years. This fairy tale, happily ever after story took place in 1996. Today, the Landlord is offering the property albeit now well renovated, for N20m but can ‘come down to N15m’. Payment terms include this clause: 1 year rent is acceptable. This means that using the exchange rate of N360 - $1, the landlord is effectively ready to accept $41,666 rent for the property, compared to $175,000, twenty-three years ago. Why this turn of events? Those negotiating for the bank (now defunct) in 1996, knew that, as they were discussing with the Landlord, he was also fielding comparative offers from multi-national companies, Embassies, International Oil Companies (IOCs) and local financial institutions. This level of demand meant that the landlord could charge a premium over the going rates, even for a decrepit building. An Ikoyi residential address was considered essential for the Managing Director of the bank to compete with his peers in the financial sector. But by 2018, the situation had changed drastically. Demand for property in the high-end locations has weakened significantly. The banking reforms had pruned the number of the banks, oil prices meant that the IOCs had cut back on staff and therefore housing, while Embassies had relocated to Abuja over the period. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  So while it is true that there is an oversupply of properties in the high-end markets heightening competition, the drying up of demand is also a major factor landlords have to consider in current times.   This is not only the case in the residential property segment. In its 2019 Nigeria Real Estate Market Outlook, Northcourt, a real estate investment solutions company explained that in the shopping malls, “Grade A retail rents are now paid in local currency as opposed to the erstwhile favourite – the US Dollar and payable monthly in some instances (as opposed to annually/multi-year).” What started as incentives occasioned by the 2017 recession is now the norm. In its OFFICE MARKET  VIEWPOINT  Q3: 2018, Broll observed  ‘Market practices that have become the norm (rent free periods, tenant improvement allowances, extended BO periods, etc.) have persisted amongst prime-grade landlords. In a bid to drive occupancy levels, competitive leasing terms which are favourable to tenants were noted in Q3:2018. The median average asking rent for A-grade offices in Ikoyi has remained constant at US$750/m2/annum in Q3:2018. In the Victoria Island commercial node, the median average asking rent has also remained fairly constant at US$650/m2/annum.  Vacancy rates in A-grade buildings are currently around 76% and 56% in Ikoyi and Victoria Island respectively.’ The point must however be made that demand has not dried up completely. Indeed, in some real estate segments like co-working spaces, demand is rising. In 2019, the landlord must work out where the demand is and position their offerings appropriately. Read also:

  • Landlord Maintenance Tips

Should the property be re-configured? A landlord of a 5 bedroom semi detached house in Lekki Phase 1 had been looking for a tenant for his property for over two years. Based on the comment of his 30 year old niece that she would gladly take the property if she had two people to share it with, he reconfigured the property into two nos 2 bedroom flats and the servants quarters into a chalet. He was able to let the flats for N2m each and the chalet for N1.2m bringing his total rent to N5.2m. This was compared to the N4m he was prepared to take for the entire property let as a whole. It is this type of space reconfiguration that has been applied to commercial office blocks in the form of Collaborative work-spaces (co- working) According to Wikipedia, Coworking involves a shared workplace, often an office, and independent activity. Unlike in a typical office, those coworking are usually not employed by the same organization. So instead of landlords of commercial office blocks, looking for one or a small number of  corporates to take up long term leases of  spaces in their property, they have reconfigured the property to take a larger number of small businesses. This is where the demand is. According to a report by the Brol Property Group – Co-working: Trends and  outlook in the Lagos Office market,  this is a fast growing segment of the market. “In Lagos, we see the global co-working trend through a varied number of local service providers operating in the market. With over 50 local co-working operators, Regus is the only international brand operating under a direct franchise model in the market. Nigeria has a strong entrepreneurial culture as cataloged in the Global Start-up Ecosystem 2017 Report, which valued the Lagos startup ecosystem the highest in Africa with a growth index of 6.6. As these start-ups continue to spring up, we see a stronger demand for co-working real estate solutions. “ Should the use be changed? Lagos is evolving rapidly and the character of many neighbourhoods can change. It appears overnight but astute watchers of a location can see the trend well before it becomes the norm. For instance, for over eight years, Castles Lifestyle has been reporting on the commercialization of Lekki Phase 1. The precedent was clear: this was how Victoria Island moved from being primarily residential to overwhelmingly commercial. The reason for the movement of corporates to Lekki Phase 1 is obvious: it is about 40 – 50% cheaper than renting office space, and with the Lekki Link Bridge, it is also very assessable. Forward-looking landlords have already converted their properties on the ‘high streets’ of Fola Osibo, Admiralty Way, Admiralty Road etc to shopping malls. Others are joining in but they have missed the first wave and will have to contend with fierce competition. Owners of shopping malls are also changing their models to focus on revenue generating areas like parking food courts, play areas and cinemas. Facility management: service or self-service? A new lexicon has entered the real estate dictionary – ‘self-service. It refers to a multi-tenanted property where the landlord does not provide all or any facility management services. A landlord of a townhouse mini-estate in Oniru found to his chagrin that it was until he removed the generator as part of the services to be charged for that he was able to let the apartments fully. His tenants, mainly families, had their own generators and inverters and were not ready to pay the service charge for alternative power generation.  In some other apartment blocks, even in highbrow Ikoyi, tenants have negotiated with the landlords to limit the alternative power supply to reduce the Service Charge. Landlords have to judge the appetite of the prospective tenants for top facility services – if the tenants don’t want them or are not prepared to pay for them, then those services are a turn off and not an attraction. We have seen a number of adverts styling properties as ‘Self Service’ to indicate that there is a demand for such properties. The Short-lets/Air bnb  model. By now the trend is becoming clear. If your property cannot be let in the conventional fashion, then consider other altering the offering to attract another type of tenant. One of these options is the short let model. Again, this depends on the location, style and layout of the property and the amount of work the Landlord is prepared to do make this model a success.  However, with the right property, plugging into the Air bnb network means that most of the work has been done for the landlord. Void periods is a recent phenomenon brought about by changes in the real estate landscape. The conventional tenants have disappeared. To get their properties yielding a fair return, landlords have to ‘follow the money’. Who has rent money to spend and what do they want to spend it on? It then lies on the landlord to ensure their properties meet the criteria of these prospective tenants. If not, their money will go to another property. [/read]

The flower kitchen pendant lamps provide decor and ambient lighting. REQUEST FOR EXPRESSION OF INTEREST FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF A RESIDENTIAL GATED COMMUNITY IN OSOGBO, STATE OF OSUN

THE STATE GOVERNMENT OF OSUN
MINISTRY OF LANDS AND PHYSICAL PLANNING

(1) BACKGROUND
Housing is a crucial basic need of every human being and it is fundamental to the welfare, survival and health of man. According to UN-Habitat (2019), roughly one billion people or 1/3rd of the world’s urban population live in slum. Housing resources, lack of access to affordable land, lack of access to mortgage finance at affordable interest rate, high cost of building materials due to high custom and excise duties, inadequate local manufacturers etc.
Consequent upon this, the State Government in her bid to ensure provision of adequate housing for her citizenry intends to provide residential gated community at former St Mark’s premises, Ayetoro Area, Osogbo.


(2) THE OPPORTUNITY
The State Government of Osun is calling for Expression of Interest (EOI) from competent private sector developers for development of a residential gated community in Osogbo.


(3) PROJECT BRIEF
The overall scope of this project is to develop a residential gated community on an area of land measuring 8.570 Hectares in Osogbo. The State Government of Osun has prepared prototype design of the residential gated community which will be made available to successful applicants.
The community will comprise the following;
• 152 units Terrace Houses (Four Bedroom Terraces+Maid’s room)
• 120 units apartment blocks 20 blocks (6 Nos 3 bedroom flats per block)
• Ancillary buildings consisting
(a) Shops/Offices – 2900sqm
(b) Elementary School – 1730sqm
(c) Gate House
Management of the community will be undertaken in line with the best practices and will be guided by overall housing policy of the State Government of Osun.


(4) REQUIREMENTS FOR APPLICATION
The request for expression of interest is open to individuals, registered groups and enterprises registered in Nigeria that have demonstrable capacity to undertake the development.

According to FIABCI-Nigeria President, Mr Adeniji Adele, the desperate need for ease of engaging in business activities in the country and its economy is the reason behind selection of theme ‘Ease of Doing Real Estate Business’ for the program. The event will be chaired by the Dr. Oba Otudeko CFR (Chairman, Honeywell Group), while Prince Gbolahan Lawal (Honorable Commissioner for Housing Lagos State) will the special guest of honor. Modern design ideas for the bedroom. It is standard for any modern bedroom in Nigeria to either have built in wardrobes or walk in closets. The idea is to remove the awkwardness of such a large piece of furniture and give the room a more streamlined look. Can the same idea be applied to the other large piece of furniture in the room – the bed? In the Majestic Mountain Charme Hotel in Italy, architectural studio CaberlonCaroppi has designed the rooms with built-in headboards. They have done this by building a upholstered velvet headboard to be flush with the wood wall that surrounds it. Go idea or bad? Send your feedback to enquiries@castlesweekly.com How do you get enough light for your bedside reading? A lamp is adequate but hardly makes a statement. The low pendant lights in these designs bring a lot of ‘pizzazz’ to the bedrooms A feature wall and planters on the wall give this bedroom a distinctive look. Create a reading spot by adding a comfortable chair, or try a wall mounted console as a desk.

The marathon is set to hold on Saturday 2nd of February 2019 by 6:30am

INVITATION FOR PRE-QUALIFICATION OF CONTRACTORS FOR COMPREHENSIVE FACILITIES MANAGEMENT OF NCDMB HQ BUILDING BY NIGERIAN CONTENT DEVELOPMENT AND MONITORING BOARD NCDMB CORPORATE HEADQUARTERS, GLASS HOUSE, ISAAC BORO EXPRESSWAY, OPOLO, PMB 10, YENAGOA BAYELSA STATE INVITATION FOR PRE-QUALIFICATION OF CONTRACTORS FOR COMPREHENSIVE FACILITIES MANAGEMENT OF NCDMB HQ BUILDING The Nigerian Content Development and Monitoring Board (NCDMB) intends to pre-qualify contractors for Comprehensive Facilities Management of NCDMB Headquarters (HQ) Building and Ancillary Facilities in Yenagoa which consist of a 17-floor main offices Building (32,000sqm), a 1,000-seater conference Hall (8,00sqm) and a 4-floor multi-level car park (19,000sqm). It also includes Ancillary Buildings such as a Generator house, a Sewage Treatment Plant, a Water Treatment Plant, etc. and External works (i.e. External Car Park, Roads, Drainage, Landscaping, External ower Generation, fence, etc.) The Board has adopted the Integrated Facility Management strategy for management of these facilities. Accordingly, NCDMB invites reputable, competent and experienced Facilities Management (FM) service companies for the prequalification exercise. SCOPE OF WORK The scope of works of the FM Contractor shall include but not be limited to the following: (a)   Service maintenance and repair of heat and ventilation Systems, Electrical and plumbing Services, Lifts and Escalators (b)  Building maintenance and repair of the building fabric, decorations, fixtures and fittings ( c)  Maintenance and repairs of external facilities (drain clearance, hard landscaping, soft landscaping/horticulture, fence) inclusive of utilities, cleaning and security. (d)  Furniture& Equipment maintenance and repair or replacement (e)  Materials procurement and logistics (f)  General cleaning services such as cleaning of windows, cladding, internal areas, pest control, waste disposal, operation maintenance of cleaning cradle. (g)  Security (Reception, guarding, surveillance and maintenance of security system), (h)  ICT, BMS, Cable management, CAD, CAFM CMMS, CPMS, access control management (i)   Utilities supplies (electricity, gas, fuel) (j)   Water and waste/sewerage management (k)   Energy conservation and management (l)    Catering& Hospitality services (m)  Front desk, Help desk and Reception services. (n)    Fitness Center management (o)     Risk, Environmental, Health, Safety Management, including fire drills (p)      Space management i.e. office space and commercial spaces (convenience, shops, banks, restaurants, conference building) (q)     Rent Management (r)      Disaster Recover, Crisis Management [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  PRE-QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENT Interested firms should submit the following pre-qualification documentation detailing the company’s capabilities and financial status. (A) General Company Profile (i)  Evidence of company registration with the Corporate Affairs Commission (CAC) and support documents (C02 & C07) showing the equity structure of the company is at least 51% owned by a Nigeria(s), Memo and Articles, and photo ID of company Promoters (ii)  Evidenced of current three (3) years tax clearance Certificate valid till December 31, 2018. (iii)  Evidenced of current Pension Compliance Certificate valid date December 31, 2018. (iv)  Evidence of current industrial Training fund compliance Certificate valid till December 31, 2018. (v)  Evidence of current Nigerian social insurance Trust Fund (NSITF) compliance Certificate valid till December 31, 2018. (vi) Interim Registration Report (IRR) as an evidence of registration on the National Database of Contractors/Consultants and Service Providers issued by BPP. (vii)  Relevant DPR permit. (viii) A Sworn affidavit declaring the Bidder Free of pecuniary interest, falsification and prior conviction of any of their directors and pecuniary interests in NCDMB and certifying that all information submitted in the bid are correct in all particulars. (ix)  Evidence of Registration on the NOGICJQS Portal –http:/portal.nogicjqs.com (B) Technical Capacity and Capability (x)  Evidence of individual and/or company accreditations, certifications and professional memberships pertinent to this assignment (i.e. registration with COREN, NIESN, IFMA). (xi) Detailed Company Profile including Organizational Structure, key professional staff with good knowledge base in FM and their qualifications. (xii) Verifiable evidence of having successfully executed similar works in the past five (5) years. This should include the project title and brief description of contract award, duration of contract award, type of contract ( fixed lump sum, reimbursable, etc.), copies of completion certificates and the name, email address and phone numbers of referees in client’s company of at least three (3) referenced project. (xiii). For a joint Venture or Partnership, the previous experiences being claimed must include those executed by the joint Venture or the partnership. (xiv)  List of relevant equipment owned and/or to be sourced by the company. (xv)   Company’s CASHES and QAQC policy. Includes copies of any certifications associated with the Quality program. Demonstrate ability to handle host community issues and details of safety records for accidents, injuries, damages for the past three (3) years etc. Lost timed incidence, downtime, etc. (xvi) Evidence that the Annual Turnover of the company is not less than Five Billion Naira (N5 Billion) and a corresponding Tax clearance certificate. Organizational structure indicating Nigerian Professionals, skilled and unskilled personnel to be engaged on this project. The Estate Agent and the panties controversy I have been managing properties for over twenty years and I can say with some confidence that I have seen all there is to see in managing tenants. But this issue of yahoo boys using panties to ‘determine the destiny’ of a woman is tasking my skills, experience and patience! One of the blocks of flats I manage is on 4 floors in Oniru Estate in Lagos. There are two flats on each floor making it a total of 8 flats. 6 of the flats are rented by families and the two top most flats are rented by single professional women. The tenants usually get along, although they are not close and I never had issues with them. The rents and service charge gets paid on time and communal facilities like the clothes line, dustbins etc  are used with mutual respect. All this was going on smoothly, until last week. It all started when I got a call from the Landlord. He had received an anonymous tip that clothes were being spread on the veranda of some of the flats. This was against the rules and he wanted me to check. Later that day, I went to the property and was amazed to see that all the flats had clothes spread on the balconies. All except one – the flat of the Chukwus. I immediately came to the conclusion that, this was where the anonymous tip had come from. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    As it was against the rules and was expressly stated in the Tenancy Agreements, I immediately wrote to all the tenants, stating that the practice should be discontinued. The response to the email was immediate.  If they could not spread their clothes on the balconies of their flats, they would move at the end of their lease. The two professional women on the top flats actually threatened to move immediately.   Read also:
  • Invitation For Bids by Federal University Lokoja
  • Get The Look: Gardens
  What could be the cause of all this? I asked the security man, as these people usually know all the goings on in a compound. Turns out that, as a security measure for ‘protecting their destinies’, the women in the compound had started spreading their underwear on the balconies. What about the Chukwus? Turns out that Mrs Chukwu has a washing machine and dryer installed for this purpose. Where could the tip have come from? Mrs. Chukwu. She was threatened by the fact that her husband will be seeing such exotic panties and undergarments and make him start having ideas about the other women in the compound. What can I do about this situation? The Landlord is adamant that clothes should not be spread on balconies but if the tenants  go it will be very difficult to get new tenants. That means my Management fees will not be paid for a while. 2019 has not taken off on a good note!           [/read]

PROPERTY INVESTMENT Don’t make your building project a white elephant Building a house in Nigeria is such an emotional affair that reason and logic flies out of the window. Of course, everyone wants the best but if you don’t want to end up with a half finished building without knowing how to complete it, then a practical approach is needed. The first thing to determine before briefing your architect is to assess how long you expect the project to take and how much you can raise during that period. It is this amount that you can raise (including borrowing) that should guide your next decisions. If the amount you can raise is too small, then extend the period of construction by dividing the project into phases. For example, phase 1 could be foundation, Phase 2 for ground floor block-work up to decking and so on. During the project design briefing, go to town with your ‘wish list’ but also add the amount you can raise. The two major cost models relative to the project design are; Cost to design (CTD) and Design to Cost (DTC). Cost to design simply means putting up a design first and then estimating the total construction cost from the design usually without tying it to any budget while Design to cost entails stating your budget for the project first, then ensuring that the project is designed to be completed within that budget. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  Engr. Osaz’ ENOBAKHARE explains the concept:  For instance using the recommended DTC model, a project owner can approach a designer/contractor with say 4 Million Naira to construct a simple bungalow and achieve his/her desires within it in the following simple steps;
  • First, you discuss the development idea/concept with the designer/contractor,
  • Thereafter you reveal your initial budget, say 3.5 Million Naira and retain the balance,
  • Then request that the designer/contractor provide two or three design options that can be achieved within your budget and based on your specifications (e.g. It should consist of 3 beds -all rooms en-suite, French-style windows, an ante-room, slanting height, a court yard etc). However it is strongly recommended that you employ the service of a designer/contractor with good knowledge of both design, estimation and construction from the start as it is in common knowledge that most independent designers/architects aren’t good estimators or alternatively you co-engage a Quantity Surveyor to achieve your cost goal (You will have to pay for this service say around 5% of the total project cost).
  • Once the preliminary site investigation is completed and the building designs and cost estimates are ready, you then choose the most appealing design. Do not hesitate to pre-inform the estimator/contractor to simplify the cost estimates by breaking it into two main sections one showing the Material cost/schedule and the other, the labour cost/schedule (which will include the contractor’s profit so that it can be negotiated separately). You have to study the estimates carefully and compare for consistency with the design.
  • Because some features would have been deliberately excluded in the design in order to make it fit into the cost plan, you may have to add some much desired features (like special finishes, fittings and fixtures, etc) within your initial retention budget (in this case, the 500,000 NGN left). But don’t use all of it; keep a fraction for contingencies, and
  • You are good to go.
  Read also:
  • Tenant tales
  • Tenders! Supply of Goods and Services by FCT Admin
  However in the Cost-to-Design model, the project owner/landlord is highly disadvantaged in that the designer/contractor may come up with fabulous designs that may be far beyond your budget because there have been little or no consideration of the cost implication of the design at the initial stage.  This is the most common case in practice. When this happens, subsequently the project owner lured to this expensive design begins to run helter-skelter to source for additional funds to complete the project and this is not usually a funny experience. Think carefully and make the right choice of cost model to adopt for your next building project.           [/read]

PROPERTY INVESTMENT

The Facility Management advantage Over 80% of tenants who moved out of one luxury flat into another flat did so because of what they considered ‘below par’ facility management. This finding was the result of an informal poll of 45 respondents, which was carried out by Castles Lifestyle in January 2019.  The higher the rent and service charge, the more exacting the expectations of the respondents the result of the poll seems to suggest.  So a Facility Manager who is running the services of the property efficiently but does not respond to enquiries promptly may be considered as ‘below par’. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]   The competition in the luxury flat rental market has become very fierce in recent times as more units are placed in the market while the pool of prospective tenants has been shrinking. Landlords have reacted by cutting down rents and accepting Naira rents as opposed to dollars. They have also reacted by providing even more recreational facilities – squash & tennis courts etc to attract tenants. But the results of the poll show that they must also keep a very close eye on he facility management side.  After rental amount, facility management comes a close second on the wish-list of tenants in this segment. They are very interested in how this service is provided and conduct independent research to confirm what the agents are telling them during the search. The Service Charge is not considered independent of rent – the present day tenants view both as their total outlay on the property and this influences their decision.  The result is, in some apartments, the service charge is as high as 60% of the rent because the tenants demand a high standard of facility management while maintaining a fixed amount of what they want to pay. So rental income suffers as the Landlord is forced to back down or continue to face a void period. The pressure then shifts to the Facility Manager as tenants adopt a ‘take no prisoner’ approach to standard of services received. Because Tenants now pay yearly instead of being  locked into contracts for two years or more, they are more mobile and increasing vote with their feet by moving apartments at the end of the term.   [caption id="attachment_48336" align="alignnone" width="596"] Angry tenants are more likely to move due to poor facility management[/caption]   Read also:
  • Kings Tower, Ikoyi
  • 2 Bedroom Apartment – Design Scheme 1
  Self-Service The impact of facility management charges has also been felt in the upper middle class locations of Lekki Phase 1 and Oniru. Here Landlords faced with tenants’ resistance to paying facility management fees have resorted to limited services tagged ‘self-service’. Here expensive services like 24/7 power are scrapped with the tenants, even those in multi-tenanted apartments’ making provision for their own power. “It’s not a tidy arrangement”, Castles Lifestyle was told by an agent running an apartment block on those terms “but we find that if we add power into the service  charge mix, the value goes up significantly and a fair number of tenants renting in these locations are not prepared to meet that cost. They already have their own generators and inverters and want to run these according to their own pockets and not a communally defined arrangement. It is not very tidy but we have to move according to market sentiment.”   Indeed, landlords and property investors have to be more responsive in their approach to property management as the real estate market in these segments is more of a buyers market.   [/read]

TENANTS TALES Can Blood Speak? When Bayo got into a studio apartment (a glorified boys quarters actually) in a high class estate in Ikoyi, he thought he had hit the jackpot. At N300, 000 per annum, he knew from Castles Lifestyle that the rent in that location was easily over a million Naira. The deal made him throw caution to the wind: he did not even tell his Pastor to pray about it, which was his custom when making serious decisions. Even the altercation between the agent and one of the occupants during the inspection did not faze him. The man had asked the agent why “leading the sheep to the slaughter.” His major concern was the economics of getting the studio flat. First, the flat was incredibly cheap even cheaper than the one he was renting in Egbeda. Another plus was the high calibre tenants he would be mingling with. He was sure that the connections would stand him in good stead in the future. The icing on the cake was the savings he would make in transport fare to his office in Victoria Island. He moved his wedding plans by several months just thinking about the situation. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]   However, the first night he spent in his dream apartment was not a good dream. He had a horrible nightmare. He woke up that morning drenched in sweat but could not remember what the dream was all about. His only recollection was a woman’s voice, repeatedly saying “why nah? Why nah? Why nah?” He put it out of his mind and decided that that he will make conscious effort to meet his top class neighbours as they set out for work. His greeting however evoked funny stares, which he put down to snobbish behaviour. Read also:
  • The Facility Management Advantage
  • Get The Look: Gardens
  “Why nah? Why nah? why nah?” the haunting voice was his constant companion all night. He decided that he would invite his Pastor to pray with him in the place. The next morning, he was accosted by a neighbour who narrated the story that scared him. Apparently a young girl who had lived in that flat was murdered 3 years ago. The neighbours found the heart of the young lady hacked into pieces in flat. It was suspected that her boyfriend was responsible for the murder but was never proven. Before Bayo packed into the flat about 3 men that rented the place had to quit. Each with the same complaint of the sound at night. Another tenant who heard the tail end of the conversation laughed it off. He said that there was a tree beside the apartment which gave that kind of sound when the wind blew through its leaves. Bayo was not even listening to what the man said – he had just realised that he was in a discussion with two General Managers of new generation banks! By now both men had realised it was getting late and left with a promise to call Bayo that night when they returned. Bayo was in seventh heaven as he left to his office. He was already making top connections! But what about this ghost business? He called his Pastor to pray there with him that night. If the Man of God did not pick up any signals, all was well and the explanation of the second tenant was probably correct. That night, the pastor came, prayed and anointed the flat. The pastor prophesied that he would ‘prosper’ in this place. Bayo shook off the suspicion that his Pastor was more interested in the connections he too could make from the other neighbours rather than spiritual warfare. That night, the sound (blood speaking?) came again. Was this a warning or was there a scientific explanation for this? Should Bayo pack out, lose his rent and give up all the advantages of Ikoyi life? Email  enquiries@castlesweekly.com for any advice you have for Bayo   [caption id="attachment_48340" align="alignnone" width="690"] Bayo’s flat was the scene of a brutal murder. FACILITY MANAGEMENT ‘Light’ at the end of the tunnel? The Holy Grail for landlords and facility managers in the luxury property segment in Nigeria is achieving 24/7 power for their properties in an economically sustainable manner with a low carbon footprint. The Green House in Guzape, Abuja ticks all these boxes. How did the developers achieve this? The Green House is a ‘mini estate’ of 10 units of semi-detached houses in the Guzape District of Abuja. There is nothing in its exterior to suggest that it is different from any of the other developments around it. But it is extremely different from all other buildings in Nigeria.  The residents have been enjoying continuous power supply since May 2015…..without connection to the grid or generators! The firm responsible for this ‘miracle’ is Nigeria-based backup and renewable energy firm, Blue Camel Energy Ltd. To be able to achieve this, they had to take over the design, construction and overall maintenance of the apartment block. The design and construction was driven by the need to minimize the energy consumption of the residents. The building’s layout is such as to foster adequate ventilation to flow through each unit, reducing the need to run the air conditioning (AC) units. The roof is made of concrete slabs, which minimizes heat penetration into the building. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"] To ensure that the residents use energy efficiently, each apartment comes semi-furnished with eco-friendly refrigeration units,  air conditioners and television sets that are power efficient. The external perimeter, garden and security lighting systems  run independently.  The fridges and freezers are connected to a timer to maximise energy savings, running for an average of 10 hours a day. The AC units do not have starting current or surge current and they consume approximately 30% less energy than a regular AC system. The installed water tank system has the capacity to supply 57,000 litres of water, while 2,250 litres is the solar thermal capacity at any one time. Read also:
  • Narrow is the way…..
  • 2 Bedroom Apartment – Design Scheme 1
  Energy is provided by 10 wind turbines and 148 solar panels – 15kW of wind and 45kW of solar photovoltaic (PV) – enabling the development to run completely off renewable power. 12 units of 200Ah AGM deep cycle batteries back up every sub-unit within the property. Blue Camel undertook detailed calculations on the power use of each apartment before installing the system. For instance it worked out that using only LED Bulbs, if all the light points is an apartment were switched on less than 1,000W of energy will be consumed. [caption id="attachment_48354" align="alignnone" width="670"] Blue camel’s flagship project at Guzape, Abuja[/caption] Total cost of the renewable energy setup approximately N30 million. When the cost of battery replacement is factored in as well as project maintenance costs, Blue Camel has worked out that each apartment will spend about N970.00/day (N29,000 monthly) on this system over the next 10 years. That is access to clean and uninterrupted power. After this initial period, it is virtually free energy for the next 15 years of the solar panels’ lifespan.
