Long Term Tenants - Good or Bad. Are Long term tenants good or bad? This is an often under thought question but is a fundamental consideration in your property investment strategy. Your ultimate aim as an investor is to maximize the returns on your capital, be it by the rental yield from the property, or the capital appreciation that can be gotten by a rise in prices. As such you want to pay attention to things that affect either of those factors before and during your ownership of your property asset. A big headache for Landlords besides problem tenants, which we’ll cover in a separate article, is void periods. It is not the ideal place to be for a Landlord to have a unit that isn’t generating any income or sitting fallow, especially if there is a mortgage on the property, or the landlord is at a point of their career or business life, where it is harder to cover any void periods out of their active income. With this backdrop in mind, it is favored to get a Long term tenant, either by happenstance i.e frequent renewals or by contract from the onset. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"] Typically, there are two ways you get a Long term tenant, as mentioned above, either from someone who extends their contract at expiration for another term, or someone who would like to bed down in an area for a longer period requests a long term contract from the onset. The typical length of a tenancy agreement in England is one year, with a break clause after 6 months for either of the parties to terminate the contract. However, it is also possible for a tenant to request a 3-year contract for instance, which would come with an agreed break clause. Some long term tenants prefer the Annual renewal of their tenancies as it gives implied flexibility and are happy to renew annually for as many as 11 years In some cases. There are strong advantages to having a long term tenant, with the first one being financial security. A long term tenant guarantees a stable rent and fewer void periods around tenancy renewal periods. This saves you the landlord the inconvenience of sitting on a costly empty property and is also beside the fact that when you’re sitting on an empty property, you’re still liable for council tax on the unit.  Long term tenants also tend to be reliable - they would have been evicted or eased out if they weren’t - and by extension tend to look after your property better, since they see it as their own. This conversely means there are fewer repairs to be carried out in your property, thus protecting your income. Read also:
  • ‘Light’ at the end of the tunnel?
  • Can Blood Speak?
  There are also shortcomings with long term tenants though, Firstly if it’s a long term contract option, there is always the risk that the tenants' life circumstances may change and leave you with a sudden and unexpected break in income, changes such as loss of job, death etc. Also, the tenants can come to believe they own the property and drag their feet when it comes to leaving. This may not seem like a big concern but can become problematic if you need to sell the property vacant. The biggest problem with long term tenants, however, is that rent stagnates over time. Rent increases by an average of 2.6% per annum in London, what this means is that if you have a long term tenant over ten years, you may lose out on 26% of rental yield growth over that period. At an annual rental yield of £20,000, that would equal roughly £52,000 of lost income over ten years. People choose Long term rental for different reasons such as its proximity to work or good schools. They may even be seeking some stability for their young family for a while whilst also building up their savings. We once had a tenant in Islington who moved into a unit we managed in the year 2000 and stayed for 11 years, the stability and saving they were able to accrue over that period helped them move to their own place, so these are some of the great points of long term rental. We however also had a property bought with a sitting long term tenant, the Landlord requested possession after some months as the rent didn’t match the going market rate. Emotions ran high and it dragged on and cost thousands of pounds in Legal fees, the tenant had become so attached to the property that they didn’t want to leave. Whether you’re comfortable with a long term tenant in your property or not, it is important to be armed with all the information you need to make the right decision on what is right for your investment as situation and circumstance demands.   For all your property related questions and needs, feel free to contact us for a non-obligatory conversation.   [/read]

CREATING AN EFFECTIVE BOARD FOR NIGERIAN ORGANISATIONS BY WORLD RENOWNED PROF CHAMBERS   Professor Andrew Chambers, former Dean and Professor Emeritus of Cass Business School London.   1. Tell us about TEXEM
These Executive Minds (TEXEM) pride themselves on their ability to customise programmes for their clients and TEXEM have a deep understanding of Africa. Also, TEXEM and its world class faculty partners have a very good grasp of contextual realities of Africa vis-a-vis fragile institutions, resource dependence, limited infrastructure and the huge size of government.  [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]  
  1. Beyond independence, what are the critical skills that a director requires to deliver a board’s oversight of company management effectively?
The two overarching responsibilities of the board are to set the direction of the company and to give effective oversight of management who are charged with the responsibility to implement that direction.  In answering this question, we are focussing on the ‘oversight’ responsibility, not the ‘directive’ responsibility; and, yes, independence is important.  Each board member should contribute to the board’s oversight responsibility – and that includes executive directors who are also expected to exercise independent judgement.  When the executive director is acting as a board member, he or she shares with all the directors an oversight responsibility.  ‘A director is a director is a director’ – whether an executive or a non-executive director. But, apart from ‘independence’, what other personal qualities are needed to contribute to effective board oversight.  The board need to possess these qualities collectively – we can’t expect each director to possess them in abundance.  Here are some of them:
  • Sector experience
  • Executive experience
  • Relevant technical expertise
  • Other appropriate diversity qualities – such as gender, ethnicity, nationality, linguistic
  • An enquiring, tenacious mind
  • A good team player, while being willing to challenge
  • The confidence to probe
  • Willingness to devote sufficient time
  • Adequate preparation for the board, and board committee, meetings
Effective board oversight does not only depend on the personal qualities of individual board members.  It will not happen unless there is a culture of openness and frank discussion at board meetings.  How frequently the board meets and the composition of board agendas and agenda papers are other factors.  Ensuring that key issues come to the board in a timely fashion is important.  Follow-up between board meetings is important too.  It is hard to over-estimate the role of the board’s chair in promoting these and other vital board attributes.  
  1. Sourcing and retaining top talent were named by 41% of 5,000 directors surveyed by the Harvard Business Review as their number 1 challenge. How could boards obtain and retain top talent?
Of course, this is a challenge for both management and staff and also board positions. Most leaders will affirm the real value of ensuring that the right people are recruited into critical positions.  Their job is so much easier if their lieutenants are competent, highly motivated and with the right personal skills to fit into the team.  It is usually better to leave a vacancy open until it can be filled with the right person – and that applies at senior management level as well as at board level. For both executive and board positions, it is now commonplace to use search consultants.  You may consider you know all the players in the sector who might be potential recruits, but you would be surprised how effective search consultants are at homing in on the best talent.  Having search consultants as ‘middlemen’ to negotiate terms also shields the candidate and the organisation from the aggravation that direct negotiation might entail. It is essential that the search consultant is given a clear specification of the nature of the talent being sought.  That presupposes that the board (in the case of board positions) has taken the trouble to work out what talent it needs to refresh the board – which is important.  The board should allow the search consultant to challenge this specification.  Similar considerations apply to the use of search consultants to fill executive positions.  Be careful not to specify just the technical skills sought: personality qualities are just as important. Once top talent has been obtained, it is not only a challenge to retain that talent: it is also a challenge to ensure that retained talent is not losing its cutting edge but continues to perform to a high standard.  The latter is where leadership comes in!  Many of the measures which will aid in retaining top talent will also contribute to ensuring that talent continues to perform well: for instance:
  • A supportive, enjoyable culture
  • Provision of adequate resources to enable work to be done well
  • The intrinsic interest and fulfilment in the work
  • Both opportunity for fulfilment and also recognition of achievement and advancement following achievement
  • Remuneration at or above market rates
  • Reward schemes which acknowledge good performance
While the above categories are germane to management and staff, they also apply in varied ways to board members.  For instance, independent, non-executive directors are likely to perform better if they receive a reasonable fee for their efforts – even though many corporate governance codes take the position that it is inappropriate for independent directors to receive any performance=related rewards.  Corporate governance codes often recommend that the performance of boards, board committees and individual directors should be evaluated, and feedback is important. For more insights on how to implement this, please attend my forthcoming programme organised by TEXEM scheduled to come up on the 10th and 11th of April in Lagos.   Read also:

  1. How can boards help manage economic and regulatory volatility?
It is often said that the only thing we can be certain about, is that the future is uncertain.  We foolishly tend to plan on the basis that present trends will continue into the future, but they are likely not to do so.  At present, the automobile industry is in disarray due to future uncertainty about diesel engines, electric vehicles, and future tariff-free automobile trading between Japan and EU, and Brexit.  The question is whether their boards undertook proper scenario planning in a timely way.  This emphasises the importance of risk identification, risk assessment and risk mitigation which should all feature at board level, not being left just to management.  Risk committees of boards are becoming more critical.  Boards should seek to be comfortable that key risks across the organisation have been identified and are being mitigated sufficiently so that the organisation is performing within its risk appetite. Regulatory volatility is often likely to be predictable in its nature.  Take for instance the current anti-social consequences of social media.  It should have been possible for the boards of social media companies, and in particular, their independent directors, to have identified the risk of attracting governmental regulation of social media companies, and to have designed their business model to minimise rather than attract that risk.  Many regulatory measures come into effect because of the misconduct of organisations and are therefore often predictable by management and boards of those organisations.  When predicted, measures may be taken to minimise the risk of increased regulation.  Alternatively, companies should be ‘one step in front of the regulator’, able to adapt to the changing regulatory environment in a timely way.  
  1. How can directors strike a balance between the pursuit of legitimate corporate strategic goals and the concerns of directors and executives who perceive themselves at increased personal legal risk for corporate wrongdoing?
Corporate strategic goals are only legitimate if they are legal, and achieved in legal ways.  The old school of corporate governance might have averred that the sole aim of business is to maximise profit.  But even Milton Friedman, that arch doyen of free-market economics, added ‘so long as it stays within the rules of the game’: ‘There is one and only one social responsibility of business – to use its resources and engage in activities designed to increase its profits, so long as it stays within the rules of the game ...’   In their pursuit of added value, there is a temptation to sail close to the wind.  It has been suggested that any business will be corrupt if it sees a chance of increasing value significantly, especially if (a) it considers there is little or no chance of being ‘found out’ or that the consequences will not be serious should discovery be made, and/or (b) its survival or future success will not be under threat.  Perhaps a more sober assessment would be to say that a small proportion of businesses will be honest in all circumstances, another small percentage will be dishonest whenever the opportunity presents itself, and the vast majority in the middle will be easily swayed depending upon the opportunity and potential consequences.   The progressive, contemporary and positive perspective is that it is in the enlightened long-term self-interest of organisations to be socially responsible corporate citizens – which includes adhering to the law and best practice.  Some would say that this is often just politically correct rhetoric formulated to encourage companies to behave on the broader ESG (environment, social and governance) interest.  Make no mistake, making a profit is the principal social duty of business.   Effective hard and soft law, as well as regulation, are necessary counter-balances to the temptation for management and boards to engage in wrongdoing.  Sometimes boards set management extreme and conflicting targets which encourage wrongdoing or questionable business practices.  Perverse incentives for management, agreed by the board, can exacerbate this.  Frequently the board will be unaware of the corners being cut by the administration.  A key issue is how board obtain the assurance they need that their policies are being implemented by management and that there are no ‘banana skins’ round the corner that the business is likely to slip over.  Many of the mechanisms boards have in place should be designed to mitigate this assurance black hole: space doesn’t allow these to be itemised here.   Across the world, the personal legal and regulatory responsibilities of management and directors are tending to increase, with a corresponding increase in penalties for violation.  The risk to directors is reduced by an open culture, high-quality information to the board, open dialogue at board meetings and a commitment to high standards of corporate governance.   A director is a professional person. Professionals are not infallible, nor expected to be.  But they will be culpable if they are negligent.  The record of board meetings will be an important source to demonstrate whether or not the board and its members have done their duty.  
  1. Does the board have a role in monitoring the organisational culture and leadership tone?
Yes indeed.  But it is much more than this.  The board’s role is not just an oversight role in monitoring management with respect to, among other things, culture and leadership tone.  The board’s purpose is to determine, inter alia, the organisation’s culture and leadership tone.  More than that, the board must be exemplars of the organisation’s culture and leadership tone.  If it isn’t, then the board shouldn’t expect the intended culture and leadership tone to be observed at management levels.  The chairman of the board has a huge responsibility to ensure that the behaviour of the board and its members are strictly ethical.  
  1. What are some of the highlights of this forthcoming Masterclass at TEXEM?
It is newly designed to ensure that participants are made aware of the measures and approaches available to impact positively on board and director effectiveness; when they are appropriate; and how they may be implemented.  The intention is to inspire participants with proven ways to re-engineer corporate governance in practice and to provide practical ‘toolkit’ advice on how to apply these state-of-the-art methods.  Those with significant prior experience will have the opportunity to benchmark their understanding against best practices which will contribute to effectiveness.  Networking and debating with other workshop participants will give valuable opportunities to identify the pitfalls and the tactics to resolve those challenges. Location:  EKO HOTEL AND SUITES, VI, LAGOS. Price:  £1,500.00 or N720, 000 Telephone contact: +447983128450 or visit https://texem.co.uk/programmes/developing-efficient-and-effective-leaders-for-success-in-an-era-of-slow-growth-and-low-performance.html   About the Faculty – Professor Andrew D Chambers Andrew is currently a member of the joint UK Institute of Directors/Institute of Internal Auditors’ panel developing new guidance for directors on internal audit.  He was a member of the UK committee that in 2013 published enhanced ‘Internal Audit Guidance for Financial Services’. He has run master classes in more than 48 countries across the world.   He was Dean of the leading Cass Business School in the City of London where he is professor emeritus.  Andrew has been a director of a large mutual insurer (The Medical Defence Union), a well-known charity (The Tavistock Institute), an FTSE250 financial institution (The Paragon Group of Companies), a bank (The National Mortgage Bank) and several smaller public sector, private and family businesses. He has authored some five hundred articles mainly on aspects of governance and auditing including about three dozen peer-reviewed research papers. Andrew was a judge for Hawkamah’s Bank Corporate Governance Awards in the MENASA region (2009-15), and (b) the ICSA-Hermes Transparency in Governance Awards (2011-15).  He conducted the 2012 Board Evaluation for the Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank. He was twice mentioned in the UK House of Lords’ debates as “an authority on corporate governance” and recognised by The UK Times Newspaper as ‘a worldwide authority on corporate governance’.  A past member of the FRC’s Auditing Practices Board, he was appointed in 2010 as the Specialist Advisor to the House of Lords’ Economic Affairs Select Committee’s Inquiry into Auditors: market concentration and their role that led to the recent audit market reforms.  From 2004 he was a member and until 2017 chair of Accountancy Europe’s (FEE’s) Corporate Governance and Company Law expert group in Brussels, the pan-European association of three dozen professional accounting bodies. Andrew has authored some five hundred articles focussing on aspects of governance and auditing he is the Author of:
  • Chambers Corporate Governance Handbook (2017), 7th ed. Bloomsbury.
  • The Operational Auditing Handbook - Auditing Business & I.T. Processes (2nd ed., Wiley, April 2010)
  • Tolley’s Internal Auditor’s Handbook and two dozen other books on these subjects plus translations.
Andrew started his career as an auditor and IT consultant with Arthur Andersen & Co before moving on to run an internal audit function of a manufacturing company.  He was the world’s first professor of internal auditing.  Awarded the IIA (UK)’s Distinguished Service Award (2008) and then the global IIA’s Bradford Cadmus Memorial Award ‘to honour individuals making the greatest contribution to the advancement of the internal audit profession’ as ‘an outstanding advocate, author, practitioner and subject matter expert, whose leadership and commitment to internal auditing has advanced the profession on a global level’ (2014).     [/read]

Nigeria LNG Limited, of of the largest companies in Nigeria, with massive residential facilities as well, is seeking to replace the Heating, Ventilating, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) Systems in its residential area buildings. Details below:  NIGERIA LNG LIMITED INVITATION FOR EXPRESSION OF INTEREST FOR INSTALLATION OF HVAC EQUIPMENT FOR NLNG RESIDENTIAL BUILDINGS (1) INTRODUCTION Nigeria LNG Limited (NLNG) plant complex located on Bonny Island, Rivers State, Nigeria, consists of six (6) Natural Gas Liquefaction trains with a total capacity of twenty-two (22) million tons of Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) per annum and 5 (five) million tonnes of Natural Gas Liquids (NGL) per annum as well as associated gas receiving, treating, storage and loading facilities with utilities and support infrastructure including its residential area. The Heating, Ventilating, and Air Conditioning (HVAC) Systems in the residential area buildings are due for replacement, hence this Expression of interest (EOI), inviting Specialist HVAC contractors who have the requisite experience and technical expertise to express interest in installation work for the proposed HVAC systems replacement. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]   SCOPE OF REPLACEMENT WORK Prospective contractors will provide installation works covering: (1)    Decommissioning of obsolete HVAC systems which shall include: (a)  Disconnection of main power supply to outdoor unit. (b)   Disconnection of refrigerant pipes from AHU and Condensing units. The pipes shall be sealed for re­use. ( c)  Disconnection of the drain pipe from indoor AHU (Air Handling Unit). (d)  Disconnection of outdoor condensing units. ( e)  Disconnection of indoor temperature control unit. ( f)  Removal of the indoor AHU from ceiling void. (g)  Removal of the outdoor condensing units. (2)  Removal of useful part from the decommissioned indoor and outdoor units and handover to maintenance department for storage. (3)  Disposal of metal scraps from the scavenged units, in line with NLNG waste disposal strategy. ( 4)  Removal of a section of gypsum ceiling (indoor) to create opening for removal and replacement of indoor units (AHU) in the ceiling void, and to create access spaces for ducting works. (5) Removal of existing transition ducts from the houses ducting system. (6)  Design, fabrication, insulation and installation of new transition ducts to connect new evaporator (AHU) unit to the existing ducting system. (7)  Installation of new free-issued outdoor condenser (outdoor) unit on the concrete pad to be provided by the contractor. (8)  Installation of new free-issued AHU (evaporator) units in the ceiling void. (9)  Procurements of HVAC installation accessories (HVAC units will be free-issued) (10) Connection of existing refrigerant lines to the new condenser and new AHU units. This shall require bracing short pieces of new field routed copper pipes and appurtenances to the existing refrigerant lines. Connections to be done in a professional manner by using protective dry nitrogen during bracing. (11)  Connection of existing drain pipe to the new AHU units. (12)  Re-insulation of the new and existing Refrigerants pipes including mechanical protection. (13)  Pressure, leak and vacuum testing of the refrigerant lines. (14)  Pre filling of the system with the appropriate refrigerant. (15)  Pre-commissioning, commissioning, final filling of refrigerant gas and start-up of the new HVAC systems. (16)  Carry out witness test. (17)  Hand over report after completion. (18)  Re-installation and painting of the removed gypsum ceiling. (19)  Site cleaning to remove all scraps, tools and unused materials etc, from site and relocated to the next location or demobilized. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS NLNG hereby invites interested reputable contractors with requisite experience and technical expertise in installation of new equipment in brown field to submit an Expression of Interest (EOI) for the purpose of pre-qualification for the installation of new HVAC equipment within NLNG residential area in Bonny Island. The companies considered to meet the pre-qualification requirements will subsequently receive Invitation to Tender for the work on the course of project development. Interested companies are required to provide the following information/documents for consideration: ( a)  Respondents confirmation of interest to participate in the pre-qualification for installation of HVAC equipment for NLNG residential buildings. (b)  Company profile and organisation structure, including parent company (if any) and information of key personnel (including CV and list of management personnel). ( c)  Certificate of Incorporation and Registration with DPR. ( d)  Current Tax Clearance Certificate or Evidence of Payment of Tax for  three years (2015, 2016, 2017). ( e)  Evidence of previous work experience (work done) within the last five years in installation of new HVAC systems (including split-ducted and multi-split systems) on an industrial scale. The interested contractor shall provide evidence of HVAC installation contract award(s), work completion certificates, etc, for referenced previous or ongoing HVAC work(s), and contact details of the clients representative(s). ( f)  Evidence of previous experience (work done) in HVAC design, customization and modification for industrial or residential service, including details of advanced diagnostic tools and methods for HVAC troubleshooting capabilities. ( g)  Evidence of strong HSE and Quality Management System (QMS) performance and compliance records. ISO 14001 & 9001 certifications. Good working knowledge of OHSAS 18001 will be positively considered.   Read also:

  COMPLIANCE WITH NIGERIAN CONTENT (NOGICD ACT 2010) The Nigerian .Oil and. Gas Industry Content Development (NOGICD) Act 2010 supports and details expected Nigerian Content deliverables within contracts in the Nigerian Oil & Gas industry. NLNG is committed.to the development of the Nigeria Oil & Gas business in compliance with the Nigerian Content Act 2010 for Nigerian Content Development. Interested companies shall comply with provisions of the Nigeria Content  Act that relate to these services, and in particular comply with the Minimum Nigeria Content targets for the scope, which are covered in the Schedule of  the Act. Failure to comply with the Nigerian Content Act  or demonstrated commitment to Nigeria Content Development shall result in disqualification from this Process. GENERAL NIGERIAN CONTENT REQUIREMENTS Companies responding to this advertisement are required to submit the following in compliance with the Nigerian Content Act, 2010: ( 1)  Tenderer shall demonstrate that the bidding entity is a NIGERIAN Company or an INDIGENOUS Company. Bidders should provide Certificate of Incorporation, forms CAC C02 & C07 demonstrating minimum 51% Nigerian shareholding. (2)  Tenderer shall provide evidence of registration with NCDMB’s NOGIC JQS. (3)  The process and procedure that explain the methodology of how it intends to comply with the requirements of the Nigerian Oil & Gas Industry Content Development Act 2010 (Nigerian Content Plan), and how it will achieve the set target(s) in the schedule of the Nigerian Oil & Gas Industry Content Development Ad, and any targets set by the Board. (4)  A plan for giving first consideration to services provided within Nigeria, with a list of work packages, third party services and subcontracts which should be reserved for Nigerian indigenous contractors, including those that will be provided by companies of Nigerian origin. (5)  A plan of how it intends to give first consideration to materials, manufactured, as well as assembled goods of Nigerian origin which shall include a breakdown of all materials to be utilized, and identifying those that are sourced locally, finished products and materials that will be procured from Nigerian manufacturing and assembly plants, finished goods that can be ordered from outside Nigeria through Nigerian authorized vendors and accredited agents, as well as those that would be directly imported. ( 6)  Tenderer is to submit a detailed training plan which shall provide sustainable training and development (including certification as applicable) for Nigerians, in line with the Human Capacity Development Initiative Guideline of the NCDMB. The training plan will include contract Specific training and estimated man-hours. Tenderer is required to submit Memorandum of Association with-Oil and Gas Trainers Association of Nigeria (OGTAN), to support their training plan. (7)  Technology Transfer Plan (TTP) explaining the methodology of how it intends to promote the effective transfer of technology from alliance partners to Nigerian individuals and-companies. (8) Develop a Research & Development Plan which shall explain the methodology of how it Intends to promote, education, attachments, training research and development in Nigeria in relation to the contract (including MOA with NCDMB approved Research and Development clusters or evidence of application for same. (9)  Provide evidence of registration with relevant agency of professional body like: NSE, COREN, DPR, etc. (10)  Details of the company’s corporate organizations overall human resources structure (management, supervisors, senior and junior skilled officers, etc.), identifying positions manned/occupied by Nigerians, with evidence of type of employment in-country, and identifying the positions manned/occupied by other nationals. Also include the proposed organogram for this work scope. (11)  A detailed description of the location of in-country committed facilities and infrastructure (assets, equipment, technical office, and administrative space, storage, etc.) in Nigeria to support this contract. (12)  Evidence that 50% of all equipment deployed to work by multinational and international companies (if applicable) are owned by the local subsidiaries. (Tenderer to provide verifiable evidence (purchase receipt, bill of sale, etc.) of ownership of equipment in executing this contract.) (13)  Provide evidence of approved Nigerian Content Equipment Certificate or status of the application submitted to NCDMB for the certificate for procurement of all equipment, systems and packages to be supplied on the contract (where applicable). Where Tenderer intends to use subcontractor(s)/supplier(s), Tenderer shall provide same information for the nominated supplier(s)/sub-contractor(s). SUBMISSION OF RESPONSES The Expression of Interest document should be submitted: In Hard Copy in a sealed envelope marked “Confidential -Expression of Interest for Installation of HVAC Equipment for NLNG Residential Buildings” to: The Head, Business Strategy & Vendor Management, CPM Department,, MD Division, Nigeria LNG Limited, Km 16 Aba Port Harcourt Expressway (INTELS Camp) Port Harcourt, River State. OR In electronic copy (PDF format) by e-mail to EOI.Response@nlng.com “Confidential -Expression of Interest for Installation of HVAC Equipment for NLNG Residential Buildings”- in the subject line. The submission in either format must be received by Nigeria LNG Limited not later than three (3) weeks from date of this publication (25, March 2019). PLEASE NOTE: This is not an invitation to tender. Full tendering procedure will be provided to applicants who are successful at this expression of interest, in accordance with NLNG’s pre-qualification procedures. Notwithstanding the submission of documents for the expression of interest, NLNG is neither committed nor obliged to include any company and/or associated companies, agents or sub-contractors in any bid list, or award any form of contract to any company and/or associated companies, agents or sub-contractors. This invitation to express interest does not guarantee that any company or group of companies will be requested to submit an offer to NLNG; it does not constitute any form of agreement or contract between NLNG and any company or group of companies. NLNG shall not be responsible for any cost incurred in responding to this invitation. This advertisement of Expression of Interest and Pre-qualification shall not be construed as a commitment by NLNG, nor shall it entitle respondents to claim any indemnity from NLNG, and/or any of its shareholders by virtue of having responded to this advertisement. This Expression of Interest is a simple invitation for interested vendors to express interest in the indicated work scopes and does not warrant any further feedback from NLNG hereafter. If you do not hear from NLNG within 3 months of submission of this publication, it should be taken that your application was not successful. SIGNED MANAGEMENT     [/read]

post_content: Oga Femi is a good landlord. I will give him that. He responds quickly to any issues with the house and the facilities management of his property is second to none. I cannot remember a time that we were without water or the rubbish was not collected on time, or the soakaway evacuated as and when due.   But the Landlord has done something that I can never forgive him for. In fact when my tenancy expires, I will leave his house. You see, I started renting a unit of 3 bedroom townhouse in his complex when rents in our estate in Lekki were very high. The estate had only a few houses and demand outstripped supply so I was compelled to ‘beg’ him to accept the N3.5m annual rent.  He refused, saying he wanted a corporate tenant and not an individual as a tenant. After a while, I got used to it and since the others in the complex were paying the same thing, it was not so bad.   Over the last 4 years however, the estate filled up and over time there were more houses than tenants and ‘For Let’ signs started to show up. The agent that got me my house offered me a newer unit at the same price but I declined, thinking that it will be hurtful to the Landlord. Now, over the past two years, due to the glut, house rents started coming down, to the point that newer houses were collecting between N2.8m to N3m per annum as rent while older houses like the one I currently stay in, would take N2.5m.   [caption id="attachment_61562" align="alignnone" width="300"] Does a landlord have an obligation to tell his sitting tenants that he will accept a lower rent than the amount they are paying currently?[/caption]   All this while, my landlord has been collecting N3.5m from me but was collecting N2.5m from the newer tenants. After paying my last renewal, I found out that my neighbour, who had just moved in, paid only N2.5m as rent! I was livid. I went to the landlord and accused him of disloyalty. He kept looking at me as if I was speaking Greek. After a while, he said that I should not worry and that he will accept N2.5m as next year’s rent. I refused. If he does not return N1m to me now or adjust my next year’s rent of N2.5m by N1m (so I will only pay N1.5m) I will not stay in the house.   He responded that he could not do that as we had agreed at the current rent and another term means a new negotiation. He tried to paint me as being unreasonable and going back on a signed and sealed transaction. It was a business transaction and I had the opportunity to reject the terms before committing myself. That, once I had agreed and paid, it was wrong of me to come back to him, to renegotiate the contract! Related Article: A beautiful Neighbour is Not Good! Can you imagine? I am supposed to be unreasonable! A man collecting N3.5m from his loyal sitting tenant, while accepting N2.5m from new tenants? I am resolved to leave his house at the end of my term. He is too dishonest for my liking. Or is he right? Am I being too emotional by expecting him to tell me the current rent he is collecting from others? Comments to feedback@castles.com.ng

Royal Design Scheme 2 has by Nest Homes is a well thought out scheme that has generous spaces but it is also very compact. Ideal for the modern Nigerian family     Ground floor: The ante room flows gracefully into the living room, where the piano has pride of place. The dining overlooks the generous play area with the Guest Bedroom not too far off. The kitchen comes second in size only when compared to the living room - it is massive! The living room and kiddie’s zone are side by side on the ground floor, separated by a wall to ensure the kids are closely monitored while they play. The dining area is by the corner, open to the music from the living room and drawing everyone together. It’s a modern family affair right here! Upper floor: Getting to the cut plane view of the upper floor, the wood flooring of the bedrooms is enhanced by the plush rugs at the center of each bedroom, and the dash of colours in different sections (the blue sofa of the family lounge, potted plants, e.t.c.) add to the beauty of this amazing layout.   The living room decor is a personal favourite and has an undeniable “wow” effect. There is a unique harmony of shapes and colours in this cool and breezy living room and the blue sofa spotted with a mix of blue and white throw pillows is a subtle detail. The lustre of the white circular coffee table on the circular rug contrasts beautifully with the black hues of the grand piano and its unique mustard green bench stool. The wood TV wall and console leaves you adds warmth to the scheme..     The feature wall in the dining is elegantly designed with warm wooden panels - the warmth spreading out from the wall surface visually expands the warm ambiance of the room. The dramatic lighting created by the spotlights excellently accentuates this tasteful finish. The choice of wood is consistent throughout the entire space; you can see how the same choice of wood grain and colour is used on the TV wall, creating a unique symmetry and balance with the beige floor. It feels light, airy, and open especially with its use of the sleek black and white dining set.   There is a complete transformation of this kitchen with a simple addition of tone. The plain white cabinet blended with the wood tones of the open shelves gives an element of sophistication  that elevates the design.   Here comes the playroom! The colorful rug creates this visual feeling of being outdoors on lush grass - pretty colourful patterns emulate the reds of roses and blues of violets.  The open shelved wall unit with side drawers will be a great attraction for children and will keep them busy for the nanny to catch a breath! But who says the playroom can’t have taste? Clearly not our designers because the array of graceful vases and beautiful lampshade on the contemporary shelf speak volumes about the affluence of this particular home. The framed bambi on the wall is just as colourful as vibrant as the child’s mind. The playroom is just in order to receive the star child! Alpha Mead Group Identified in London Stock Exchange Group’s ‘Companies to Inspire Africa 2019’ Report
  • 2019 report identifies a new cohort of fast growing and dynamic private businesses across Africa
Lagos: January 17, 2019                                             [caption id="attachment_61607" align="alignnone" width="1066"] Charlie Walker, Head of Equity Primary Markets, London Stock Exchange PLC presenting a certificate to Femi Akintunde, Group Managing Director, Alpha Mead Group at the launching of the London Stock Exchange 'Companies to Inspire Africa Report' which recognized Alpha Mead Group as one of the Companies to Inspire Africa yesterday[/caption]   One of Africa’s leading Total Real Estate Solutions Company, Alpha Mead Group has been identified as one of the companies in the London Stock Exchange Group’s (LSEG) 2019 Companies to Inspire Africa Report. The report, according to David Schwimmer, CEO, London Stock Exchange Group “identifies Africa’s most inspirational and dynamic private, high-growth companies to a global market”. The Companies to Inspire Africa report is a listing of 360 leading private corporates across 32 Africa countries that demonstrably outperform their sector and market peers. Aimed at improving awareness on the region’s most dynamic companies, the report showcases outstanding stories of innovation, growth and entrepreneurship in African business to a global audience. To be included in the list, companies needed to be privately held, and show an excellent rate of growth and potential to power African development. Reacting to Alpha Mead Group’s listing in the LSEG report, Femi Akintunde, Group Managing Director, said the listing is another attestation to Alpha Mead’s capacity for growth, transparency and strong corporate governance regime. He furthered: “one of the things that has driven us over the years, is the need to expand across Africa and provide an all encompassing service that makes the real difference in the businesses and operations of our customers”   Read also:
  • FG Seeks Advisers to Concession Tafawa Balewa Square
  • My Landlord has cheated me!
  “We observed the dynamics of the market and the challenges of most multinationals to run smooth operations across Africa with unified standards; and we chose to invest in developing our people, processes and technologies, expand our operations across major cities in Africa and warehouse key parts of the Real Estate value chain in one place for organisations with desire to implement a global Real Estate contract strategy”. “It is therefore fulfilling to see a prestigious report like the Companies to Inspire Africa attesting to the standard we have designed for our customers. For us, sustainable business operations goes beyond meeting the varying needs of our customers across Africa, it is also about assuring new international brands planning to come into Africa that the continent is no longer a black box. So, for us, this insignia of LSEG; also re-affirms that the capacities, opportunities and possibilities we are creating are recognised and accepted globally”. This is the third time in seven years, that Alpha Mead will be featured in rankings or recognitions of African promising companies. In 2012, it was ranked 16th Fast Growth 50 Company in Nigeria by the Allworld Network Inc. (co-founded by Professor Michael Porter of Harvard Business School) and The Tony Elumelu Foundation. Also, in 2013, Femi Akintunde, won the emerging category of the Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year, West Africa. These are among several international and local awards like the European CEO awards in 2014, Middle East and Africa Award 2017, Africa Real Estate Conference Award 2018, among others. HOW TO GET THE BEST DEALS WHEN BUYING PROPERTY FROM A DEVELOPER.   Buying property in a well laid out estate from a developer has several advantages despite the relatively higher price. However, there are ways of getting the property lower than the advertised properties. Here are four ingenious ways to do so  
  1. BUY IN BULK/BUY MORE THAN ONE: If you can afford it, buy more than one unit (land or property) from the developer. The cost per unit will be lower than just buying one. If you do not have the finance to buy in bulk as an individual, buying as a group is a good option. When you buy as a group, you have a stronger bargaining power unlike buying as an individual. You will observe that most cooperative societies are able to get land and houses at great prices because of the strength in their numbers. If you and your friends are interested in getting land or houses in a particular area, you can search for it together and negotiate as a group. Some developers even advertise the benefits of bulk purchases with offers like “Buy 5, get 1 free” sales promotions. This means that six individuals can buy six plots for the price of five plots.
 
  1. BUY DURING FESTIVITIES: Most real estate companies give discounts and do promotional offers during festivities. In the past, many real estate companies have given discounts and gift items to those buying properties around Easter, Ileya, Christmas, Ramadan, Children’s Day, Independence Day, Worker’s Day and even Valentine’s Day. Delaying your purchase to the next festivity can save you some money. I know an individual who bought a plot of land from a real estate company for N3Million in March of a particular year, only for the real estate company to do an Easter promo in April of that same year selling the property for N2Million. Thus making those buying in April gain N1Million.
Read also:

  • Outdoor Living…

  • Tenants can install their floors

  1. BUY FROM A PREVIOUS SUBSCRIBER WHO IS DESPERATE TO SELL: It is not only the developer selling units in the estate; usually there are previous buyers who now want to sell. Some of these buyers are willing to sell at lower prices: either because of desperation or because they had bought when prices were lower than the current price and can sell at lower than current prices and still make a profit. These previous buyers usually contact the developer of its staff to sell for them so remember to ask if they have any such sellers on their list.
 
  1. REQUEST FOR A DISCOUNT: If you are not buying in bulk, buying as a group, buying during festivities and you could not find someone desperate to sell, you can always request for a discount. Most real estate developers have some internal mechanisms to accommodate customers who request for a discount. If you do not request for a discount, you will not get any.

PROPERTY INVESTMENT Election season has no impact on property market   “The re-election of Buhari and the ruling party’s renewed majority in the national assembly impacted on the stock market yesterday, with investors losing another N85 billion while the benchmark index fell by 0.7 percent.” Was the opening statement in a Vanguard newspaper article after the Presidential Elections of February 23, 2019.  It is quite clear that Election fever in Nigeria is making many to get hot under the collar. Depending on which side of the political fence one sits, the Presidential election could be considered the fairest or the worst. Nigerians have been trading barbs and political insults at one another …….but they have not stooped from trading properties with each other. And the animosity and tension has not had any substantial impact on the market according to informal surveys carried out by Castles Lifestyle.   One of the accepted positions of practitioners in the real estate market is that property transactions during the electoral cycle will fall as property owners adopt a ‘wait and see’ approach. There will however be new players in the market: politicians seeking to sell their properties to fund their campaigns. These deals are usually discreet and because of the desperation of the politicians, the sales price is below the market price.   In this election cycle, there appears to be a change in the market dynamics. Politicians appear to have either found another way of funding their elections because there were very few election related sales. Some have postulated that the market is not liquid enough for the quick sales turnaround that politicians required so they did not bother to put their properties on the market. Others opined that the fear of the regulatory authorities particularly the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) to target property sales by Politically Exposed Persons also contributed.   Market sentiment was also largely unaffected by the elections. There was no slowdown in property advert placements or lack of interest in the buying and letting public. Transactions were not stalled for the elections. Developers also continued apace with their construction and marketing of properties with some breaking new ground. Instructions to seek JVs and other transactions were nit withdrawn.   The general sentiment of the market was that property investment has long-term consequences and short-term considerations like election results should not impact it. Indeed this way of thinking squares with the view of investors who look beyond the everyday behaviour of the economy and focus on long-term considerations of where the market will be in the future.  Unlike the stock market, those in the real estate market believe the future is bright enough to invest in. Professor Mahmood Yakubu,  INEC Chairman

The future of LEKKI. Lekki is the fastest growing area of Lagos in terms of development. From Lekki Phase 1 to Epe, new residential estates have come up. The residentai estates are varied: there are Government planned estates like  Femi Okunnu Estate and private estates like Victoria Garden City. There are estate like Abraham Adesanya Esate with only bungalows and other like Safe Court Apartments in Elegushi where there are only highrises. In Lekki one finds residential estates dedicated to recreation like Lakowe Lakes with its magnificent 18 hole golf course. There are many more planned estates and developments in the axis and homeowners can expect some interesting designs and concepts.   But the major driver of Lekki ‘s future will not be the excellent residential homes and estates but the commercial projects that are coming up. In the early 200s, Chevron, the massive oil company, set up its Head Quarters along the Lekki Epe Expressway, the immediate impact of its presence was that the area came to be known as ‘Chevron’.  This overt impact masked the fact that many of its well paid employees started renting and buying in the axis. Well laid out and serviced estates like  Crown Estate and Victoria Garden City attracted these employees. They also as cooperatives, were behind massive estates like NICON Town and Twin Lakes.  So apart from the well built estates, the main driver for these employees living in Lekki was the proximity to their office.   In an estate close to Greensprings School in Lekki, the developer was at his wits end. There were just no takers for the already developed houses. But within 6 months, all the houses in the estate were let. And because the properties were let, the developer was able to sell the houses to investors who wanted the income stream from the rents. Who rented the properties? Workers from the contractors working on the Dangote Refinery.   These two examples show that massive projects that employ a lot of workers will impact the way Lekki will develop. Instead of Lekki residents getting on the Lekki Epe Expressway to go to work in Victoria Island, Ikoyi, Lagos Island and even the Mainland as is the case now, these residents will live and work in Lekki. Already Lekki Phase 1 is home to many small and medium sized companies and both residents from Lekki and outside Lekki go to work there. There are also a number of commercial concerns on the Lekki Epe Expressway and shopping malls offer retail employment opportunities.   But the drivers are going to be major projects that will create thousand of high and mid-level jobs. Shell, the major oil company, is to move its headquarters to the Lekki axis as well as major projects like the Dangote Refinery and Dangote Fertilizer Plant will bring thousands of these jobs to Lekki. It will make sense for these workers to live, shop and get their children to school there. Like the workers in Chevron, they will form cooperative or groups and get estates developed to suit their tastes. Read also:

  • FIABCI to Unveil Nigeria Property Scorecard

  • A First Class Master Bedroom Design

The Lekki Deep Sea Port and Lekki International Airport may not directly employ the large number of employees like oil companies and massive conglomerates but they attract businesses which do. For the Lekki Deep Sea Port, think Apapa and for the International Airport, think Ikeja. These two projects are going to create commercial areas that will create thousand of jobs, which means that people will live and work in the axis.   As the character of Lekki changes from a predominantly residential axis to a mixed use location, the typology of developed properties will also change. Purpose built warehouses just like in Apapa and Ikeja, to serve the port and industrial concerns that will sprout up in the area will be good investments. Also business parks and office high rises like in Broad Street and Marina in the Lagos Island CBD will have ready tenants in the Lekki of the future. That’s our prediction for how Lekki will turn out in 2039.   Feedback Agree? Don’t agree? THE FUTURE OF REAL ESTATE IN NIGERIA IS CALLED PROPTECH   Just as FinTech has aggressively spread globally using technology in finance, property technology is now emerging. Property Technology, popular referred to as PropTech, is an array of technological advancement and tools that are currently revolutionizing the way people operate, buy, sell and rent and properties. Globally, investment in PropTech has reached $12.6 billion in 2017 from a mere $20 million in 2010. These new investments have been witnessed in portal listings, agency and brokerages, virtual reality, real estate crowdfunding, collaborative economy (shared spaces), big data and analytics, blockchain, artificial intelligence and smart building technologies.   But unlike fintech, the concept of PropTech has not fully gained ground in Nigeria. However, it is no longer a difficult subject to grasp. PropTech could be the deployment of apps within the real estate value chain including construction. The emergence of listing portals, crowdfunding and virtual reality tours in Nigeria all falls within the PropTech space. But there is a lot more than this in the PropTech bouquet that hasn’t happened in Nigeria yet. For example, democratising property investment in Nigeria is still at infancy even though smart city developments like the Eko Atlantic City are leading the path to energy efficiency and massive PropTech revolution.   Real estate is known to be hugely contingent on legal relationships and savvy negotiation with counterparties. Will PropTech disrupt or eliminate the conventional role of real estate agents or legal personnel? What about the popular property inspection – Will virtual reality replace the traditional site visits organized by agents? How about tile search and validation – Will the real estate developers and local municipalities adopt blockchain technology?   HOW DOES THE CHANGING PROPTECH LANDSCAPE AFFECT THE NIGERIAN REAL ESTATE MARKET?   The future for real estate (PropTech) in Nigeria is much closer that you might be thinking right now. Although the real estate industry is a conservative one, disruptions are already happening in sizeable pockets along the value chain. Agreed, it is not yet as aggressive as fintech, but the likes of Tolet; Estate intel; Filmo Realty; hotels.ng; CoBuildit; One Square Metre; Zama; Fibre; Nigerian Property Centre; etc are beginning to innovate and dare the conservative real estate practice in Nigeria. Traditional methods and conventional practices inch by inch are being broken with the goal of customer satisfaction and benefits.   We are in the fourth industrial revolution, and technology is determining how we live our lives. The risk of becoming antiquated while remaining resistant to these global changes is enormous. Besides, billions of dollars are being invested in the global PropTech space.  Projections are that the industry will hit US$ 20 billion in 2019. With Asia – Pacific region raking in about US$ 5 billion since 2013, a lot of interest in Africa is seen by venture capital firms. Who will be the winners and losers? Who will be affected? Developers, Lawyers, Valuers, Construction Companies, or Agents? What are the matters of concerns to various real estate stakeholders? This is the reason why we are holding this 1-day building capacity and thought leadership conference on Nigeria PropTech Industry – NIPROPTECH 2019   NIGERIA PROPTECH CONFERENCE (NIPROPTECH 2019)   Following the global emergence of PropTech and the start of a burgeoning PropTech industry in Nigeria, the Roland Igbinoba Real Foundation for Housing & Urban Development as part of its role in the Sustainable Development Goals (Goal 11 – Sustainable Cities and Communities) is hosting a capacity building and thought leadership 1 – day conference. The details of the conference are:  Thursday April 11, 2019 at the Eko Atlantic City, Lagos.   The conference will cover Blockchain; Artificial Intelligence (AI); Virtual reality; Crowdfunding; Big data and analytics; Smart building technology (Internet of Things – IoT); Construction technology (including 3-D Printing); Property listing; Collaborative economy (Shared spaces); Circular economy in real estate; Predictive Analytics; Smart contracts and “Legal tech”   NIPROPTECH 2019 is a gathering of all real estate stakeholders across the value chain who are innovating or at conceptual stages of innovations that will transform the way we operate, use and invest in the real estate market space. Roland Igbinoba                                                                                                                          Founder, Pison Housing Company rigbinoba@pisonhousing.com

WHERE TO CONDUCT A SEARCH ON YOUR PROPERTY - Written by Ayobayo Babade.   Before purchasing a property, it is essential for you to conduct your due diligence. There are five places where you can conduct a search on your property before purchase depending on the title the property has and facts surrounding the sale.  
  1. Lands Registry: If the property has a registered title like a Crown Grant, Land Certificate, Registered Conveyance, Registered Court Judgement, Certificate of Occupancy, or a Governor’s Consent, the place to search is the Lands Registry where you are to obtain the Certified True Copy of the registered title. This is because the Lands Registry keeps record of transactions to land which have been brought to the knowledge of the state through the process of registration.
 
  1. Surveyor General’s Office: If the property does not have a registered title and you desire to know the status of the land as well as the zoning, the Surveyor General’s Office is the place to go to where you are to obtain a Land Information Certificate (LIC). The LIC will inform you about the status of the land – free, excised, acquired or committed as well as the zoning of the land – Residential, commercial, industrial or agricultural. This will also assist the buyer to know what title will be processed on the property – Certificate of Occupancy, Ratification or if no title can be gotten on the property.
 
  1. Probate Registry: The Probate Section of the Court is the segment saddled with the responsibility of dealing with matters relating to the estate of a deceased person. If the holder of the registered title is deceased, there will be the need for a Probate search to determine the authenticity of the Probate Grant or Letters of Administration. If the title holder makes a Will before his death, the Will will be entered into Probate and a Probate Grant will be obtained before an Assent will be made by the Executors of the Will to the named beneficiaries. If the property holder dies without a Will, the survivors will apply for a Letter of Administration to administer the Estate of the deceased. The Administrators of the Estate shall be legally entitled to transfer the property to the would-be buyer.
  Related Article: The Future of Lekki  
  1. Court Registry: If there is a suspicion of a legal dispute relating to the property, a search in the Court Registry should be conducted. When there is a legal dispute in relation to a property, such property is said to be Lis Pendens. Lagos State has the Lagos State Lis Pendens Electronic Information System accessible online at http://lagoslispendens.com.ng/ which shows properties that have pending litigation at any of the divisions of the Lagos State High Court. A search on the platform can give preliminary information regarding the existence of a legal dispute in relation to the property.
 
  1. Social Search: If after you have done the other searches above, you still feel the need to probe further, a social search is recommended. My father and real estate mentor, Mr. Tope Babade, often says that “If your instincts tell you something is wrong with a transaction; check again, something is wrong somewhere.” One of the most revealing searches to conduct is what I term “Social Search.” This involves going to the property in question and asking neighbors, shop owners and transporters (like Okada men) in the area about the property in question. Facts about the property not revealed in documents are often revealed via Social Search.

My wife and I are used to the sound of a baby crying during the night. As veteran parents of two young children, we had gone through the night time feeding and all that and whenever we hear the sound from a neighbouring flat we let out a sympathetic chuckle and go back to bed. But these cries we were hearing this night was particularly grating on our nerves. Not because we disliked the baby but the fact that the baby in question was pushing up our service charge bill. Let me explain. We live in a block of six flats with five other occupants. Each flat is tenanted by similar type families- middle class with about 2 children, except for Okey, an investment banker, whose family is in the United States. The flats are serviced with 24/7 water and electricity. For logistic reasons, the flats are divided into two wings with three on the right wing with its own power and water services while the other wing also has its own. The cleaning of common parts and security is done jointly but the real costs are the water and electricity costs. So our own wing, which also has Okey on the ground floor and Kunle, an investment banker who lives with his wife and two children in the middle floor with me on the top floor have agreed that the generator that serves our wing will only be on from 7 in the night to 7am and that with Okey being ‘single’ he will pay a fifth while Kunle and I, with families will pay two fifths each of the water and power service charge. This system worked very well and even when Okey’s family came over, because it was for a short time, we didn’t alter the system. The problem came when, Kunle’s brother showed up one day with his wife, a new born baby and their mother. His brother’s house had been sacked by flood and they needed a place to stay at short notice. We were all sympathetic at first. However, one month, became two months and this became six months until, they had been staying with Kunle for eight months. Don’t ask me what happened to Kunle’s brother’s flat. I was not told and it was not in my place to enquire. What I know was that the service charges for the water and power bills were going up steadily. When I asked the security guard, he explained that because of the baby, the system of  putting the generator on for twelve hours had been amended to ‘whenever power was cut by PHCN’ (or is it Eko Disco now?) . Infuriated I asked who gave him the authority and calmed down when he said it was both Okey and Kunle when I asked Okey, he admitted that Kunle’s brother had virtually blackmailed him with the issue of the new born baby and he had to give in. he counselled that I should ‘take it easy’ as it was only for a while as they would soon leave. I kept my peace until one day I got a ‘crazy’ service charge bill and charged to Okey’s house to complain and seek his alliance for us to confront Kunle on the steadily increasing service charge bill. When I got to Okey’s flat, I found out that it was empty and the guard told me that yesterday, he had to rush to the United States on a family emergency when would he be back? The guard did not know. Did he drop any money for the service charge? The Facilities manager answered in the negative. So I did not know when Okey would be back but I did know that there would be a shortfall in the service charge account. I decided that it was time to confront Kunle. He was quite reasonable at first until he suggested that we share the bill equally until Okey came back. When I replied that, such a suggestion was not fair bearing in mind that he and his extended family were using most of the resources. Then his wife got slightly abusive. I decided to retreat to maintain my dignity. I now have two drastic choices: refuse to pay the service charge until we agree to a fair compromise – this will mean the services being cut off and would pressure him to agree. This would also have the impact of creating enmity between the families. The second choice was to report to the Landlord who would not approve of a large family using his facilities and will result in Kunle’s lease not being renewed. The third choice of agreeing to Kunle’s suggestion of sharing the service charge equally? That is not an option at all. What should the writer do? post_content: 4 Bedroom + 1B.Q. Semidetached Duplex – THRIVE Design Scheme 2 Luxury is not just about aesthetics, but about comfort too. It is not every day we see an exquisitely designed interior space that uses reserved colours and shades in its taste, and yet still hold enough visual interest while ultimately delivering great comfort to the user. This is exactly what our design team has been able to achieve in the Thrive Scheme 2 series. From the choice of colours and textures to the interrelationship between the elements in the spaces, this home is one that would peak the excitement of any homeowner. Even the kids’ room is not left out; the spatial grandeur of the room alone is enough to raise curious eyebrows about how so much could fit into one home! There’s nothing quite like it!   From the accent leather sofas of the living room on the ground floor to the warm coziness of the children’s bedroom on the upper floor, the concept for this design scheme resonates with the same attribute which echoes the word - COMFORT! The 3-dimensional imagery shows the absolute brilliance of what we have done with the space. Here, the view shows the entry into this beautiful home and finding oneself in the simple, but tasteful ante room. Right behind the user, in an obscure position is the visitor’s toilet. You can hardly tell it’s there! And that’s what we’re going for - a space that cleverly keeps private business away from prying eyes. It’s just brilliant. Absolutely brilliant!   A deeper exploration into this beautiful home finds you in the robust living area, which spills elegantly into a dining area. The staircase is within a few strides from there. But what absolutely takes the cake on this floor is the kitchen! It’s generous and the layout brilliantly thought-out. It comes complete with a laundry niche, lavish storage spaces and a mini-breakfast bar that can double as a place to sip a glass of wine or two with the occasional guest.  Seeing the pictures of the kitchen (as seen below) can absolutely make anyone fall in love!   The two bedrooms on this floor (guest and maid’s room) alongside the living room with dining and the large kitchen, maximum space utilization is achieved without compromise on functionality especially in the open plan arrangement of the kitchen/dining. The breakfast nook on the way to the kitchen with two bar stools can also serve for casual dining. Climbing up the stairs finds you in the upper floor spaces with an abundance of elegant furniture and decor resulting in vibrant spaces which are lively and yet relaxing. In consistency with the lower floor, there is an undeniable balance between beauty and functionality on this floor. A box room has even been located right opposite the family lounge area to help keep everything organized! Appreciating the wonderful interior design on the ground floor, the TV wall with black and wood console assembly makes for a never-boring feature wall; the adjacent wall niche with display wooden shelves keeps the living room classy and inviting. The ceiling design with spotlights is a neat and conservative arrangement, and further contributes to the balance of the space. The modern and unassuming planter in the corner goes on to express the homeowners love for simplicity and tasteful design. The dining area flows into the kitchen with minimum barrier and beside the mini-breakfast nook. The deep chocolate accent wall of the dining area warms up the space and the cream dining chairs offer a good visual contrast. Oh la la! Now comes the kitchen! The kitchen (on the right picture) is efficiency at its finest with the U-layout leaving everything within reach, it is a chef’s dream realized! Dynamism is then suddenly introduced into the space with the sharp chamfer right above the mini-breakfast nook. The choice of colour for the cabinetry is one that we’re highly proud of. The way the white is complemented beautifully by the silver edges of the cabinets - this kitchen has to offer a 5-star dining experience! Even Chef Gordon Ramsay must have something nice to say about this kitchen space!           This white kitchen is elegant and exemplifies refinement. The slightly patterned greyish floor which matches the wall tiles/backsplash helps to liven up the space while still maintaining its minimalist character. Just look at this beauty!           The whimsical style of this master bedroom makes it a place of retreat and recuperation. The chocolate ottoman is a feature piece that goes with the plush textured rug (which gives an island feel around the bed). Extra storage spaces abound in this space - the TV wall cabinet, the wall recess finished in white (above the bed head) and the open shelved wall unit just at the end of a wall. Bold monochrome art decor is the theme and is carried across in different locations - on walls and in open shelves for display. The white and wood cabinets break the monotony and adds character. The Master Bathroom decor evokes a pampered decadent feeling and the white subtle look is embellished with sections of greyish brown wall tiles around the shower area; the wood shelving of parts of the wash hand basin unit is the perfect icing!           A teenager’s room should be a reflection of their personality and a space where they can feel comfortable, safe, and inspired. For teens or pre-teens sharing a room, the bedroom above is ideal.  It is colourful and replete with personalized spaces. The lemon twin beds are sizeable and comfortable while the sleek desk area is ideal for studying. The double wardrobe and bookcase units ensure that boundaries and respect of property is maintained; a little personalization goes a long way in creating a safe space for teens where they’ll actually want to be. The flowy white curtains are similar to ones found in 5-star resorts - all dreamy and luxe!   The bedroom on the right is compact in size which made the use of smart storage spaces (they blend into the wall planes with little obstructions), a good idea. The white feature cabinet with the mirror front (facing the bed) and the white wall hung bookcase further emphasizes the sense of space.   This THRIVE scheme 2 home is one that our design team has put a lot of thought into. It accurately illustrates how comfort and functionality can work together to become one unified and unstoppable union!    There are more than a handful of things to love about this Scheme. We are quite sure you agree!   FOOTNOTE:   At the Nest Homes, we build homes that go a long way in enhancing wellbeing, convenience, and livelihood for YOU and family. This inspires us to create spaces that are particularly built around individual personalities and style. Our THRIVE Design Scheme 2 is a scheme under the THRIVE house-type (4 Bedroom +1 B.Q. Semidetached Duplex) in our on-going Abijo Development. All house-types in our development are priced very affordably and tailored towards unique and stylish living. If you are going to OWN a Home, why not own one that matches what you crave for in a Home? See remarkable interior styles and designs on the different affordable house-types on the blog section of our website at www.thenesthomesng.com We can be reached via the following channels: Phone: 01-4532779, 09060008356 Email: connect@thenesthomesng.com

“Is the new tenant a white woman?” Jimi, my neighbor asked as we met in the corridor.    “I haven’t met him or her” I replied. “Why?” I was curious to find out. “I heard a very serious American accent when Ayo (the agent), was showing her round. It is a lady by the sound of the voice I heard” We both pondered on the implications of an expatriate moving into the unoccupied flat of the four flat apartment block where we were both renting in Lekki Phase 1. “I hope this does not mean that the Landlord will start charging dollars o, with these oyibo tenants” Jimi who always read meanings into the Landlord’s action said. By this time, we had reached the parking lot. We exchanged goodbyes, got into our cars and went our separate ways to our respective offices. I did not give the matter another thought until Saturday morning when I heard raised voices in the compound. I was exasperated as I had come in just a few hours ago after a great time at a night club. I snuggled deeper under the covers hoping that the argument will stop but instead it grew louder and louder. I could recognise my co-tenant, Sister Kemi’s voice and there was another I could not place. Sister Kemi lives on the ground floor: a fervent Christian, she was always trying to get me to go for one program or the other. Although her evangelism was tiresome, she had a good heart and Jimi and I could count on her for a great meal on demand. I managed to get downstairs and saw Sister Kemi, who is not often agitated, raising her against another Lady who affected a ‘speak to the hand’ attitude. This was the new tenant. Her name was Sandra (call me Sandy) and she looked and sounded like an American, although she said she was Nigerian. I got involved. The cause of the conflict was simple: Sister Kemi had an all-night prayer session and Sandy was unhappy that she was kept up all night. Read Also: Over 2,500 Flats, Houses Office Spaces to Let “Don’t you want prayers?” Sister Kemi was nonplussed at a Nigerian who could stand against the Lord’s anointed.  “The previous tenants were fine with my prayer sessions and used to send me prayer requests”. But Sandy went off about her constitutional rights to sleep etc and that she would take up the matter with the ‘authorities’. I managed to make peace between both of them and then was treated to the spectacle of two ladies bouncing off and slamming their respective front doors. Over the next few weeks, Sandy and Sister Kemi clashed repeatedly over things that Sandy said ‘infringed on her right to happiness in her abode”. She was unhappy that Sister Kemi took too much space on the washing line, kept her stuff in the common areas, and had a prayer meeting in the house and so on. Jimi was not spared when one of his visitors parked in Sandy’s parking slot. Wiggling her finger under Jimi’s nose, she told him off in no uncertain terms. I managed to keep out of Sandy’s way until…………… Conclusion of the story next week

Stacks ----a unique architectural triumph in Lekki Phase 1 Stacks, a complex of 3 blocks of 3 units of terrace houses and 4 flats each, is a testament to excellent space management and innovative design. To break up the monotony, each block is subtly differentiated with the interplay of the front balconies and use of pale colours. Most of the car parking spaces are zoned to the front to reduce vehicular activities at the heart of the site; and almost by default the service building occupies a small area in front of the site for quick access. In an already used up site, pockets of green areas wrap around the main building to ensure there are break-out spaces within the site where residents can enjoy outdoor activities at the ground level. To give distinction to each apartment, the terrace units are “stacked” next to one another with vertical grooves separating them while the flats are stacked horizontally on top of each other across four floors. A typical terrace apartment measures at 317sqm and features a single car garage, a steward’s room, laundry, a store and an ante-room on the ground floor. The living room, dining area and the kitchen occupy first floor and the bedrooms, four in number, are on the second and third floor. The flats measure at 177Sq.M each with the exception of the ground floor flat at 132Sq.M. Each flat features 3 ensuite bedrooms, a kitchen, living and dining area and a steward’s room. Read Also: 4 Bedroom Duplex Design Scheme II To compensate for limited green area at the ground level, a green roof was created to serve as sky garden for the residents. The green roof also comes with its environmental benefits such as absorbing rainwater, providing insulation, and helping to lower urban air temperatures and mitigate the heat island effect. Generous areas of glazing and openings in the living and sleeping areas are used to optimize natural ventilation and lighting. The glazed areas are shaded by terraces on the floor above to prevent direct sunlight reaching the interior spaces. Details 4 bedroom terrace house with 1 room bq N80m 3 bedroom luxury flat with 1 room bq N60m Location: Jide Sawyerr Drive, Lekki Phase 1 Flexible payment plans with 40% deposit Contacts: Michar Real Estate Limited 08034000707, 08038600039, 08055000707

post_content: Modern Room Partitioning Ideas We all like large spaces for our living areas but it is often times necessary to define zones within the space. The key is ‘definition’ and not ‘demarcation’ because the former means that the space is cordoned off but that will defeat the purpose of the large space. Below are some examples of how to achieve this.   [caption id="attachment_67882" align="alignnone" width="616"] At section of this large living room has been defined as a small meeting room or TV section. This has been done by selecting a corner of the room, with a see-through divider at one edge.[/caption]   [caption id="attachment_67883" align="alignnone" width="622"] Here a bookcase is used as a divider – so we see that dividers can be functional furniture as well as achieving the purpose of defining the large space.[/caption] Read Also: A Unique Architectural Triumph in Lekki Phase 1 [caption id="attachment_67884" align="alignnone" width="643"] An indoor waterfall is a light and airy way to define the dining area from the living room space. Made of glass, with water cascading down on a bed of gravel, it is a focal point as well as an unobtrusive way of creating two zones.[/caption]
