post_content: Last week, I introduced you to Sandra (call me Sandy). Sandy was an ‘American-Nigerian’ by accent and behaviour and no sooner had she moved into the vacant flat in the block of four flats that I reside in, than she had issues with my other two co-tenants. (see www.castles.com. ng for Part 1 of this story). I had managed to keep out of  Sandy’s path as I had a major project at the office which meant that I worked till very late at night and left first thing in the morning. Some days I slept in the office. At long last, the project was over and I prepared for a nice evening before the TV catching up with the programmes I had set my DSTV to record. I was just lamenting how my team, Arsenal FC had thrown away a two goal lead when I had a sharp rap on my door. I opened to see Sandra looking very irate. “It’s disturbing my feng shui”. I was completely lost – was she talking about Chinese food? Read Also: My Aje Butter Co-Tenant! Part 1 It took a lot of explanation on her part to make me understand that my DSTV dish was affecting ‘her spiritual’ balance anytime she practiced yoga on her balcony. ‘Yoga’? Feng shui’?  This girl had totally lost in the United States where I presumed that she had lived for many years. I tried to explain to her that the dish could only be in that spot to receive signals and that it had been there well before she moved in. When she started talking about good neighborliness and lack of consideration on my part, I lost it. I angrily told her in my best American accent to get off my property and that I was within my rights to affect her feng shui, yoga or whatever. She stomped off angrily. Then began the war of attrition as Sandra did all she could to annoy me. If I sent the Mai guard on an errand she would call the agent and complain. If a few people come over to watch football in my flat, she would insist that they should not park in the compound. This continued for a few months until Sandy’s mother came to stay. We did not know she was Sandy’s mother – the wizened old village woman asking for ‘Chinwe’ definitely could not be mother to the globetrotting Sandy who very possibly was on first name terms with the American First Lady and many of the British Royal family? But she was. Sandy, sorry Chinwe went on her knees to greet Mama. Before long the pungent smell of stockfish and other native cooking came wafting from Sandra’s flat. Now cooking smells were a constant peeve’s of Sandra and she had told everyone off in the flat whenever she perceived a hint of such smells. So Sis Kemi, Jimi, (the other two tenants) and I made a beeline for Sandra’s flat. We were going to tell her off. Sandra opened the door, acute embarrassment written all over her face. “Are those the neighbours? Invite them in for a proper village meal” the old lady appeared behind Sandy. We all trooped in to enjoy one of the proper naija meals ever with Sandy eating with her fingers like the rest of us. Suffice to say that after Mama left, there were no more Americanisms from Chinwe (sorry Sandra)!

The perfect 2 Bedroom Apartment ……..for the business professional. Tango, Design Scheme 2 by Nest Homes, is a winning design for the Lagos business professional. This is an individual who loves to manage clients, bounce multi-figure ideas among similar minds, as well as entertain casual guests when the need calls for it. He is the task-juggler-cum-high-achiever who likes his ducks in a row and appointments synced with his business calendar. Just the way a brilliant mind operates! The zoning of this home is a mix of openness and a tint of privacy - with the master bedroom being completely off-limits. Just the way this expert juggler likes it! A look at the floor layout gives away the openness of the plan. There is minimal use of walls; the spaces graciously flow into one another, while the outdoor terraces are brought to life with dotted planters. The brilliance of the apartment comes together in a fierce composition with patterns, whites, textures and shades of grey dominating this home.   A closer look from this view gives a sense of calm and peace which pervades within this home. The front terrace can be opened up to allow a flood of warm sunlight which visually enhances the size and ambiance of the living room. This is wonderful, especially during an evening of entertainment when he has a handful of guests who love to clink half-full glasses of Moet & Chandon and make casual talk about the future of Blockchain technology. “Here’s a toast to digital gold investments!” Soft tones and textures are used prevalently, and the powder room is tucked inconspicuously into the corner; guaranteeing utmost privacy. Valiant pride lingers in this living space; it’s certainly a home to remember.   The walls of this living area are a work of art, distinct in character and with a sense of harmony that is mind-blowing. The pristine nature of the white sofa with the colours of the throw pillows is classic. The hazel-wood wall colour right behind magnificently complements it. The choice of the brisk frame edges for the brilliant photography collections gives away the selective nature of this host. The spotlights draw attention to this. Soft wood tones of the TV console, centre table, wall niche and dining cabinet just warms up the place introducing an alluring coziness into the space.   The living area is dominated with shades of beige, warm wood tones, and textures in visually satisfying unison. There’s a glorious interplay of lighting as it bounces off the textured surfaces. The large windows throw in copious amounts of sunlight, giving this home a theatrical feel.   The brick accent wall for the TV is a focal point and the goodness overflows into the adjoining wall in the study/home-office to maintain a sense of wholeness in the entire open plan layout; this accent wall is superbly matched with the light wood colour of the home-office furniture. The different patterns of the center rugs demarcate each space subtly, creating a visual island for the different spatial functions. Readl Also: Modern Room Partitioning Ideas   The uniqueness of this neat home-office is in the choice of furniture; the grey cotton sofa adds just the right dash of fabric to this space. The long and flowing window drapes further keep things cozy here. The soft white of midday sun unrestrained, bursts through the large windows. The grey sofa helps to maintain the atmosphere of business while the wall painting and brick accent wall adds a touch of class and warmth; this space is a “workstation” for high achievement!   The kitchen is well organized with unique shelving and compartments. The wood-themed lower cabinets are the perfect backdrop for the upper white cabinets with the added two step wood ledge which enhances the layout. The kitchen-dining combo allows an open-air interaction between guests of the home and the business professional who at this time has assumes the role of a private chef.   The subtle white brick backsplash provides a cohesive look to the entire kitchen-dining ensemble and together with the open nature of the design, creates the illusion of a wide space; perfect for cooking up an exotic dish of semovita and efo riro!   The double-door refrigerator is housed in a unique wall unit with extra neat storage above it; the light wood pantry beside it with open and closed sections is a perfect flourish.   The closet of this bedroom spans almost the entire wall facing the master bed and is organized to accommodate a TV wall unit with drawers below, swing doors on the side and above with textured plain white fronts. The two step picture ledges at the corner is a cool detail which rhymes with the soft wood colour of the wardrobe plinth.   A line of wooden dresser with a narrow mirror is neatly positioned at a corner where it is truly functional; the red markers on the grey plush rug add the dash of colour that this space needs to pop. Modern glass globe bedside lamps with polished black steel frames stand majestically on either side of the bed like two elegant art collections on display.   In the master bathroom, the white vanity of the wash hand basin blends with the white frame of the mirror above it. This is a brilliant idea and the greyish-white texture of the marble floor and walls provides a soothing neutral backdrop which makes for a smooth start to each day. The pattern created by the stretcher bond can hardly be missed. The bathroom is simple, yet visually intriguing!    FOOTNOTE: The  TANGO Design Scheme 2 is a scheme under the TANGO house-type (2 Bedroom Apartment) in Nest Homes  on-going Abijo Development. All house-types in the development are priced very affordably and tailored towards unique and stylish living. post_content: Nigerians don’t take baths. Don’t get us wrong, we are not saying that Nigerians do not bathe but that they do not run water into bathtubs and then linger in the water for several minutes. What they typically do to get clean is to put water in a bucket, lather their bodies with soap and then rinse off by drawing the water from the bucket with a smaller bowl. Those lucky to have flowing water, take showers. In either situation, what is required is a defined bathing area rather than a bathtub. But doesn’t a defined bathing area cum shower stall look a bit, well, bush? Not if you give it spa-like quality like the examples we have on this page……… [caption id="attachment_68456" align="alignnone" width="429"] An engaging mural on the focal wall, glass-fronted entrance, generous space, a backlit ledge and bench cast into the wall creates a wonderful enclosure for bathing Nigerian style.[/caption] Read Also: The Perfect 2 Bed Apartment [caption id="attachment_68457" align="alignnone" width="418"] We love the idea of this shower with an outside view. The window is placed at eye level where one can look out without their privacy being compromised.[/caption]   [caption id="attachment_68458" align="alignnone" width="497"] His and hers. This cavernous shower stall will take two taking a side by side showers. The ledge which is at the right height for storing bath things also helps break with the sterile and cold looking tiled surface.[/caption]   [caption id="attachment_68459" align="alignnone" width="556"] For those mornings when you have to rush! There’s nothing between you and the shower so you jump off the bed and under the warm rush of water. This shower stall integrated into the bedroom helps to give both distinct spaces an impression that they are bigger than they actually are, a perception which would have been limited by a wall and door. A curtain to wall off the shower area? Too tacky.[/caption]

post_content: The London Landlord and the Tenant Fees Act The United Kingdom Parliament proposals for a Tenant fees ban via the Tenant fees Bill will come into force on the 1st of June 2019 following Royal assent. The Tenant Fees Act, banning Landlords and agents from charging letting fees paid to tenants in the private rented sector and caps tenancy deposits in England to 5 weeks where annual rent is below £50,000. The aim of the Act is to reduce the costs that tenants face at the outset, and throughout a tenancy and is part of a wider package of measures aimed at rebalancing the relationship between tenants and landlords to deliver a fairer, good quality and more affordable private rented sector. Tenants will be able to see, at a glance, what a given property will cost them in the advertised rent with no hidden costs. The party that contracts the service – the landlord – will be responsible for paying for the service, which will help to ensure that the fees charged reflect the real economic value of the services provided and sharpen letting agents’ incentive to compete for landlords’ business. Read Also: The Deséa Golden Touch by Gufram – Coffee Machine Landlords and their agents will be unable to charge anything not exempted, that the tenant is required to pay as a condition ‘of the grant, renewal, continuance, variation, assignment, novation or termination of’ an assured shorthand tenant, or license agreement. This includes payments to third parties, either for service rendered throughout the tenancy or for specific performance of a job and third-party loans. Rules around deposits and how they are dealt with, will also be significantly tightened. There will be a ban on setting rent at a higher level for the first portion of the tenancy and then dropping it down, afterwards. This is to prevent landlords or agents trying to offset the ban on fees by artificially increasing the rent for the initial period to make up the costs. A higher rent than you would normally charge for the property, which is consistent throughout the tenancy will however be fine. Holding deposits - the commitment fee tenant pay when renting a property - will be limited to a maximum of 1 week’s rent and subject to statutory legislation on the repayment of this should the tenancy not proceed. Damages to property caused by the tenant’s breach of tenancy, such as cleaning cost for the property at the end of the tenancy will still be deductible from the deposit; as well as other default fees, you’ll still be able to charge if the tenant loses their keys or is late paying the rent. A landlord can also still charge for changes to the tenancy requested by the tenant or early termination of tenancy. Examples of banned fees are: * Credit checks * Referencing * Inventories * Charging for a guarantor form * Cleaning services * Professional cleaning * Having the property de-flea as a condition of allowing pets in the property * Admin Charges * Requirements to have specific insurance providers * Gardening services What does this all mean for you the Landlord? Some of the tenant fees goes towards important things like reference and credit checks, to ensure good quality tenants are the ones you hand keys over to and other bits of it to things like inventory checks, which creates an audit trail of the building’s condition, before and after the tenant moves in/out. Thus these aren’t costs that can be forgone. 57% of Landlords surveyed in research by the Residential Landlord association indicated a willingness to raise their rents to cover increased charges. It is important to work with an agent that can minimize the impact of these changes on your earnings and makes sure your portfolio isn’t left exposed. post_content: Have you ever wondered if you locked the doors after you were already in bed or whether you turned off your home appliances after you arrived at work? or perhaps you would like to know what your children are watching or what they were up to when you were away? These questions and many more are what smart home technology can answer for you. From home monitoring systems to light and sound control; smart home technology has just begun to scratch the surface of what is possible in the construction Industry. “The Sixtus” (4 units of terrace duplexes and 2 units detached houses at Lekki Phase 1 in Lagos, Nigeria) a project by Joe Etoniru & Associates is a showpiece of such technology. Safety & Security: Every home has some form of safety system no matter how rudimentary it might be. From the kind of locks used on the doors to whether or not a burglar bars should be placed on the windows and other openings. In the case of an automated home, there is the opportunity to take this up a notch. First, you can get a smart lock that reduces the need for the use of keys especially in cases where strangers have to access the home for various reasons. With most smart locks, you can create a code specifically for a person to use which can be deactivated once the person is done with their assigned task. The closed circuit door camera that takes pictures of everyone who presses your doorbell or was at your door while you were away is another ingenious way to protect your home against unwanted guests or track who has visited your home and at what time. Read Also: The London Landlord and the Tenant Fees Act Home Controls: Home control systems like Amazon Echo, Alexa, Siri and Google Home, provide convenient and safe ways to control your lights, blinds, garage door and more. With these control systems, your entire home can be automated to give you access to all home appliances from anywhere in the world using smartphones, laptops or other mobile devices.  For example, while you are away, you can control your TV and place parental control on what your children can watch at any point in time. Smart devices like Amazon Echo Show allows you make video calls, set wake up modes, leave a message on the system for your spouse or children and sing lullabies to your children without being physically present. With the recent heat wave in Nigeria, you can automate the Air conditioning in your home to come on at a specific time in desired areas of the house from the comfort of your phone. The wide range of existing SMART home technology gives prospective home owners the advantage of prioritizing which smart home functionalities they want in their homes as early as the design and build stage. “The Sixtus” presents and opportunity for the discerning homeowner to determine how smart he wants his home to be. post_content: US Embassy buys plot for consulate and developer introduces apartments at competitive prices…. A number of news reports put the size of the land purchased by the United States Embassy for its Consulate in Eko Atlantic City at the unbelievably humongous 1,000 hectares (10 million square meters)! This is about the actual size of the entire Eko Atlantic City itself! Perhaps the writers and their editors can be excused for such exaggeration because of the seismic implications of the transaction. The agreement between the United States Embassy in Nigeria and South Energyx Nigeria Limited, for the purchase of land for the site of a new American Consulate office complex in Lagos signed in May 2019 will come to be seen as one of the bellwether events in the life of the project. Although the actual size has been put at around 50,000 square meters (five hectares of land), the publicity coup of getting such an important institution as a US Consulate is massive – as attested to by the overwhelming media interest in the transaction. Also, the inference from the sale is that the US Government has confidence in the security, infrastructure, and viability of Eko Atlantic. United States Consul General, John Bray said during the signing ceremony “Eko Atlantic was selected for its world-class infrastructure.  Purchase of land for a new Consulate General will ensure we can continue to work with Nigerians to provide opportunities for economic growth and development in Lagos.” This will draw companies and other institutions to see Eko Atlantic as a preferred location for their business and this, in turn, will drive interest in residential apartments. Read Also: Decoration/Luxury: A New Idea of Safe by Agresti But will these apartments be competitively priced in terms of sales prices and rents?  Eko Atlantic is not only about luxury and high priced apartments. According to its website “One common misconception about Eko Atlantic is that all properties are priced above the market. While the city will naturally feature a range of high-end luxury apartments, it also houses many opportunities for more competitively-priced accommodation.”  When Highbrow Living spoke with Ron Chagoury Jr  (Ron Jr), the Vice Chairman of South Energyx Nigeria Limited in February this year, he explained that Eko Atlantic is for innovative developers. This is a blank canvass for developers to come up with projects to meet market demand and a segment of that demand is for competitively priced apartments. ‘What we have done in Eko Atlantic is to remove all the hindrances for the developer and give him an opportunity to push the envelope in terms of concept and design. Arkland Properties & Investment Co. Ltd, privately owned real estate firm, with over 115 developed apartments . in Lagos, Abuja, and Turkey, has taken up the challenge with its exciting A &A  Tower Project in Eko Atlantic City. A & A Tower, designed by the renowned Turkish architect Atilla Ilhan, is a development located in the Ocean Front District of Eko Atlantic  City. It consists of two and three bedroom homes, as well as shops and offices. A & A Tower has all the facilities and luxuries that come with a high-spec apartment block:  recreation facilities like gyms, cafes, and restaurants as well as a landscaped promenade directly adjacent to the ocean. But what will be extremely interesting to investors and future homeowners is the price point. We have been told by the developers that going prices for the two and three bedroom apartments will be commensurate to mid-range apartments prices in Ikoyi. This could be as much as 40% of prices of similar apartments in Eko Atlantic City.  According to JIDE OLUMODIMU,  MD/CEO  Arkland Properties & Investment Co. Ltd, A & A Tower will be at the top end in terms of finishing and furnishings but will be competitively priced to attract those whom ordinarily would be priced out of Eko Atlantic City.   2019 may well turn out as the year the rush for Eko Atlantic City apartments turns into a stampede. With the siting of the US Consulate in the enclave and competitively priced apartments offers like those in A & A Tower, the promise of luxury with first class infrastructure and the lovely views of the Atlantic Ocean has become an affordable reality.   Contacts: ARKLAND PROPERTIES & INVESTMENTS +(234) 813 952 2288, 08090652055, 08090652054, 08090652056, 08090652057 contact@arklandproperties.com

Over three hundred residents/families of Victory Park Estate sitting on about thirty-three Hectares of land located in Osapa London along Lekki Epe Expressway wish to bring to public notice and that of all the authorities concerned, our plight which has brought upon us untold hardship anguish and pain due to a combination of corporate fraud, unbridled abuse of power, and deliberately orchestrated inhuman treatment. We wish to state that categorically that the Asset Management Corporation of Nigeria (AMCON), some banks, the Awosedo family, and the Police are all culpable in this gross act of human rights abuse which has seen people being forcefully evicted from their homes using the instrument of government (the police), and faceless thugs! Below are the facts of the matter to further corroborate our position.
  1. As far back as 2003 some of us bought into Victory Park Estate land to develop our houses after doing our due legal diligence and confirming at the Lagos State Land registry that the title to the land that is in the name of Knight Rook Limited was free from any encumbrance. The legal interpretation of this was that the title was good, no mortgage, pledge, charge etc that had been obtained against it by any financial institution or any other company. From 2003 till about June 2017, the present homeowners in the estate continued to buy into the estate and also developed, living in the estate without molestation by anyone, either government or otherwise paying their Land Use Charge to Lagos State annually after having our various titles to our properties registered.
  2. To our amazement in June 2017, we all woke up to see a publication that Knight Rook Limited, the owner of the global C of O over Victory Park Estate was in Receivership with other companies over a loan one of the companies Grant Properties Limited allegedly took from Sterling Bank, Skye bank now Polaris bank, Wema bank and FCMB and used Knight Rook Limited with its shares as security that the companies have defaulted in paying while the said loan, now an eligible bank assets was subsequently sold to AMCON in 2011 or 2012.
  3. So it was AMCON that went to court to put the companies in Receivership.
  4. We gathered that following the suit filed by AMCON, the shareholders of Knight Rook Limited as security for the facility, transferred their shares to the nominees of the banks and resigned their positions as directors in Knight Rook Limited relinquishing their right to continue to act as directors of Knight Rook Limited. Interestingly, we discovered that the Awosedo's family who owned the companies continued to act to the knowledge of the banks and they (the banks) never stopped them from acting despite not being directors of Knight Rook Limited anymore which according to them, a change in that direction was effected at the Corporate Affairs Commission in Abuja.
Despite the removal of the Awosedo's from Knight Rook Limited, an agreement was entered by the banks with the other company of the Awosedo's; Grant Properties Limited to market and sell all the land in Victory Park Estate and remit sales proceeds to the banks which to the knowledge or active collaboration by these banks, the Awosedo's again defaulted without the bank doing anything and even AMCON after they purchased the asset. This agreement between the banks and the Awosedo's companies was made in 2006. So from 2006 until AMCON’s publication of putting the companies in receivership, members of the public were misled by the Awosedo's, the banks and AMCON to believe that the Awosedos have a right to the land in Victory Park estate held in the name of Knight Rook Limited. THIS IS HOW THINGS STAND PRESENTLY With the receivership by AMCON of Knight Rook Limited and by virtue of assets of Knight Rook Limited, AMCON is now laying claim to all the land in Victory Park Estate whether already sold and developed years ago or not and have continued to harass innocent bonafide purchasers without notice of their interest. They have filed several suits against the Awosedo's companies in court whereby some magic since the companies are in receivership, Knight Rook Limited admitted in court that it is indebted to AMCON and a consent judgment was made in that regard against Knight Rook Limited. These suits were filed by AMCON without joining any of the homeowners in any of the suits but have turned around to use the judgment in those suits to take over the properties of homeowners in the estate. On our part, on being aware of the suits and the attempt of the Receiver Manager appointed by the court on behalf of AMCON, we have taken steps to go through due legal process to challenge the right of AMCON to interfere with our possession but unfortunately, for eighteen months, nothing has been done and AMCON and its RM have continued to make life unbearable for us as they are not only taking over unoccupied and undeveloped properties, but even the ones in occupation, people are being forced out by the use of thugs and police! Just yesterday, (Wednesday 25th June 2019) two families were forced out of their houses and their properties sealed by court officials acting on these judgments obtained against the Awosedo's companies. We have also written petition letters to the Presidency, the Inspector General of Police office, the Lagos State Commissioner of Police and even the board and management of AMCON, yet no respite. We have heard, but refuse to believe that that the Inspector General of Police and the Presidency actually approved the actions of AMCON against us innocent law-abiding people who never took any loan from any bank to buy property in Victory Park Estate and therefore defaulted in paying. Pursuant to the above, it leaves a sour taste in the moth to see that the Awosedos, the banks, and even AMCON officials who committed and orchestrated this shameful fraud on our economy and us are left to enjoy their loot whilst we suffer no reason. Members of the public will be shocked that out of pure frustration, a family within the estate has started making plans to relocate to another country within the next few days! Finally, we are making a passionate appeal to President Muhammadu Buhari, the Vice President, Professor Yemi Osinbajo, the Inspector General of Police, and the leadership of AMCON to place a premium on the current administration’s anti-corruption mantra and right these wrongs by calling AMCON to order. It is a complete travesty of justice that ordinary Nigerians like us are treated like sub-humans and strangers in our own land and in a country governed by a democratically elected government. THIS INJUSTICE MUST NOT BE ALLOWED TO STAND! Signed Concerned Residents of Victory Park Estate
post_title: Victory Park Estate: Residents Seek Justice, Call On Presidency To Call Amcon To Order

[caption id="attachment_69803" align="aligncenter" width="1170"] Picture of a retaining Wall | castles.com.ng[/caption] Foundation coating is not a very common practice in this part of the world because of the cost implications, but it is increasingly becoming popular as traditional methods are failing. The key benefits of this approach is that a thorough coating of a foundation not only prevents water from ingress into the building interior, it also protects the main elements of the foundation from deterioration due to passage of water/moisture into it thereby helping to maintain its structural integrity throughout the building’s life span . Foundation coatings are usually made from bitumen and asphalt but together with other admixtures. These two materials are known to possess the functional requirement of limiting passage of moisture through them. Foundation coat is a chemical mix that normally comes in gelatinous or pure liquid forms at room temperatures. Coating of foundation is usually done during the construction process but occasionally, on post-construction maintenance. This approach is not really complex but requires due diligence during application. Unlike the use of damp-proofing membranes/sheets which are only placed in foundation or extended walls and laid over floors to prevent water from rising above into the interior area of the building, foundation coating are usually applied over the whole surface area of the interior and exterior sides of the foundation walls up to the ground or basement floor. It is relatively difficult to coat a foundation when the building has already been built but it is not impossible. There is also difficulty when coating foundations that are submerged in ground water; dewatering action would apply exclusively in such cases before further action. In applying coating on foundations, here are some simple steps;
  • Clean up the surfaces to be coated with clothing materials, brushes and other suitable tools. They should be free from grits, loose particles, protrusions and unwanted bulges.
  • Fill up voids and close or line up cracks with suitable admixtures.
  • If the concrete has not cured and surface coating must be done due to construction timelines or other reasons, you may be required to use a suitable primer or membrane before applying the coat.
  • Follow the manufacturer’s instructions on how to use their product. Some products will require that you apply directly without including any other mix while others will require the opposite.
  • Spray the solution onto the surface of the foundation up to ground floor using a spray painting machine or by the use of paint brush. Ensure the mix forms a thick even coat on the surface to ensure several layers of protection from moisture effect.
  • Then leave to dry.
Precautions must be taken to protect your eyes and body skin from exposure to chemicals as this is dangerous. Also minimized wastage by avoiding over-concentrated spraying – i.e. spraying so many content on one spot. Foundation coating in Nigeria will cost some N8,000 per sqm depending largely on the product used. There are at least 10 known brands in the Nigerian market today but their use is largely common with commercial, industrial and other non-residential facilities. However it can be used in any kind of building and other earth-laid infrastructure. Most of the available products are imported and there is need for massive local production to check cost. When you are embarking on a building project in areas susceptible to rising damp, flooding etc., foundation coating is a sure way to stop moisture from making a mess of your investment or space or as the case may be.   Osaz’ ENOBAKHARE is a young Contractor and the CEO of Heavens Contractors Ltd with over 40 successfully completed projects across Nigeria and elsewhere.  Phone: 08167394799 Mail: osaz@heavenscontractors.com Blog: www.engineerosaz.blogpot.com Web: www.heavenscontractors.com

post_content: The roof is built to withstand the adverse effect of wind pressure, direct sunlight, rainfall and external forces that act on it. A typical roof system will normally consist of the roof beam, the roof carcass, the roof covering, roof appendages (e.g. parapet) and the roof drain (see figure). While the roof beam and carcass are designed to provide the required structural support to the entire roof, the roof covering and drains are the exposed members that receive the rainwater over the entire surface area of the building and keep it away.        There are various roof types classified largely according to their design patterns or shapes as well as the materials used in their construction. The common roof types include Gable roofs which basically slopes in two opposite directions all along its stretch. Hipped roofs which typically slope in four direction -two each at opposite ends. There are also the Monopitch roofs which as the name implies slopes in one direction only. Scatter roofs are those that slope in various directions. Flat roofs are those with very little or no slope – most of which are perfectly horizontal and are built from reinforced concrete. A roof can be a composite that contains a combination of any two or more of the aforementioned categories. Some roofs are designed to accommodate chimneys, some designed to carry the load from as little as a household antenna to as heavy as radio communication towers as well as water storage tanks and roof-top open swimming pools, sports court, sit-outs, etc. Most gable, hipped, mono-pitch, scatter and composite roofs are covered either of asbestos, corrugated zinc, corrugated aluminium, glass, oven-baked tiles (with popular style including Milano, Gerald, Shingle etc.). Not many flat roofs are covered with any of the materials listed above and care should be taken to avoid the use of any of them materials singlehandedly in covering a flat roof because there are a number of issues associated with that most of which include unwanted water retention after a period of time and poor run-off potentials leading to persistent leakages. To keep your flat roof water-tight always, you have to; -  Design it properly: Flat roofs, besides scatter roofs and other complex roof systems are seen as the most critical type of roofs when keeping water completely out is the goal. When designing this type of roofs, if you are not a fan of concrete roofs and you are keened on the use of other materials, you should give it a little slope at least. The toast is -your roof is still regarded as flat even with a 4° slope. The slope is needed because metal or composite sheets don’t do well in water runoff over time when they are perfectly horizontal and this is why -due to the effect of temperature changes they expand and contrast and begin to form voids that retain water. The water retain begins to wreak havoc on small openings and joinery points even when overlapped up to the extent that they find their way to the other side. Overall, it is better to design such roofs with reinforced concrete in mind. If the roof is intended to carry load, then there is no sense in using any of the metal coverings. Your structural design must take cognizance of the additional weight to be imposed on the roof in the future as well as its effect as par penetration of rainwater. -  Build right:  Flat roofs are beautiful, especially for contemporary block design concepts, however, if you do not build them right they become a huge turn-off. When using concrete, you need to include a surface finish not exactly for fancy but to damp proof. Bituminous felt and asphaltic coatings can work well here but there must be a proper channel that drains off water collected immediately and it should be installed such that it slopes in the direction of the drain.  All the edges of the flat or concrete roof must be well protected including the parapet where applicable because water only needs a tiny space and boom! There has been increased use of tiles for damp proofing of concrete roofs. This practice although commendable as a short-term solution is not as effective as the jointing between tile members are highly susceptible to leakage. The right materials and expertise should be employed in building flat roofs. Roof carcass should be treated properly on installation in non-concrete flat roofs. -   Avoid placing things on your roof: Except for flat roofs originally designed to accommodate load (as in concrete roofs), you would be doing further harm to a flat roof by loading it at all. -    Seal appendages well: Where there are chimneys or say water storage tank or swimming pool, such areas should be double proof because of the effect of excess heat and overflowing waters respectively. -      Inspect, Recoat your roof or Change it: Metal Flat roof coverings should normally be inspected from time to time to check for leakages that can be quickly fixed and then your roofs should be recoated or treated every 20-30 years depending on the type. Damp-Proof Membrane also becomes weak on prolonged exposure beyond their design life span which is usually around 25 years, they should be replaced.        Engr. Osaz’ ENOBAKHARE
post_title: HOW TO KEEP YOUR ROOF WATER-TIGHT  (PART 1)

post_content: [caption id="attachment_69824" align="aligncenter" width="1080"] Admiralty Way - www.castles.com.ng[/caption] There are over 500 businesses on Admiralty Way with a significant number of churches and event centres. This is reminiscent of a high street and it may be time to regard Admiralty Way as one. Admiralty Way used to just be the street where everyone used to access places in and around Lekki Phase One but it has taken a commercial turn. With the diverse businesses and investments coming into Lekki, Admiralty Way makes a case for itself as an ideal location. This is a deviation to what used to be the norm when businesses were prohibited from opening up on the road to keep the area residential. The story has changed significantly as there are now over 30 malls and 10 supermarkets on Admiralty way and a few fuel stations. Home to a number of corporate establishments, Admiralty Way is a viable option for all types of business establishments. The multitude of people that pass through Admiralty Way either to visit the existing businesses or as a connecting road to other places will benefit any business, while the industry clusters will give added benefit to the businesses that fall under those industries. The most popular business venture on Admiralty Way are food franchises. There are at least 30 different food franchise on Admiralty way, all within walking distance of the other. The many mini-malls are home to various businesses that include boutiques, gyms, photo studios and marts as well as lounges like Skybell and Roma that ensure an active nightlife. Perhaps this business cluster is the reason all the major banks have now pitched their tents in Admiralty Way. Similarly, the logistics industry have some of their biggest players on Admiralty Way with the presence of GIG logistics and DHL. Office spaces on Admiralty Way are priced at about N80,000 to N100,000 per square metre. There are also standalone buildings that can accommodate big businesses. Detached houses are priced between N20m and N30m per annum. Admiralty Way continues to expand as a business hub. There are a number of significant ongoing constructions that could herald the opening of over 200 more businesses by the end of 2020.

The emergence of Forbes ranked most expensive neighbourhood to live in Nigeria has got a lot of people aspiring to live there. Castles Lifestyle Magazine decided to research the types of houses available for rent on the island and how much they cost. The result of a quick search on our website showed that there are more 3 bedroom flats and 4 bedroom terrace houses available for rent in Banana Island than any other type of house.   How much does it cost to rent in Banana Island? Banana Island is the creme de la creme of housing in Lagos. Rents run into tens of millions for most of the properties available. Houses on the roads leading to Banana Island are sometimes marketed as Banana Island houses but carry a much cheaper price tag. Our research on the houses available for rent in Banana Island shows that 3 bedroom flats are priced between N8m to N20m and 4 bedroom terrace houses are priced between N12m and N25m.  Why Banana Island? Filled with opulent and luxury homes, Banana Island tells a tale of wealth and affluence. Resident in Banana Island are people within the upper echelons of the society. A good example of the calibre of houses in Banana Island is the Ocean parade towers which sold its flat for $400,000 when it launched. Similarly, Banana Island houses business moguls that include Mike Adenuga and Kola Abiola.  State of the environment. The Island is a planned mixed development with dedicated areas for residential, commercial and recreational activities. Residents are provided with world-class utilities including underground electrical systems, as opposed to the overhead cabling common throughout Lagos, an underground water supply network, a central sewage system and treatment plant, street lighting and satellite telecommunications networks.  Security. Security in Banana Island is top-notch. The gated estate is manned by the estate security who have put a lot of security checks in place to ensure the safety of its wealthy residents and maintain its safe ambience.

It is fraudulent and Breach of Professional Conduct for a Lawyer to increase Price of Property to Make Profit over a Buyer or Vendor.... COURT

Anthony Ojigho v. NBA & LPDC (2019) LPELR-46895(SC); [2019] 9 NWLR (Pt. 1678) 399. A lawyer, Mr. Anthony Ojigho, was petitioned for fraudulently increasing the price of a property which the Petitioner (Banjo Onanubi) paid the vendor through the lawyer. It was alleged that the lawyer fraudulently induced the Petitioner into paying N40 Million for a property instead of N30 Million that was demanded by the vendor. The case of the Petitioner was that it was the vendor who informed him that the excess sum of N10 Million had been returned to be paid to him through the lawyer being in excess of reserved price. When confronted, the lawyer admitted the wrongdoing and made an initial refund of N3 Million and issued a cheque for the repayment of outstanding N7 Million which he later countermanded (stopped). At the hearing, the lawyer failed to enter a formal defence and chose not to appear at the Legal Practitioners Disciplinary Committee (LPDC) but was instead, represented by his Counsel, Mathias Emeribe. The LPDC held that where a solicitor engrosses an agreement for both the vendor and the purchaser of property, and both of them rely on his legal advice, he is a solicitor to both parties. It is immaterial that one of them introduced him to the other. Thus, the solicitor owes a fiduciary duty to both parties in the circumstance and that the lawyer in the instant case was in breach of same. Latest Developments in Eko Atlantic City The LPDC finally held that it was imprudent of the lawyer not to have entered a formal defence and to have sought to defend himself of very serious allegations of professional misconduct and impropriety through the avenue of his Counsel’s Written Address. The LPDC found the lawyer guilty of infamous conduct in the course of the performance of his duty as a legal practitioner and accordingly directed the Chief Registrar of the Supreme Court to strike out his name from the Roll of Legal Practitioners. Appeal to Supreme Court Being dissatisfied with the decision of the LPDC, the lawyer appealed to the Supreme Court which had no difficulty in dismissing the appeal for lacking in merit. Bage, JSC reasoned as follows: “Clearly, the Appellant [the lawyer] acted contrary to his oath as a legal practitioner when he misled the Petitioner to purchase the property at a price other than that which was fixed by the owner. Assuming the Appellant was ‘beclouded’ by a sense of professional duty of maximising the benefit or gains for his client, he had clearly breached this by refusal to pay-over the N10 Million balance demanded and collected in excess of the price fixed for the property.” Warning to lawyers and call for ‘cleansing’ This is a warning to all lawyers out there, especially those who also double as property consultants. Being overly too smart does not pay. According to Bage, JSC: “The Appellant’s self-deceit smartness is less than a half. Having conducted himself in a rather unprofessional manner, and having also admitted the misconduct by repaying part of the outstanding sums, a prudent Legal practitioner ought to do more by disabusing the minds of an observer as to his ‘saintly’ disposition in the transaction to negative the likely outcome or consequence of lacking in professional decency and probity. He has chosen to lace his bed with stones, pebbles and crumbs of iron and broken bottles; he surely deserves to sleep on the bed alone. This will send appropriate signals to potential violators of Rules of Professional Ethics, 2007 and other applicable provisions of the Legal Practitioners Act 2004. It is my view in this considered Judgment that having regard to the evidence led before the 2nd Respondent, I am convinced beyond any shadow of doubt, that the LPDC was correct in coming to the conclusion that the Appellant was guilty of infamous conduct in discharging his professional duties. I am also of the view that the 2nd Respondent was justified in its direction to the Registrar of the Supreme Court of Nigeria dated December 2, 2013 that the name of the Appellant be struck-off the Roll of Legal Practitioners in Nigeria.” His Lordship also called for some cleaning in the legal profession when he said: “We need a sharp depart from infamy in the legal profession. All Judges are first and foremost lawyers. Thus, the bench and the legal profession must continue in internal regulation and/or self-cleansing. This, in my view is to save the legal profession and invariably the entire structure with which justice is administered in this country. The justice mechanism essentially includes all legal practitioners, and by direct implications all those who practice as solicitors, transaction advisors or as in-house Counsel and law academics. They all belong to the category of ‘Legal Practitioners’. This is because their avoidable professional indiscretion, misconduct, imprudence or lack of probity in written agreements, transaction or advisory and other forms of professional engagements may, and have often formed basis of or cause of action in several suits and appeals.”
post_title: Supreme Court warning for Lawyers in Real Estate Practice

post_content: Published in 2017 When I found my current apartment, nothing suggested that I would be in for the scariest six months of my life. The house is a 2-storeyed building in a well-known area of Lagos. My apartment was a 2 bedroom flat on the ground floor. It had a spacious, neat compound and well-trimmed flower beds. The environment was serene with good road and also secure. Even electricity supply from PHCN was okay. But what swayed my mind was the fact that all I had to endure to get to work from the house was a short 25-minute drive. My landlord and his wife, both in their early forties, occupied the top floor.He was a retail businessman while his wife ran a small-sized confectionery store. The first time I met them, they were extremely pleasant and seemed genuinely delighted to meet me. We talked at length, touching on a variety of topics that ranged from spinsterhood to balancing work-life schedule. This clearly endeared them to me and I decided on the spot to take the flat. The agreement was drawn up and I paid the rent up to two years. It turned out to be my second major mistake —the first was not carrying out adequate due diligence by asking questions from those I met living in the area. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    Everything was smooth for the first seven months. During that period my relationship with the landlord and his wife was as amiable as ever. It wasn’t until eight months after I moved in before I started noticing certain strange events. For one, despite the fact that I was usually always tired once I returned from work, I found it usually difficult to sleep. If I eventually managed to fall asleep, I would wake up almost immediately covered with goose bumps and all my senses tingling. Another thing was the strange people who visited the landlord occasionally at night. They would come in around 9 pm. Any time they came around, there would be a lot of activities all through the night. A few weeks ago, an incident occurred that proved to be the final straw for me. My landlord’s strange visitors arrived as usual. The soft chants and activities went on through the night. I couldn’t sleep. The next morning, I decided that I would approach my landlord to complain about everything. What I saw when I stepped out wiped off that thought from my mind completely. Close to the wall that was adjacent to the main gate, a cubic cement block had been erected. Upon inspection, I found a thin chain attached to the block and the other end cemented to the wall. Locked to the chain was a small red padlock. Upon closer inspection, I found bits of feathers around and what appeared to be drops of blood. I quickly took some photos on my phone and ran away. Later when I was narrating the story to my friend, I showed him the photos but all the images were corrupted. All three photos!! I don’t really believe in the metaphysical but with what I have experienced over the past months, I’m beginning to have a rethink. My friend thinks I am being paranoid. Its been almost three weeks since I stepped into the house as I am extremely scared and don’t know what to do. Should I lose my rent and save my life?   [/read]

post_content: Published November, 2017 Windows are the ‘eyes’ of a building and as they are balanced on the human face, there is the temptation in design to arrange them uniformly and symmetrically. That’s a safe bet but it could be extremely boring. Fenestration is defined as the design and disposition of windows and other exterior openings of a building. [read more="Click here to Read More" less="Read Less"]    [caption id="attachment_5795" align="alignnone" width="300"] Photography © zone zuidarchitecten[/caption] The façade of this home, located in Roosendaal , The Netherlands, has been rescued from ordinariness by the varying sizes and shapes of the windows. In particular, the window that protrudes out from the house, making it large enough to have a deep window seat for someone to sit in, is a ‘double take’ feature and it has a very practical use as well.   [caption id="attachment_5797" align="alignnone" width="300"] Photography © zone zuidarchitecten[/caption] The typical response by architects in these parts to add some pizzazz to building facades is to attach facing bricks in some form of design, a practice which is getting dated and is more likely to ruin the looks of a building than enhance it. The creative placement of window and other openings can achieve the effect better, much better. Fenestration: the arrangement of windows and other openings on a building.
